IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is an aggressive form of leukemia and approximately 20-30% of AML patients harbor an activating mutation in the FLT3 receptor tyrosine kinase, which is associated with decreased survival and an increased rate of disease relapse. This application describes experiments aimed at testing the effects of 150030, a small molecule inhibitor of FLT3 and SRC family kinases, on AMLs using genetically engineered syngeneic and PDX models, with a long term goal of conducting clinical trials in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term survival and quality of life of head and neck cancer patients that undergo surgical resection are pivotal on the ability of the surgeon to fully remove the tumor while avoiding healthy normal tissue structures. Our capacity to successfully obtain tumor-free surgical margins is limited by our ability to visualize microscopic residual tumor cells. The proposed paired-agent imaging technique allows the separation of bound signal from non-specific signals due to plasma transport kinetics, and tissue leakage that plagues single fluorescent tracer techniques. If successful, this technology will ultimately allow clinicians to identify and remove involved tumor margins to maximize patient survival and reduce life-long surgery-induced morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Aside from these few examples, the prevalence and functions of alternative polyadenylation (APA) in a wide spectrum of human traits and diseases remain largely unknown. We propose to develop innovative bioinformatics and experimental methods for identifying 3′UTR APA quantitative trait loci (3′aQTLs) and nominating APA-linked disease/trait susceptibility genes in a wide variety of cell types and environmental factors, followed by in vivo functional characterization using our unique CRISPR engineering system. We expect to establish APA as an emerging and important molecular phenotype to explain a large fraction of GWAS risk SNPs, leading to significant novel biological insights into the genetic basis of APA and APA-linked susceptibility genes in a wide spectrum of human traits and diseases. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed research is focused on the development of a cross-protective recombinant subunit candidate vaccine against Eastern, Venezuelan and Western Equine Encephalitis Viruses (EEEV, VEEV and WEEV, respectively) that are highly pathogenic in humans. The proposed vaccine combines recombinant glycoproteins from all three New World Alphaviruses into a single formulation. The use of a single vaccine candidate to protect against multiple related encephalitic Alphaviruses provides a valuable medical countermeasure for pandemic threats and a safeguard against biothreats. Validating the success of this vaccine candidate would have a significant impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We compared alveolar fluid from 88 patients with critical COVID-19 with similar samples from 211 patients with pneumonia from other causes to generate a hypothesis about how SARS-CoV-2 injures the lung. We will test this hypothesis using a novel treatment (CRAC channel inhibition) that has shown promise for the treatment of patients with severe or critical COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)-related cirrhosis is the second leading cause of liver transplantation in the United States. In this proposal, we will investigate the critical contribution of the heterodimeric integrin receptor α4β7 and its ligand, mucosal addressin cell adhesion molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1), in governing hepatic inflammation and fibrosis via immune cell recruitment to the NASH liver. Our primary objective is to identify viable targets for therapy that will halt the development and progression of NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The practice of transplanting kidneys from hepatitis C virus (HCV) infected donors into patients without HCV is considered `experimental' by many leaders in the transplant field because of limited information about risks and benefits. Specifically, when patients consider accepting a kidney from a donor with HCV infection, their doctors are not able to provide good information about key issues, including: the risks of not being cured of HCV, whether choosing to accept these kidneys is likely to improve their survival, the long-term function of these kidneys after transplantation, and whether there are additional infectious risks such as developing complications from viruses other than HCV. This multi-center trial seeks to define the safety and determine the most important outcomes after transplanting kidneys from HCV-viremic donors into HCV-negative patients in order to move the practice from experimental to routine clinical care from the perspective of patients, providers, and payers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing loss is widespread in the United States and can affect our ability to follow speech in noisy environments. The proposed research will investigate how head motion can be used to improve hearing, and how this is enabled by central auditory pathways in the brain. This will lay the groundwork for future studies to develop improved neuroprosthetics, such as cochlear implants, to restore natural hearing ability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is a global public health concern and causes acute and chronic hepatitis leading to severe liver diseases. Although HBV DNA replication can be suppressed by effective nucleoside analogs, an indefinite course of antiviral treatment is necessary to suppress viral replication continuously due to its ineffectiveness in eliminating integrated HBV DNA and cccDNA. Currently, the treatment goal is to achieve functional cure that is defined as the clearance of the HBV surface antigen (HBsAg), NO clinical test, however, is currently capable of sensitively detect cccDNA from patients. The goal of this application is to develop a cccDNA assay that can be used to detect cccDNA to monitor antiviral treatment efficacy and identify “cured” subjects who can then be free of a life-long regimen of unneeded anti-viral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Variants in the noncoding genome have profound effects on human health, but their role in gene regulation is not always clear. This study will investigate the role of quantitative epistasis between cis and trans regulatory variants in regulating complex traits. Insights from this work will advance basic and applied fields of genetics, providing insights into the tunability of gene expression to promote the development of therapeutics for gene regulatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative N6-methyladenosine (m6A) regulates gene expression and is involved in cancer progression. This project seeks to understand the mechanisms for m6A to regulate DNA repair by interplaying with environmentally-induced RNA and DNA base damage in cancer cells. The results from this project will provide new mechanistic insights into environmental carcinogenesis via the interaction between RNA modifications and DNA repair, the key to developing m6A as a new target for cancer prevention, diagnosis, and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is in part driven by dysregulated interactions between immunoregulatory and inflammatory T cells within the intestine, however, the exact cellular players involved and how these responses become dysregulated are less clear. We show here that conventional STAT3 and BATF-expressing T cells are critical for maintaining intestinal homeostasis through interactions with microbiota-dependent inflammatory γδ T cells. In this proposal we will define STAT3 and BATF-regulated cellular pathways required for these interactions and the role of microbe-dependent γδ T cells in disease using a novel murine IBD model.

PHR: Project Narrative Among patients with diabetes, 15% develop a foot ulcer, and 12-24% of individuals with a foot ulcer require amputation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome mining of natural products from sequenced microbial genomes is a promising strategy to new human therapeutics. To increase our abilities in performing genome mining, this MIRA proposal will i) fundamentally understand the enzymology of biosynthetic enzymes that make natural products; and ii) develop more effective methods of mining with a particular emphasis on using resistance enzymes to prioritize biosynthetic pathways that may produce natural products of desired biological activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acinetobacter baumannii has emerged as a bacterial pathogen of immense healthcare concern due to increases in frequency and severity of infection, combined with the organism’s ability to resist front-line antibiotics. A. baumannii antibiotic resistance is predominantly attributable to expression of members of its expansive repertoire of drug efflux pumps that extrude antibiotics from the cell. This project will develop broad spectrum efflux pump inhibitors (EPI) that reduce or eliminate the organism’s ability to efflux multiple classes of antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Our lab studies how G proteins within the cell are produced with the help of a set of chaperones called Ric-8 proteins and are activated by a class of cell membrane-spanning receptor molecules, called adhesion GPCRs that sense or adhere to neighboring cells or the mesh network that surrounds cells. Our proposed work will use cutting edge techniques to solve the structures of Ric-8 / G protein complexes in order to deduce the mechanism of how they help fold or produce G proteins. We recently worked with collaborators to solve the structure of self-activating adhesion GPCRs engaged with G proteins and from this, we propose a series of experiments using protein biochemistry, cell biology and genetic mouse models to determine the mechanisms of how adhesion GPCRs become activated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory processing provides an opportunity for us to understand how neural circuits represent information from the external world, but we know relatively little about how non-sensory internal factors such as arousal, spontaneous movements, and cognition can alter the perception of stimuli. This research proposal will reveal the influence of these non-sensory factors on the primary visual thalamus during active visual perceptual behavior. The overall outcomes of this proposal will underscore a need for the field to take into account how internal factors such as arousal, task-engagement, and visual spatial attention impact early visual signaling before reaching cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Up to half of adults will experience a traumatic event in their lifetimes and up to half of patients seeking treatment for substance use disorders have PTSD, and these individuals have worse treatment outcomes for both conditions. Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a common sequela following trauma and is highly comorbid with PTSD. Here we aim to test the overarching hypothesis that following a traumatic event, the opioid system becomes dysregulated in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis leading to heightened anxiety and risk for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The purpose and objectives of the training program proposed for continued support remain the same: to prepare bioengineers for an impactful career in orthopaedic research as part of a focused program leading to the Ph.D. degree in Bioengineering. Training a diverse cohort of bioengineers side-by-side with orthopaedic surgeons and life scientists, will continue to foster an environment conducive to research and education in the orthopaedic arena. Indeed, this has been the formula that has been very successful in our training program thus far and, in today's complex and interdisciplinary research world, this approach is more essential than ever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High-risk neuroblastoma is characterized by amplifying the MYCN gene and deleting the 1p36 (D1p36) region of chromosome one, which houses multiple tumor suppressors. This proposal will test the hypothesis that the INTS11 protein is a potentially novel target in high-risk neuroblastoma. To that end, we will utilize a combination of INTS11 knockdown and small molecule inhibitors to determine if neuroblastoma cells are uniquely dependent on INTS11 for viability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex genetic disease caused by genetic and environmental factors. Genome- wide association studies have identified hundreds of small genome sequence changes—called DNA sequence variants—that are associated with increased risk of developing T2D, but how these variants affect the ability of pancreatic cells to respond to stress is unknown. This project will assess how T2D-associated variants impact the ability of pancreatic cells to respond to stress related to the burdens of making and secreting insulin, and the findings are expected to broadly enhance our understanding of how T2D-associated variants affect sensitivity to other forms of cellular stress and promote T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) is a debilitating genetic disorder characterized by enlarged, leaky small vessels (telangiectasias) and inappropriate, fragile connections between arteries and veins called arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), which can rupture leading to aneurysms, stroke and even death. There is an urgent need to develop disease-modifying interventions that could prevent, stabilize, or even normalize AVMs because there are no drugs for effective treatment in HHT patients, while invasive surgical procedures pose inherent risks. Our studies use established and novel HHT animal models, pharmacological approaches, and molecular-based methods to uncover the mechanistic signaling cascades involved in AVM pathogenesis and identify new drug targets for the therapeutic design and treatment of HHT.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative How infants learn to progress from spontaneous and seemingly disorganized movements into goal-directed and refined motor skills is unknown. Until we understand how to promote successful infant learning, we cannot design optimal early intervention for infants with or at risk of neuromotor developmental disabilities. The objectives of this project are to 1) determine the relationship between error rate and the development of reaching skill in infants with typical development, 2) identify individual and environmental factors related to the development of skilled reaching in infants with typical development, 3) identify patterns of concurrent brain activity that differentiate between spontaneous arm movements, early reaching attempts, and skilled reaches in infants with typical development, and 4) identify patterns of concurrent brain activity that differentiate between spontaneous arm movements, early reaching attempts, and skilled reaches in infants at high risk for cerebral palsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This COBRE will establish a Center on Sleep and Circadian Rhythms in Child and Adolescent Mental Health at the EP Bradley Hospital with the objective to establish and build a comprehensive and sustainable resource to support the growth of pediatric sleep, circadian rhythms, and mental health research while providing mentorship of junior Project Leaders for research and for transitioning to independent scientific careers with external funding. The proposed COBRE Center will be the first and only NIH-funded research center in the country to have an explicit focus on sleep, circadian rhythms, and pediatric mental health. Extending the reach and accelerating the growth of a cadre of clinical scientists with multidisciplinary training and with the infrastructure to support advancement to independent research careers shows great promise to improve the health and well-being of children and adolescents and their families.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal the PI will study patients with Idiopathic Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (IHH), an inherited disease of delayed puberty and infertility for which the genetic etiology remains to be fully characterized. In this training grant the PI will define the role of copy number variants (variants that lead to loss or gain of genetic material) in IHH and will be trained in human genetics and clinical investigation. Successful execution of this proposal will fill critical gaps in our understanding of the genetic control of human reproduction and will enable the PI to develop into an independent investigator.

PHR: Project Narrative The Georgia Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) Project will continue to collect population-based data on women’s attitudes, experiences, and behaviors before, during, and shortly after delivering a live birth in Georgia. Mothers will be contacted by mail, phone and web (when it becomes available). The information gained from this surveillance system will be used to identify risk factors and disparities in adverse birth outcomes, determine maternal and child health priorities, develop and evaluate programmatic interventions, and inform policies that will improve the health of mothers and infants in Georgia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE OFFICE OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: CDC-RFA-DP-21-001 Louisiana PRAMS Application Project Narrative:  Louisiana Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) is an ongoing, population-based risk factor surveillance system designed to describe maternal behaviors and experiences that occur before, during, and immediately following pregnancy. The program is administered by the Louisiana Department of Health, Bureau of Family Health in conjunction with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Information collected by Louisiana PRAMS is used by health professionals, policy makers, and researchers to develop and modify programs and policies designed to improve the health of mothers and infants. Louisiana PRAMS provides both quantitative and qualitative data on:   Factors that influence pregnancy outcomes, including health insurance status, chronic  conditions, pregnancy intention, contraceptive use, prenatal care, alcohol use, tobacco  use, physical abuse, and life stress   Mothers’ experience of pregnancy complications, including hypertension, diabetes and hospitalizations   Maternal experiences and behaviors after the baby is born, including depression,  maternity leave experiences, breastfeeding, contraceptive use, tobacco and alcohol use,  and safe infant sleep practices 1

PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-001 Louisiana Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System Application

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Novel strategies aimed at reinvigorating anti-tumor immune responses have shown promise for the treatment of cancer, but the majority of patients have only minimal or transient responses to these treatments. We have hypothesized that aberrant T-cell metabolism limits anti-tumor T-cell responses and have identified redox imbalance as a critical regulator of T-cell immunity in experimental systems as well as in primary patient samples. The proposed research will test the importance of oxidative stress as a driver of intratumoral T-cell dysfunction and determine whether metabolically rewiring T-cells to enhance redox homeostasis represents a broadly applicable strategy for improving immune responses in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Chronic low-grade inflammation, a hallmark of advancing age termed inflammaging, has been implicated in metabolic dysfunction. Increased senescent burden in both solid organs (i.e.; liver, adipose tissue) and immune cells, also known as immunosenescence, likely contribute to inflammaging, but the interplay between the two, the mechanisms governing these processes and how they lead to metabolic dysfunction are poorly understood. Here, we seek to elucidate whether cellular senescence per se, immune cell recruitment/accumulation and the associated tissue inflammation, or both underlie age-related metabolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The high prevalence of violence (i.e. intimate partner violence, child abuse, community violence) experienced by people living with HIV (PLWH) and its negative impact on HIV-related health outcomes underscore the need for systematic violence screening and intervention to be incorporated into HIV care services. To help resource- limited Ryan White HIV Clinics (RWCs) and AIDS Service Organizations (ASOs) at the heart of the United States HIV epidemic prioritize the forms of violence on which they should dedicate screening and support services, we first assess the relative impact of the different forms of violence on retention in HIV care and HIV viral suppression. Next, we explore the preferences of key stakeholders (i.e. PLWH, HIV care providers and staff at RWCs and ASOs) for violence screening and support service provision/referral to ultimately inform evidence- based violence screening protocols and a proof-of-concept violence support model that leverages existing local RWC and ASO infrastructure to address psychosocial consequences of violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  HSE is a life-threatening viral infection of the CNS. In some children, forebrain HSE is caused by inborn errors of TLR3-, IFN-a/b or -l-mediated CNS-intrinsic immunity, whereas in others, brainstem HSE is caused by inborn errors of DBR1-dependent RNA lariat metabolism, which probably disrupts CNS-intrinsic immunity by TLR3- and IFN-independent mechanisms. We aim to study the CNS-, tissue-, and cell-intrinsic basis of forebrain and brainstem HSE in two complementary ways: (i) we will analyze TLR3, IFN responses and HSV-1 infection in iPSC-derived olfactory and cortical neurons, and other CNS cells including microglial cells, from patients carrying known and novel genetic etiologies of forebrain HSE, (ii) we will analyze lariat accumulation and HSV-1 infection in TG and brainstem neurons derived from DBR1-deficient patient iPSCs. These studies should enable us to analyze in greater depth and breadth the cellular basis of human CNS- intrinsic immunity to HSV-1 and the pathogenesis of HSE.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of how neural circuits can undergo modulation to drive adaptive behavioral responses to account for changes in their external environment. My work focuses on how these shifts in neuromodulation can affect memory processing circuits and lead to changes in the acquisition and retrieval of memories. This becomes particularly important when it comes to drugs of abuse, specifically alcohol, and my work will highlight mechanisms by which an animal’s internal state can affect memory processing for drugs of abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mitochondrial metabolic enzyme glutaminase (GLS) has been implicated in diverse pathological conditions ranging from neurodegeneration to cancer, and an allosteric GLS inhibitor is currently being evaluated in several clinical trials. The studies proposed here are aimed at defining the molecular mechanisms underlying a new regulatory process we have identified, whereby the bioactive phospholipid phosphatidic acid (PA) binds and potently activates GLS even in the presence of clinical GLS inhibitors, thus rendering these drugs ineffective. Knowledge gained from this project will shed new light on the physiological regulation of glutamine metabolism, and will determine whether suppression of mitochondrial PA signaling can overcome the problem of resistance to GLS-targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients who suffer from cancer, muscle wasting is very common and has devastating consequences, including reduced quality of life and overall health, interference with cancer treatment, increased complications from cancer treatment, and reduced survival. Unfortunately, right now, we do not have any medicines to help prevent or treat muscle wasting in patients suffering from cancer. To help address this issue, we propose a Phase II SBIR study to investigate and develop new and promising potential medicines for cancer-induced muscle wasting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative proposal that combines next-generation sequencing with state- of-the-art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this proposal are to identify gene variants that are associated with compulsive alcohol use, alcohol tolerance and response to FDA approved medications using genome-wide association studies (GWAS) in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to establish a data/tissue repository accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms of alcohol addiction. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of compulsive alcohol use in males and females, and create a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow-up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a life-altering autoimmune disease that is overrepresented in Veterans due to service-related exposures. It has a progressive and mostly devastating course, with the highest mortality of all rheumatologic diseases. Although SSc affects many organs of the body, hardening of the skin is the most common and distinct feature and a primary cause of disability and decreased quality of life. Importantly, skin changes guide treatment. Recently, promising new therapies have emerged for SSc, but clinical trials of these therapies are hampered by the lack of reliable ways to measure the complexities of skin changes. To tackle this important clinical challenge, we propose a handheld device, the Myoton, that noninvasively and rapidly measures many mechanical attributes of the skin. We will rigorously validate the Myoton as a practical and objective tool to aid with SSc staging and evaluation in Veterans with this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: Dr. Rhoades is an active VA investigator whose work seeks to identify novel therapeutic approaches to treating cancer induced bone diseases. Her current projects seek to target novel interactions between bone marrow macrophages and tumor cells using immune therapies in combination with tumor targeted therapies to reduce tumor growth, bone destruction, and bone marrow complications. These studies will impact Veteran populations, which have higher rates of invasive and metastatic tumors and lower survival rates, by identifying effective and less toxic therapies for patients with bone metastatic tumors including breast, head and neck cancer, and prostate cancer (which all impact Veteran disproportionately).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because, for youth with chronic kidney disease (CKD), cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of morbidity and early mortality. Children and adolescents with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) are significantly less active than their peers, but effective strategies to promote physical activity and the extent to which physical activity and muscle strength mitigate CVD complications in this population are unknown. Supported by a multidisciplinary team with expertise in pediatric patient-oriented research, measurement of physical activity, and the use of digital technology to promote healthy behaviors, this award will 1) identify optimal intervention components to increase physical activity and 2) quantify the relationships between physical activity, muscle strength and CVD, in youth with CKD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) afflict ~8% of Americans and ruptured AAA carries >80% mortality. AAA screening programs have increased identification of small AAA, but there is no medical therapy to attenuate dilation and rupture rates have not decreased. Thus, the treatment paradigm of annual surveillance of growth toward the surgical threshold has not been revised in over 20 years. In retrospect, clinical trials of medical therapy for AAA may have failed to show an effect on rate of growth due to the broad inclusion criteria. We propose that easily accessible, minimally invasive techniques may be engaged to gather biomechanical data of small AAA to improve characterization of this pathology. More specifically, aortic strain and plasma pathologic matrix markers may reflect the evolving aortic wall remodeling. Using computational analysis of acquired biomechanical data, this project will establish a model to define AAA biology that will be responsive to medical therapy, thereby shifting the current surgical treatment paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence-based treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are available, but they have suboptimal rates of symptom improvement and high rates of dropout, and evidence suggests that patients' concerns about treatment and therapists' ineffective responses to these concerns prevent optimal outcomes. This trial tests an Adjunctive Writing intervention for Amplifying Response and Engagement (AWARE), which integrates findings from the health communication literature to optimize patient outcomes in evidence-based PTSD treatments via the target mechanism of improved patient-therapist communication about patients' treatment-related concerns. This trial has the potential to enhance outcomes for patients with PTSD and improve the field's knowledge of processes for enhancing PTSD treatments, and further, given that AWARE is a brief intervention that provides structure for improving patient-therapist communication during existing check-ins in evidence-based, widely disseminated treatments, AWARE can be easily scaled and implemented to enhance patient outcomes in treatments across mental health disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disabling neurological disease affecting individuals in their most productive years and is prevalent among US Veterans. MS is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system where self- reactive T and B lymphocytes destroy myelin. Recently, B cell depleting anti-CD20 therapy has been approved for the treatment of patients with MS but with limited success and concerns of adverse effects/complications from global depletion of B cells. This proposal is to evaluate the preclinical potential of drugs targeting S- nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) for B cell immunomodulation that suppresses effector B cell activities (disease-causing) while inducing regulatory B cell activities (protecting against MS).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Photosensitivity is common following a mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and can significantly impair functional rehabilitation outcomes. While sunglasses are conventionally used to treat symptoms, they are not designed to resolve issues with photosensitivity underscoring the need to develop more effective treatment options. Recent work has shown that neurofeedback interventions, such as Low Intensity Pulse-Based Transcranial Electrical Stimulation (LIP-tES) can be effective in treating post-concussive symptoms, but it remains unknown how LIP- tES interventions alter brain activity and whether this approach can help alleviate photosensitivity symptoms, specifically. This proposal will address these questions by conducting a pilot study on LIP-tES for the treatment of photosensitivity and collect resting-state functional neuroimaging scans before and after intervention. Results of this study may significantly improve functional outcomes for veterans living with photosensitivity and further our understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying photosensitivity in mTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a highly prevalent neurodegenerative disorder and involves deficiencies in endo- lysosomal trafficking. The AD risk gene, SORL1, is a mediator of endo-lysosomal trafficking in conjunction with the multiprotein sorting complex retromer and represents a novel therapeutic target. In this proposal we will elucidate cell-type specific actions of the SORL1-retromer pathway in human neurons and glia; we will also use patient tissue and derived cell lines to assess how a polygenic burden of endo-lysosomal risk in impacts endosomal and lysosomal morphology and neural gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will precisely map the vessels that supply blood to the two tissues of the pancreas—the exocrine tissue that makes digestive enzymes to breakdown our food and the endocrine tissue that makes insulin to control blood sugar. For many years, those who study and treat patients with pancreatic disorders have been taught that the exocrine and endocrine parts of the pancreas have separate blood supplies that do not mix. However, we have discovered that these two intimately located pancreatic tissues share a common blood supply, and through mapping these blood vessels, we hope to explain how disease in one part of the pancreas often results in failure of the other part.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative Diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, including Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), remain some of the most debilitating diseases among veterans. With the incidence on the rise, a fundamental understanding of IBD is essential to developing effective therapies and an eventual cure for this disease. Our ongoing research is aimed at defining new mechanisms to promote wound healing in patients with active disease. Our strategy is to use a highly collaborative, broad-spectrum approach that integrates trainees as a mechanism to bolster the next generation of biomedical veteran research scientists.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic Post-amputation Pain (cPAP) is a major unsolved healthcare problem, especially prevalent in the Veteran population, and notoriously difficult to treat. We seek to answer key clinical questions that will improve patient management using the framework of the Million Veteran Program (MVP). First, we will identify a robust multi-faceted MVP-specific phenotype for cPAP that will serve future studies by our team and other researchers. The core, second aim of this proposal is to identify common and rare genetic risk factors for cPAP and its genetic overlap with related disorders such as anxiety, depression and PTSD. Finally, we will model the effects of perioperative management and psychosocial factors and Social Determinants of Health on the development of cPAP. This proposal supports a future line of research aimed to inform a comprehensive risk score to assess amputees’ risks of developing chronic pain, and to potentially identify novel therapeutic interventions via identification of pathways genetically associated with cPAP.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: For Veterans with Serious Mental Illness (SMI) experiencing homelessness, obtaining permanent housing is only the first step in achieving stability and improved quality of life. Many recently housed Veterans continue to struggle with aspects of functioning and day-to-day living. Maintaining connection with providers and sustaining engagement in treatment during the transition to permanent housing are additional challenges. While the VA has made considerable efforts to provide mental health care to Veterans with SMI, few treatments designed to increase functional recovery have been applied during this key period of transition out of homelessness. In this pilot study, we will administer a brief behavioral treatment enhanced with mobile technology, conducted within the GLA Domiciliary residential treatment program. With this research we hope to learn whether such treatments can be applied to meet the unique needs of homeless Veterans with SMI and could prove effective in improving community integration so that these individuals may function more fully in their lives and society.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: 40% of veterans have hypertension (HTN), a leading modifiable cause of cardiovascular disease (CVD). However, a significant proportion of veterans do not have adequately controlled HTN despite multidrug regimens, highlighting the need for novel therapeutic approaches. Vitamin D (VD) deficiency is highly prevalent in veterans, and we have determined that disruption of VD signaling in macrophages induces HTN and promotes macrophage renin secretion, which surprisingly has the capacity to regulate systemic blood pressure and macrophage function. We propose to evaluate the mechanisms by which macrophage renin causes HTN associated with disrupted VD signaling and to characterize its impact on macrophage function. Successful completion of the proposed aims and training plan will prepare the candidate to become an independent physician scientist identifying translational therapies to reduce the risk of metabolic disease and its complications in veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is more prominent in women and has greater severity in the Hispanic and Black populations. One in 4 veterans has arthritis (25.6%), compared to 1 in 5 civilians. RA is a disabling autoimmune disease that is associated with depression, cardiovascular disease, and psychosocial stress as well as being more prominent in women. Our clinic at the Jesse Brown VA sees around 700-900 RA patients annually. There is no cure for RA and up to 50% of RA patients do not respond to current therapies. Therefore, we aim to find a novel therapy that can slow or reverse RA pannus formation. To resolve the critical barrier in RA treatment, we have identified a novel pathway that plays a central role in pannus formation by linking immune cell activation with joint blood vessel formation. The goal of our research program is to understand the mechanism of the identified unique pathway and to evaluate whether the blockade of its function may be more effective than the current standard of care therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The exocrine pancreas of patients with type 1 diabetes is smaller than the pancreas of healthy subjects and shows histological and functional anomalies. This project is aimed at generate mechanistic insight into how beta cells influence surrounding tissues to coordinate activity across pancreas compartments. By identifying the effectors and principles governing this local regulation, we will be able to understand how the progressive loss of beta cell function produces pathological changes across pancreas compartments in people with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Emergence of chemoresistant disease enriched with poorly differentiated stem-like cells that escape chemotherapy and T immune cells is a leading cause of death in ovarian cancer (OC) patients. Our data suggests that these tumor cells can be attacked by another immune cell type called Natural Killer (NK) cells. Unfortunately, NK cells are defective and low in number in OC patients. To solve this problem our group has developed a novel platform that can activate and expand NK cells at clinically scalable levels for immunotherapy, called super charged NK (sNK) cells. In this study we will test the efficacy of sNK cells, alone and in combination with chemotherapy in targeting chemoresistant OCs. Biomarkers of response and mechanisms of tumor targeting will also be explored. Findings will have immediate potential for translation into therapies for women Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Pain worsens well-being and functioning, interferes with rehabilitative care and community integration, and contributes significantly to poorer health outcomes in Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Pain-trauma comorbidity is associated with greater utilization of medical services, greater use of psychiatric medication and increased total cost of treatment. The pathophysiology underlying pain-PTSD co-morbidity is currently unknown and current pharmacological treatments often lead to unwanted and debilitating side-effects. Identifying specific neural mechanisms for pain-PTSD co-morbidity will lead to the development of novel, scientifically based, therapeutic approaches for treating co-occurring pain in this treatment resistant population. The proposed research is relevant to Veterans health since it aims to lessen suffering and morbidity associated with co-occurring pain and trauma and decrease the total cost of treatment for the Veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A mutation in C9ORF72, a gene of poorly defined function, is the most common cause of Frontotemporal dementia and Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, neurodegenerative disorders that together affect approximately sixty thousand individuals in the United States and approximately 1.4 million people worldwide. This proposal seeks to identify pathways within T cells that contribute to neural inflammation in mice with a C9ORF72 mutation. Evaluation of T cell fate choice and function in human C9ORF72 carriers may be useful to reveal pathways important for neurodegeneration and in the future could serve as a diagnostic for risk of dementia conversion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, substance use disorders (SUDs) can cause long-lasting changes in the cellular makeup of neurons in the brain. Here we propose to develop new technologies to identify changes in protein expression and localization that occur in response to substance use. These novel tools may enable the design and implementation of new pharmacological treatments to treat SUDs in patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The US Veterans are at risk to develop blood cancers due to exposure to carcinogens, such as Agent Orange, during their active military service. Many of these cancers are treated with allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (allo-HCT). While allo-HCT is a life-saving therapy for hematologic malignancies, this life-saving therapy has life-threatening side effects - lethal immune activation caused by cytokine release syndrome (CRS). This proposal aims to understand the mechanism of CRS regulation, identify risk for CRS and develop preventive treatment for CRS in allo-HCT therapy, which may save the lives of both the public and veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative (3 sentences) SSADHD is a rare inborn metabolic disorder characterized by broad spectrum encephalopathy including developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures and a risk of sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP). SSADH-targeted gene restoration therapy is a potential cure for this debilitating disorder, but a viable vector candidate capable of driving functionally sufficient SSADH in human neurons leading to demonstrable phenotypic curable outcome is currently unavailable. Our proposal aims to develop a novel adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector with human SSADH promoter driving functional human SSADH expressions in patient stem cell-derived neurons and determine whether systemic delivery of such clinically translatable AAV vector in SSADH-deficient mice results in safe and effective SSADH restoration with appreciable phenotypic rescue, advancing the preclinical development of SSADH gene therapy for SSADHD patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Traumatic brain injury triggers the activation of microglia and macrophages, as part of the innate immune response. This response is a first line defense against infection, but it also contributes to secondary brain injury. Recent findings indicate that microglial/macrophage activation can be suppressed by limiting glycolytic flux. Here we will evaluate targeted inhibition of microglial/macrophage glycolytic flux as an approach to improving outcome in a rodent model of traumatic brain injury. We will also evaluate the mechanism by which reduced glycolytic flux attenuates inflammatory responses in brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Prostate cancer is still one of the leading causes of cancer-related death in men including veterans in the US. Compared to the general population, prostate cancer disease in veterans tends to more often progress to the lethal forms after anti-hormone and anti-hormone receptor treatments, therefore severely affecting the life and health of our veterans. Therefore, there is still an urgent need for development of more effective therapeutics. We recently discovered a receptor protein as a new therapeutic target for the lethal form called neuroendocrine prostate (NEPC) which develops from the current treatments. Here, we propose to develop a new strategy by targeting the receptor with small-molecule inhibitors. To make it more effective, we propose to combine the receptor inhibitors with drugs targeting a different receptor target. With the promising results from preclinical models, our studies will likely lay a solid foundation for near-future development of a new and highly efficacious strategy in treatment of advanced prostate cancer for our veteran patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a debilitating condition of articular joints that is associated with pain, activity loss, and reduced quality of life. Incidence of PTOA and similar degenerative conditions is almost three times higher in the military vs civilian population by the age of 40. Intra-articular injections of cellular products, including bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC), are becoming standard of care for joint preservation and pain relief. Most of our data on the best use for BMAC rely on studies using allogenic cells from young, healthy donors to treat PTOA in young, otherwise healthy rodents rather than autologous sources The objective of this proposal is to evaluate how patient factors (age, sex, PTOA) and physical interventions impact BMAC efficacy in relieving osteoarthritic pain. Successful completion of this project will provide translatable evidence whether pre-habilitation of all or a subset of Veterans prior to BMAC harvest and injection can improve relief of joint pain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease are extremely common in Veterans and commonly complicated by pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. Treatment options for right heart failure are very limited. Heart failure has been the number one reason for admission among patients in the Veterans' Health Care System. Recent studies show that patients with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease, and PTSD is twice as prevalent in veteran populations versus the general population. The Department of Veteran Affairs Quality Enhancement Research Initiative (QUERI) is designed to improve care using research evidence to improve clinical practice for high-risk and/or highly prevalent diseases or conditions among veterans. Congestive heart failure is one of the high-risk, and highly prevalent diseases included in the QUERI program. Thus, research in cardiovascular disease, and RV failure in particular, are extremely important and relevant to the mission of the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and currently has few disease-modifying treatments or simple, accurate diagnostic tests available in the clinic. The goal of this project is to further develop and validate amyloid, tau, and neurodegenerative blood tests for amyloid plaques (a protein thought to begin AD) and tau tangles (protein deposits closely associated with cognitive impairment) in order to diagnose AD in the clinic to enable treatment with disease-modifying drugs, which could change the course of AD. Findings from this study may enable accurate diagnoses and access to more effective treatments of AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Myocarditis associated with COVID-19 infection, long COVID syndrome and COVID mRNA vaccination have emerged as urgent unmet clinical needs. Two recent studies involving >80-million persons including national healthcare databases from the US Department of Veteran Affairs confirmed that SARS-CoV-2 infection and/or mRNA vaccination significantly predispose patients from high susceptibility as cardiovascular disease to myocarditis, constituting an urgent unmet clinical need. We propose that genetic and/or pharmacological targeting of the cardiac low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR) can be used to prevent and possibly attenuate COVID-19-induced myocarditis in susceptible patients. Using a new mouse model of SARS-induced myocarditis and a co-culture model with monocytes from long COVID patients, we propose two independent mechanisms of action for how LDLR causes myocarditis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hazardous working conditions fuel socioeconomic and racial health disparities in the US; relational theories suggest such conditions are produced by upstream power imbalances between workers, managers, and employers, social classes divisible by managerial authority and business ownership. Nonetheless, while longitudinal studies have tested the effects of downstream factors like wages, none using relational theories have tested class’s cumulative effects on health over the life course, the modifying role of power dynamics, or the effects of workplace-level and state-level worker empowerment. My proposal will address these gaps, advancing the field by analyzing disparities’ overlooked root causes and identifying actionable policy solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence in schizophrenia spectrum disorders (SSD) support the idea that aberrant brain aging may also occur, but data on characteristic phenotypical and brain age-related signatures and their underlying mechanisms remain sparse. The principal goals, consistent with the purpose of the Funding Opportunity Announcement RFA-MH-22-270 and informed by mechanistic insights on aging in the field of geroscience, is to characterize aging phenomena in SSD across multiple units of analysis and to identify actionable targets that have the potential to ameliorate, or even prevent, aberrant aging in SSD. We will characterize age-related changes in the brain in SDD across multiple levels: brain structure (cortical thickness), brain function (nonsocial and social cognition) and metabolism (bioenergetics), which could offer mechanistic insights into aging process in SSD by focusing on multiple units of analysis and provide actionable treatment targets for aberrant aging in SSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of type 2 diabetes, with no effective therapy and unclear mechanisms. In this proposal, we aim to determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which lifestyle interventions, such as diet and exercise, can be implemented to improve peripheral neuropathy using a clinically relevant mouse model of type 2 diabetes along with advanced techniques to evaluate Schwann cell- axon metabolic cross talk and energy utilization. We will also define the role of extracellular vesicle release and small RNAs in mediating the beneficial effects of diet and/or exercise to advance our understanding of the metabolic interaction of neurons with Schwann cells beyond myelination, and ultimately unlock potential avenues of investigation for treating peripheral neuropathy in type 2 diabetes to improve the quality of life in affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Recent research proposed the use of biomarkers for a biological/etiological classification of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD). However, the current system is mainly focused on dementia of the Alzheimer’s type, but another important category of vascular cognitive impairment and dementia was not considered. The present project aims to develop and operationalize a biomarker based on brain physiology to classify vascular components in ADRD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The  Veterans  Health  Administration  provides  care  to  women  servicemembers  and  mild  traumatic  brain  injury  (mTBI)  is  a  known  risk  of  military  service. Young women servicemembers  smoke  at  an alarming  rate and  are  also likely to use oral contraceptives (OC), owing to their reproductive age. Simultaneous exposure to smoking  derived- nicotine (N) and OC (N+OC) renders females more susceptible to cognitive decline, a consequence of  mTBI.  The  current proposal uses  mTBI to  model the  physiological and cognitive  consequences,  mechanisms,  and possible treatments in the setting of N+OC exposure in female rats.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Prostate cancer (PC) is the number one cancer diagnosed in US Veterans. Almost half a million US Veterans currently undergo treatment for PC at the Veterans Health Administration. Advanced PC is treated by androgen deprivation therapy and most patients' initial response is favorable. Unfortunately, the cancer usually recurs as aggressive, incurable “castration-resistant prostate cancer” (CRPC) that often metastasizes and dramatically degrades quality of life. To combat or prevent CRPC, new therapies must be found. We identified a gene termed BUB1B (known to increase cell division) that is present at high levels in CRPC and in metastatic CRPC. Reducing BUB1B protein in genetic experiments halts the growth of CRPC cells. For clinical purposes, however, no BUB1B drugs exist. We will determine how BUB1B promotes CRPC growth, pinpoint BUB1B activity that is vulnerable to drugs, and deploy a computational and experimental approach to identify BUB1B drugs. We will validate drug effectiveness in pre-clinical CRPC models and set the stage for clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to devise clinically optimal MRI synthetic image contrasts for the skull base and face that can be tailored for field strength, gradient capabilities, spatial resolution, and desired imaging time. We propose to generate novel qualitative MRI contrasts that optimize clinically-relevant contrast-to-noise and simultaneously acquire relaxometry biomarkers that are co-registered to the anatomic images at the voxel level with markedly reduced scan times compared with current standard-of-care skull base and face MR imaging. We also propose to develop a novel pulse sequence that incorporates scanner gradient strength as a parameter to further decrease scan times and to evaluate these pulse sequences across 1.5T, 3T, and 7T field strengths.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are a group of synthetic chemicals that are resistant to biodegradation, environmentally persistent, and have been detected in nearly every participant of the nationally representative US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. Little is known about the reproductive health effects of “legacy” PFAS or newer PFAS alternatives, specifically the impact on the ovary. Women Veterans are the fastest growing subgroup in the Veteran population and projected to make up 18% of the Veteran population by the year 2040. According to data from the Department of Defense, there are over 400 military installations with known/suspected releases of PFAS, leaving veterans and their families more susceptible to PFAS exposure. The results of this project will provide novel insight on pathways and processes in the ovary that are impacted by exposure to PFAS and the potential consequences on female fertility in addition to impacts on offspring developmental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fifty million people have epilepsy, the incidence of epilepsy is higher after age 70 compared with any other time in life, and treatment decisions almost certainly change over the course of a person’s lifespan, yet current science poorly defines how optimal treatment strategies should change with age. This research will combine insights from a patient preferences survey with individualized seizure risk and net-benefit modeling and then plan a randomized trial, all to identify which patients with well-controlled epilepsy may benefit from deprescribing antiseizure medications. This project is directly relevant to NIA’s mission because optimizing deprescribing decisions according to a person’s age and stage in life intends to increase patients’ healthy, active years.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Atypical left atrial flutter seen after ablation for atrial fibrillation can be difficult to treat. Here we are going to develop a generalized computational model, which can be personalized with left atrial geometry, scar pattern, and mapping results. Such a model will enable virtual electrophysiology studies leading to the prediction of ablation points to terminate all possible such flutter pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This study seeks to develop new technologies to perform magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) safely and effectively in children implanted with a cardiac implantable electronic device (CIED). Specifically, this study will: (a) provide recommendations on how to perform MRI safely in these patients with existing CIEDs; (b) provide recommendations on how to configure future CIED implantations, in order to make MRI even safer; (c) deliver robust cardiac MRI methods that produce image quality in these patients that doctors can interpret with high confidence. Our study has high potential impact because it will extend MRI access to a growing number of pediatric patients with a CIED and establish an effective MRI for doctors to care for these patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Impaired skeletal fracture healing, including non-union fractures, osteoporotic fractures, and unhealed stress fractures developed during active military service, are prevalent in the VA patient population. They represent a significant health issue resulting in substantial healthcare costs and human suffering. A defective osteoclastic regulation of the coupled bone formation is a frequent cause for compromised fracture healing. This study investigates a novel mechanism by which soluble microvesicles (MV) released from osteoclasts mediate the coupled bone regeneration during fracture healing. If successful, this work provides significant new information about the etiology of impaired fracture healing. It may also lead to development of novel MV-based osteoanabolic therapies for fracture healing that would improve the quality of life of patients and reduce healthcare costs for managing unhealed fractures. Accordingly, this study is highly relevant to the VA patient care mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This NIEHS Short-Term Institutional Training Grant (5T35ES014559) application is to request annual support for 8 medical student trainees for a 10 week training experience for the next 5 years. The overarching scientific theme of research that links our faculty to this T35 Training Grant is the common interest of the faculty in research training of medical students in our laboratories in elucidating the health outcomes of exposure of normal and obese individuals to various environmental chemicals. In addition, we will use the T35 Training Grant to entice our medical students into our Distinction in Research Track, designed to allow students to pursue research interests throughout the years 2-4 of medical school curriculum with an eye toward building a pipeline of diverse translational clinician-researchers in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Talaromycosis (penicilliosis) is a life-threatening infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Talaromyces marneffei endemic in Southeast Asia and has a mortality of 30% in patients with advanced HIV disease. Delay in diagnosis is a major risk factor for death. The current culture-based diagnosis is not sensitive during the early stage of disease and takes up to 14 days. In this project, we will determine how a new antigen-detection test can be used in real-life clinical settings to accelerate the diagnosis and whether it can be used to screen for early disease. We aim to reduce mortality by making an earlier diagnosis thereby enabling early treatment and prevention of talaromycosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: 08 Project Narrative The coordinated firing of millions of neurons in the human brain gives rise to the diverse set of experiences, emotions, thoughts, and sensations that make up the human condition. Despite the central importance of neuronal physiology to human health and disease, our understanding of this complex field remains incomplete due to a lack of tools that can reliably report on membrane potential. This proposed research will develop and apply new optical tools to study neuronal membrane potential in cells and in circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Neurexins are key regulators of synapses that control properties as diverse as the release probability, postsynaptic receptor composition, and endocannabinoid signaling, and that are genetically linked to neuropsychiatric diseases such as schizophrenia, autism, and Tourette syndrome. Despite much effort, it is unclear what functions neurexins perform, how they perform these functions, and why mutations in neurexin genes predispose to neuropsychiatric disorders. The present application addresses these questions in a multi-disciplinary effort that combines mouse genetics with broad functional analyses of synapses, thereby providing insight into the role of neurexins in shaping synaptic circuits and into the mechanisms by which neurexins predispose to neuropsychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to investigate the presence of a disease-prone population of smooth muscle cells in normal blood vessels and the contribution this population(s) make to cardiovascular illness characterized by smooth muscle proliferation. We postulate that many of these diseases are caused by expansion of the disease-prone cell pool. Proof of this hypothesis will open new therapeutic possibilities for treating thoracic and abdominal aortic aneurysms and potentially heart attacks, stroke and peripheral vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of wildfires in the US. Wildfires could have important detrimental impacts on infant health through air pollution, psychosocial stress, and community disruption. In order to inform mitigation strategies, the proposed project will document the burden of wildfire exposure across the US and its impacts on infant health and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The magnitude and duration of viremia in vertebrate hosts influences arbovirus emergence, transmission, geographic spread, and disease severity. The innate immune mechanisms by which arboviruses are cleared from the circulation, and the mechanisms arboviruses employ to evade this clearance, are poorly understood. This project will define mechanistically how blood-borne arboviruses are cleared. The knowledge gained from these studies could facilitate improved control of arbovirus transmission and treatment of arboviral disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent literature has established that adults with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) suffer from a high risk of fractures, particularly at the hip. This proposal will define the skeletal mechanisms underlying this increased fracture risk with comprehensive assessments of hip bone structure, quality, and strength among older adults with T1D. Further identification of the glycemic factors that contribute to skeletal fragility will allow clinicians to develop rational approaches to prevent fractures in patients with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels in pancreatic β-cells couple glucose metabolism to insulin secretion; dysfunction of these channels underlies a number of human diseases including neonatal diabetes, congenital hyperinsulinism, DEND syndrome and type 2 diabetes. The goal of this project is to understand the structural mechanisms governing the formation and activity of KATP channels in health and disease in order to design better drugs to treat diseases caused by channel dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This grant proposal aims to commercialize a remote EEG monitoring platform that uses wearable EEG sensors worn on the scalp below the hairline. The platform is quickly deployable and meant to be used by emergency department and intensive care unit staff during neurological emergencies. The goal is to empower physicians in community and rural hospitals who do not have neurology or access to EEG to better treat their patients through remote monitoring by neurologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health, because it advances non-invasive, radiation-free imaging and proteomic biomarkers to diagnose and monitor lung disease. The work focuses pediatric cystic fibrosis, but it accelerates the use of these technologies to evaluate novel therapies in clinical trials and to measure outcomes in patients with a range of diseases, including asthma and COPD. Thus, the research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to applying knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is currently the leading cause of death worldwide due to the lack of effective therapies to replace the damaged cardiac tissue following injury. We identified that inhibition of succinate dehydrogenase by malonate can regenerate the adult heart following a myocardial infarction. This proposal aims to identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which succinate dehydrogenase inhibition promotes adult heart regeneration. Mechanisms elucidated in this proposal will advance the translational potential of targeting succinate dehydrogenase for treatment of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative COVID-19 continues to be a global health crisis. The efforts of developing therapeutics for COVID-19 are worldwide and unprecedented. Molnupiravir, nirmatrelvir and remdesivir are successful examples of such efforts. This project will provide important information on whether these drugs can be used together for therapeutic synergy and if nanoformulation shows organ-targeted superiority such as for the lung, the major organ affected by COVID-19 in terms of severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis patients hospitalized for acute flares represent one of the highest risk and cost populations cared for in the United States, yet the treatment algorithm for these patients has remained unchanged for over a decade due to their exclusion from traditional drug development programs. We have previously demonstrated that the use of hyperbaric oxygen therapy in these patients improves disease activity, optimizes response to intravenous steroids early in the hospitalization, and prevents progression to biologics or colectomy. In the current proposal we aim to expand on our prior work by confirming the efficacy of hyperbaric oxygen therapy in this patient population through a large pivotal clinical trial, while also expanding our understanding of disease pathogenesis through tissue-based transcriptomics of neutrophils, epithelial cells, and the microbiome of participants enrolled in this clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to integrate the anatomy as well as the physiology of coronary atherosclerosis to improve identification of stable individuals who will subsequently experience heart attack in the future. Extensive clinical data will be leveraged to perform anatomic and physiologic measurements on these images, and integrated models that combine both of these types of measurements will be constructed to determine a patient’s risk of heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Neuromodulatory nuclei are small groups of neurons that change brain network function and are centrally important to motivation, adaptation, and treatments for many mental disorders. This project uses advanced statistical modeling to relate activity in nuclei that release dopamine and other neuromodulators to widespread brain networks and activity patterns. The knowledge we expect to gain offers better understanding of brain function and self-regulation, and promises many new tools for optimizing human cognition and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Development of vaccines and other immunotherapies to direct cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL)-mediated elimination of cancers will impact global health significantly. This proposal establishes an integrative service for end users to identify those CTL targets with precision in order to harness a focused and personalized immune offensive against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This research program explores molecular approaches for the study and regulation of aberrant metalloenzyme activity in human disease, focusing on the structural and chemical biology of histone deacetylase (HDAC) isozymes 6, 8, 10, and 11. HDAC6 and HDAC10 are lysine deacetylases that serve as drug targets for cancer and neurological disorders, and HDAC8 and HDAC11 are lysine-fatty acid deacylases that serve as drug targets for cancer and immune modulation. Detailed structure-function studies of these isozymes will illuminate new avenues for the design of inhibitors with improved potency and selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite a high prevalence of mental health problems among refugee adults in high-income countries, there is evidence of underutilization of available mental health services. This study will leverage a mixed methods approach to explore barriers and facilitators to the utilization of mental health services over time among refugee adults in Sweden, with an emphasis on the Syrian population. Findings from this study will inform the optimization of mental health service availability for refugees and asylum-seekers in high-income countries, with implications for the integration of these populations into national health systems and host societies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Low back pain is the leading cause of disability globally and is closely associated with degeneration of the intervertebral discs. Recent discoveries have demonstrated the importance of the cartilage endplate in regulating disc health. The proposed work will facilitate the development of non-invasive MRI-based biomarkers measuring endplate composition, which in turn will enable fundamental insight into the etiology of disc degeneration and guide therapeutic treatments for low back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) is one of the most common chronic diseases in the United States and is characterized by multi-organ insulin resistance and dysregulated glucose homeostasis. This project will employ novel methodologies to mechanistically understand renal insulin resistance, its pathophysiology, and the role of the kidney in perturbed whole-body glucose homeostasis in diabetes. This proposal is relevant to public health because it has the potential to inform the development of novel therapies for T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will clarify the mechanisms of memory encoding and storage in typical and atypical AD at the stage of mild cognitive impairment (MCI), as well as elucidate the specific roles of amyloid, tau, and atrophy as potential drivers of memory impairment both cross-sectionally and longitudinally. We will expand our knowledge of the mechanisms of memory impairment across the AD spectrum, with a special focus on the underserved atypical presentations of this disease, as well as clarify the mechanistic roles of and atrophy and clinical factors such as age at symptom onset to improve clinical prognostication and outcomes monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Low dose computed tomography (LDCT) is a procedure recommended as a screening test for adults who have a high risk for lung cancer that has been shown to reduce lung cancer mortality. Sexual and gender minority (SGM) populations may be at higher risk for lung cancer mortality due to a higher risk of cigarette smoking. Understanding rates of LDCT screening eligibility for SGM individuals, SGM-related LDCT screening disparities, and modifiable factors for such disparities can inform efforts to reduce morbidity and mortality caused by cigarette smoking, such as lung cancer and other lung-related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies are relevant to public health because they have the potential to identify women at high risk of breast cancer using ethnic-specific models. Thus, this advance is expected to have a high impact to the health and well being of women because women at high risk may choose to alter the breast cancer screening frequency for earlier detection or to participate in risk reduction strategies, such as lifestyle modification. Both approaches will reduce breast cancer mortality. This is relevant to the part of NIH's mission which focuses on the prevention of disease by supporting research in the prevention and early detection of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to reduce health disparities among Latinos and Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders (NHPI), especially considering new health behavior patterns, social norms, and increased technology use related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Through Community-based Participatory Research (CBPR), we will partner with Latino and NHPI communities to co-design and develop new technology, an mHealth application for smartphones, to improve the health concerns identified by the communities (e.g., obesity-related health behaviors and mental health). This project also focuses on training students from underrepresented in biomedical research in all phases of the research and innovation development, with an emphasis on training future, independent health disparities researchers and scholars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our data suggest that acute signal or ligand-dependent activation of target enhancers causes them to form an RNA-protein condensate, with features of phase separation, resulting in in induced proximity and cooperative activation of other homotypic enhancers, although separated by multiple TADs and, potentially, even in other chromosomes. In contrast, chronic signal/ligand activation results in loss of the dynamic RNP condensate at the enhancers, loss of induced proximity of homotypic enhancers observed with acute activation, with enhancer activation function now confined to the nearby cognate target gene promoters. We will use global genomic, proteomic, and real time, single nucleus approaches with the goal of providing a paradigm-shifting insight into hormone-regulated transcriptional programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is an increasingly prevalent cardiac arrhythmia in the United States and a leading cause of stroke. Current treatments for atrial fibrillation are often ineffective and could have significant side effects. In this study, we will conduct a comprehensive and integrated study to unveil the distinguishing fingerprints of atrial fibrillation substrates in order to develop new personalized therapies that successfully define, target, and treat the sources of atrial fibrillation in the human heart.
