IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current treatments for depression and anxiety are limited by modest efficacy and significant side effects, and these disorders are a serious threat to public health and burden of illness and contribute to increasing rates of suicide. This application proposes the critical first-in-human research to develop a new kind of intervention, called low intensity focused ultrasound, for people suffering from depression and anxiety. Using acoustic energy, this study will serve to characterize brain targets to engage and provide unique insights into the future best practices for rationally designed clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis begins when low density lipoproteins (LDL) enter the vessel wall and are retained. Our data show high density lipoproteins (HDL) can inhibit LDL entry and retention. As such, this study aims to define how the balance between LDL and HDL influence plaque buildup in the artery wall and how it is altered in type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress has a central role in mental health conditions and improved understanding of how stress affects brain and body could deliver great potential clinical impact. To determine the brain and body responses to varying stressors we will use novel instrumentation to measure 50+ behavioral metrics at sub-second resolution together with multi-brain site electrophysiology over weeks. We will then determine how varying stressors affect circadian and broader changes across animal behavior and physiology as well as neural circuit dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research described in this proposal aims to investigate the rejuvenating and therapeutic effects of circulating platelet factors on the aged brain. These studies will have significant translational potential, identifying circulating platelet-derived factors as candidate therapeutic targets to restore age-related cognitive dysfunction and potentially treat dementia-related neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Microglial inflammation has been implicated in the pathology of numerous neurodegenerative diseases, neurodevelopmental disorders, and other neurological conditions, and suppressing the activation of innate immune signaling pathways in these cells could thus represent a broad therapeutic approach. To enhance the efficacy and safety of such an approach, the intervention should be both long-term and targeted to microglia, such that a gene therapy based on an adeno- associated viral (AAV) vector would be promising. Since natural AAVs exhibit inefficient, non-targeted delivery to human microglia, however, we propose to integrate directed evolution of AAV with molecular barcoding, single cell next generation sequencing (NGS), machine learning, and human tissue and non-human primate (NHP) brain models to develop AAVs for selective gene delivery of potential therapeutic cargoes to primate microglia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in motivation are disabling features of numerous neuropsychiatric disorders including Parkinson’s disease, but a lack of understanding of dysfunction in human reward circuits prevents the development of effective treatments for these conditions. The goal of this project is to use novel sensing-enabled deep brain stimulation devices and computational reward learning models to identify the neural circuits underlying healthy and unhealthy goal-directed decision-making, as well as to test their causal role in behavior via closed-loop neurostimulation. Delineating the neural mechanisms of goal-directed decision-making in humans will uncover fundamental neurobiology of reward processing and provide biomarkers that can optimize the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of motivation dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease and other neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aging brain is vulnerable due to many changes including mitochondrial dysfunction, increased inflammation, insulin resistance and decreased neurotransmitter release leading to poor sleep quality and more complications with general anesthesia. This project aims to develop metabolic interventions (increasing ketones) to alleviate the metabolic-immune dysregulation that occurs in the aging brain to improve sleep and general anesthesia safety in the elderly and eventually to treat neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal deposits or inclusions of the essential human protein TDP-43 are a key feature in many patients suffering from Alzheimer’s disease related dementias including frontotemporal dementia and limbic-predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy, and the motor neuron disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Importantly, small chemical changes in TDP-43, including those caused by TDP-43 gene mutations and intracellular modifications, are associated with disease. Therefore, visualizing the structural details of the TDP-43 along its lifecycle with atom-by-atom chemical resolution is an important step to finding new treatments for incurable neurodegenerative diseases of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic orofacial muscle pain arising from the muscles of mastication (chewing) is a top cause of disability that affects necessary daily activities such as biting, chewing, swallowing, and speaking but also common social activities many people may take for granted such as smiling, laughing, and kissing. Treatment options are currently limited, often inadequate, and can result in substance abuse disorders. The results from my proposed work will elucidate mechanisms underlying the development of muscle pain and positively contribute to strategies for treating this common and debilitating chronic orofacial muscle pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular motors dynein and kinesin move membrane-bound vesicles, organelles, and mRNA on microtubules, a process required for cell polarity and function and axonal transport. Defects in trafficking contribute to developmental and neurodegenerative diseases, and we will investigate molecular mechanisms that regulate cargo motion using an in vitro reconstitution approach. Cytokinesis, the fundamental process by which a cell divides into two daughters following mitosis, is key to transmitting genetic material between generations, and its failure can induce changes in ploidy resulting in oncogenesis or cell death. We will characterize the biophysical properties of the myosin motors that drive this process in fission yeast, a widely used model system that has provided the most advanced models of the cytokinetic contractile ring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance The treatment of psychiatric diseases, including highly intractable clinical conditions such as depression, has been held back by a limited understanding of the underlying principles of healthy brain circuit function. This proposal focuses on the mechanisms and function of neural circuits in the medial entorhinal cortex, a brain region that contains neural circuits highly associated with navigation and memory that can go awry in a range of mood and neural disorders. Understanding how normal medial entorhinal circuits support behavior could lead to new, more precise treatments that reduce the memory-related symptoms of brain disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cases of pre-diabetes and type 2 diabetes (T2D) in children and adolescents have been rising at alarming rates, which is concerning in light of data showing that T2D in youth is more severe and more likely to cause complications than T2D diagnosed in adulthood. Currently it is difficult to predict whether a child with pre- diabetes will go on to develop T2D. Our proposal aims to discover predictive biomarkers to identify youth at highest risk of progressing from prediabetes to T2D, which ultimately will allow for earlier detection and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent immunological and physiological studies have provided evidence in support of a central nervous system (CNS) lymphatic drainage system in vertebrate animals, and preliminary evidence has suggested that a similar system exists in humans. If operative, this system may have central relevance to many vascular and fluid clearance disorders such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease related dementia (ADRD): diseases which represent some of the most pressing healthcare challenges of the 21st century. Evaluating this possibility will require improved, robust imaging methods sensitive to lymphatic drainage dysfunction; as such, the goal of this work is to apply novel magnetic resonance imaging approaches, optimized already for evaluating lymphatic circulation in patients with peripheral lymphatic dysfunction, to quantify relationships between physiological hallmarks of ADRD and CNS lymphatic function in humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive disabilities, such as those observed in developmental disorders like Autism, are often marked by improper synaptic connections between neurons. Although there are clear links between abnormal synaptic development and behavioral deficits persisting into adulthood, the specific cellular and molecular mechanisms that underly these deficits are not well understood. Disbalances of the neuromodulator serotonin have been associated with improper circuit formation in the brain and an increased likelihood of developing cognitive disabilities; characterizing the role of serotonin in proper synaptic development will help further our understanding of the cellular and molecular etiologies of developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This SEPA program will prepare pre-service, early career, and in-service teachers to provide large numbers of students, particularly disadvantaged and underrepresented students, with authentic research experiences linking biological concepts with societally relevant problems of environmental health/chemical toxicity. To become adept at doing and analyzing experiments, students will develop a solid comprehension of the elements of the scientific method and an introductory facility with computational analysis of large data sets. Conducting research within a framework of understanding the history of environmental chemicals and their implications for environmental justice, students will gain insight into relationships between science and society and, in the process, be stimulated to enter biomedical STEM fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Sedentary behavior serves as the greatest modifiable risk factor causing cognitive decline in both normal aging individuals and those with Alzheimer's Disease in the United States. This proposal will investigate the hypothesis that specific patterns of exercise engage a molecular feedback loop that integrates rate-limiting aspects of acetyl-CoA metabolic pathways and histone acetylation/methylation mechanisms to modulate gene expression required for long-term memory formation and synaptic plasticity. Furthermore, we identify a pharmacological approach that ameliorates deficits in acetyl-CoA mechanisms in the aging brain, improves synaptic plasticity and memory, and may provide novel insight into therapeutic design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This study will use a community-engaged approach to identify an effective, culturally relevant, and sustainable strategy for identifying high-risk Black families from an underserved population, facilitating genetic testing, and expanding opportunities for personalized cancer treatment, prevention, and screening. This approach may be of particular benefit to hundreds of thousands Black patients and their relatives because they are often unaware of their risks, less likely to have a provider discuss their risk and refer them for GT at the time of diagnosis and are not equably garnering the potentially lifesaving benefits of personalized care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein is an abundant RNA binding protein that plays a variety of roles in the viral life cycle, notably in the packaging of genomic RNA during virion assembly. Despite the critical role N protein plays in genome packaging, the molecular details that underlie this process are poorly understood. Here we combine single-molecule fluorescence and force spectroscopy with ensemble biophysical experiments and simulations to uncover the molecular details that underlie how N protein mediates genome condensation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This work aims to better understand the pediatric cancer Ewing sarcoma, specifically investigating the immunobiology in the setting of tumor DNA damage. The studies will be performed by examining the cancer cells themselves as well as by examining the immune cells in proximity to the tumor that can influence growth and spread of the cancer. This career development grant will provide the applicant with training in tumor immunology and bioinformatic analyses, an area of growing importance in pediatric oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Menopause is accompanied by extensive hormonal and physiological changes that can negatively affect women’s health and increase women’s risk of cardiovascular disease, though the molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. Here we propose to identify gene expression differences between premenopausal and postmenopausal women’s tissues, enabling detection of molecular pathways impacted by menopause. These findings could provide candidate mechanisms for the increased disease burden experienced by women post- menopause and could inform the future development of improved therapeutics for cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE. The major limitations in identifying new drugs for salivary gland cancer is that these cancers lack genetic events that can be inhibited conventionally because the gene fusions give rise to abnormal proteins, and there are few reliable models derived from patients. We have discovered a drug (SVC112) that inhibits production of such proteins vital to cancer cells, and we generated human models of this disease, which can actually mimic what happens in a patient more closely, and will make the testing of SVC112 more robust. Our goal is to determine if modulating protein synthesis with SVC112 constitutes a novel therapy for salivary gland cancers, a disease orphan of options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need for new ways to treat small cell lung cancer (SCLC). SCLC is an aggressive cancer and survival with current therapies is low. While almost all small cell lung cancers have the same known particular gene mutations, so far it has not been possible to develop therapeutic agents to target these gene mutations. We have identified a key vulnerability in SCLC in that SCLC cannot develop in mice when a particular protein is inactivated. Further, we identified an inhibitor of that protein that effectively killed human and mouse SCLC cells. When successfully completed, our studies could lead to clinical trials for the treatment of most SCLC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Novel, liquid metal RF coil technology will be developed to enable the design of a conformal and flexible neck-brachial plexus coil array to deliver 3X-higher SNR. We hypothesize that the achievable spatial resolution will be ~0.5 mm isotropic, greater than the ~1 mm isotropic currently afforded by commercial coils. This will enable superior 3D resolution in brachial plexus magnetic resonance neurography, which will improve diagnosis and impact non-operative and operative management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: In spite of advances due to anti-retroviral therapy and other treatments HIV infection and AIDS-associated Kaposi’ sarcoma continues to be a global health problem affecting many HIV at-risk populations. It is caused by human cancer causing-virus the Kaposi’s sarcoma herpesvirus and interactions with the HIV virus and AIDS. Having proper cellular and mouse tumor models is essential to deeply understand the mechanisms of this dual viral disease. The current application will develop several of these models that will aid our understanding of this viral disease and help design and test therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed basic research is relevant to public health because it focuses on a fundamental cell process that is critical to development and wound healing and contributes to cancer metastasis. The work will lay the foundation for the development of new strategies to prevent and treat cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Amblyopia is a prevalent form of visual disability that arises during early childhood and is challenging to treat in adulthood. This proposal seeks to test the specific mechanistic hypothesis that burst-mode firing is responsible for retinal inactivation induced recovery from amblyopic rearing in animal models. Understanding plasticity mechanisms capable of promoting visual acuity gains has the potential to stimulate the development of new treatments for amblyopia and other visual disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Major Depressive Disorder in adolescence often follows a chronic or recurrent course and is associated with significant psychosocial impairment, health problems, school failure, and suicidality; many youth remain substantially symptomatic despite receiving current first-line treatments, underscoring the need for novel, modifiable targets to improve depression treatment outcomes. The overall aim of this proposal is a confirmatory efficacy trial sufficiently powered and designed to test the hypothesis that improving the relationship between biological circadian timing and waketime, a novel modifiable target, improves depression outcomes in a subgroup of adolescents with depression and a misaligned relationship between biological circadian timing and waketime utilizing a cognitive-behavioral sleep intervention. If successful this study will provide a low stigma, safe, data driven precision medicine approach, for improving depression for adolescents with MDD and a misaligned relationship between biological circadian timing and waketime.

PHR: Treatments of malignant gliomas, including glioblastoma multiforme which are the most lethal, fail because cancer cells invade and proliferate beyond tumor boundaries. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemorrhage from intraabdominal injury after blunt trauma is a leading cause of death in children in the United States. To identify injury without exposing children to unnecessary ionizing radiation from computed tomography scans requires accurate and reliable diagnostic strategies. The proposed use of machine learning for bedside abdominal ultrasound is an innovative diagnostic tool to enhance the evaluation of injured children and is highly relevant to the mission of The Pediatric Trauma and Critical Illness Branch of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development to support research and training to improve diagnosis of traumatic injury in infants, children, adolescents, and young adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multipurpose prevention technologies (MPTs) that include contraceptive and anti-HIV components have the potential to drive product use and are urgently needed, especially in the developing world. We will use state-of- the-art biology, chemistry, biomedicine, and pharmacology research to develop a novel antibody against sperm and formulate this agent into an intravaginal ring for extended delivery, along with drugs effective against HIV. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to rigorous development of a much- needed dual-action MPT in preparation for future clinical trials.

PHR: Project Narrative The study proposed here addresses the urgent need to understand the mechanisms of new therapies for type 1 diabetes (T1D), a disease which affects over 1.25 million Americans and has no cure. This project will demonstrate how low-dose IL-2, a promising new T1D immunotherapy, impacts beta cell function beyond increasing survival. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pre-mRNA splicing is an essential component of gene expression for eukaryotic organisms. An ever-increasing number of human diseases are associated with mutations in this pathway, yet the mechanisms by which the spliceosome, which catalyzes pre-mRNA splicing, enacts this regulation is a complex problem whose solution remains poorly understood. By leveraging novel tools developed in our lab that enable detection of rare reaction intermediates, we are determining the basic mechanisms by which the spliceosome distinguishes between its many substrates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRAS mutations are found in approximately one fourth of lung cancers, a disease that kills approximately 160,000 people annually in the U.S. The treatment of patients with this molecular subtype of lung cancer remains one the biggest challenges faced by medical oncologists. This proposal will study how patients and patient-derived models respond to emerging inhibitors that directly inactivate mutant KRAS in order to develop effective treatments that prolong survival and improve the quality of life in patients with lung cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The central control of reproductive function has focused mainly on the hypothalamic neurons that control GnRH release, however, the amygdala, located outside of the hypothalamus has been documented to participate in the control of reproduction through yet unknown mechanisms. Our preliminary data suggests that Kiss1 neurons in this brain region play a critical role in reproduction. We will test this hypothesis through a series of genetic, optogenetic and pharmacological studies aimed to target these neurons in both sexes to determine their role in gonadotropin release and sexual behavior.

PHR: Project Narrative It is important to monitor factors that contribute to the health of mothers and their infants. The proposed research project, Florida Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS), seeks to collect valuable information about specific maternal and child health (MCH) issues that can only be achieved through the collection and utilization of population-based MCH data. Objectives include collecting PRAMS data to assess factors that contribute to infant mortality, improve prenatal care for expecting mothers, and strengthen programs to improve the health of women and children within Florida.

ORG_NAME: MICHIGAN STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
PHR: MI PRAMS COMPONENT A - PROJECT NARRATIVE The Michigan Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (MI PRAMS) is an annual survey of the health of mothers and babies within the State of Michigan. The survey is sent out to a portion of women randomly selected from all Michigan residents who have a live birth in the state during a given year and is vital for knowing how common are the factors that can have positive or negative effects on a pregnancy. The end result of MI PRAMS is a collection of annual estimates that represent the health of all mothers and babies in the State; these estimates are useful for planning government spending and tracking the success of programs that improve maternal and child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: The American Heart Association estimates that 2.5% of the United States population suffers from valvular heart disease, requiring over 100,000 heart valve replacement procedures annually. Replacement of the diseased valve dramatically improves short-term quality and quantity of life, however, even the best performing replacement valves used currently (i.e., biological tissue valves) are far from ideal, as they promote chronic immune-mediated degeneration, resulting in calcification and long-term valve failure (~10-15 years). The current proposal aims to fulfill recent NHLBI cardiac surgery working group recommendations; by identifying and eliminating biological tissue components which promote immune-mediated destruction, while simultaneously enhancing components which promote pro-regenerative immune responses, to provide the next generation of tissue engineered heart valve biomaterials which retain the benefits of current heart valve replacements, while overcoming their negative long term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: R01: Investigating the impact of a fatty acid–cRel inflammatory circuit in atherosclerosis RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Perturbed lipid homeostasis is associated with pathogenic inflammation in a number of metabolic diseases, including atherosclerosis, obesity, and diabetes. In this study, we will elucidate the mechanisms underlying the link between altered lipid metabolism and aberrant inflammatory responses. Our findings may lead to the identification of therapeutic targets in cardiovascular diseases and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective use of hormonal contraception is frequently limited by behavioral side effects, such as changes in mood and decreases in sexual desire. These side effects may be attributable to the ways hormonal contraception impacts brain functions related to motivation and pleasure, known as “reward function.” This project will use a placebo-controlled design to evaluate the effects of hormonal contraception on reward function, with the goal of creating a protocol that will enhance personalization of contraceptive treatment, allowing clinicians and patients to better choose agents with the least propensity for behavioral side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Among fall related injuries in older adults, head injuries are the most common, yet almost nothing is known about recovery from head injury, also known as traumatic brain injury or TBI, in this population. The objective of the proposed research is to conduct a prospective cohort study of 250 adults aged 65 and older with mild TBI to evaluate recovery in cognitive, physical and psychological function and sleep quality at four timepoints over the year following injury and identify factors associated with recovery trajectories. The potential impact of this work is that it will generate new knowledge to guide targeted treatment efforts and inform future development of strategies to optimize recovery following this common fall-related injury among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Loss of spatial memories may be one of the most distressing symptoms of neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease and psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia. Patients with Alzheimer’s disease may struggle to remember landmarks or form cognitive maps of their environment; patients with schizophrenia may struggle with sensory integration, leading to perceptual disturbances and impairments in spatial working memory. This project will characterize cellular- and circuit-level mechanisms of spatial integration, which will lead to a better understanding of how these processes malfunction in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall purpose of this national training program is to prepare doctoral nurses, including those with a Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) and/or a Philosophy Doctorate (PhD), to translate and integrate genetic and genomic content into doctoral nursing academic curricula, scholarship and practice. The foundations for this medical genomics educational training program include: Genomic Nursing Competency Implementation Strategic Plan 2014-20203, the Genomic Essential Genetic and Genomic Competencies for Nurses with Graduate Degrees4, and the Essentials of DNP Education5. The primary aims will be achieved through a half- day genomics course offered at an annual national doctoral nursing conference each January, followed by monthly webinars/web conferences through the remainder of the year to sustain interest, engage learners, and create a community of learners to become genomic nursing doctoral champions for their nursing school.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as it investigates a potential therapy for treating disrupted control of organ and muscle blood flow following traumatic spinal cord injury. Without control of these functions, patients with spinal cord injury live with a number of number of deficits, including an inability to appropriately redistribute blood, muscle fatigue, and exercise intolerance. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the NIH’s mission, as it seeks to discover a new therapy via research that is highly relevant for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obstructed defecation (OD), defined as incomplete emptying of stool, is a widely prevalent disorder in women’s health, occurring in roughly 25% of constipated women and resulting in major quality of life (QOL) and healthcare burdens. Our group has developed a cheap, bedside diagnostic approach for OD that better identifies patients that need surgery, and a minimally invasive, mesh-free surgical approach to treat those patients that causes less morbidity, and improves outcomes based on our small preliminary studies. The goal of this proposal is to do a more extensive clinical trial to demonstrate the effectiveness of these approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 7 million people in the U.S. and Europe have atrial fibrillation. MRI offers methods to give information about the left atrium that help with clinical management decisions. This proposal offers new methods using MRI to better assess the heart and to determine if these measurements are more reproducible for an individual than previous MRI methods.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) impacts 1.2 million hospitalized patients in the US annually and affects males more severely than females. Our proposed studies will determine the sex-dependent mechanisms for AKI and its recovery. Knowledge of these mechanisms will allow the development of new therapies to improve the recovery of kidney functions after AKI for both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The pathological process of Alzheimer's disease (AD) in the brain starts years before symptom onset thus studying at risk population such as people with diabetes mellitus and obesity and following them over longer time will help understand the development AD. The renin angiotensin system has range of biological functions, such as blood pressure regulation, and there is growing evidence about its likely involvement in the AD process, however the exact mechanism is unclear. In this proposal we will measure RAS proteins from blood in people with history of diabetes mellitus and obesity, which increases their risk for AD, who are cognitively normal at time of blood draw and evaluate whether MRI brain images and cognitive measures obtained 9-14 years after blood draw are altered by these RAS proteins.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A thorough understanding of the gene regulatory network (GRN) functioning in early mammalian embryos will aid in the diagnosis and treatment of human developmental disorders, along with facilitating more effective strategies for regenerative medicine. Until recently, tools for comprehensive characterization of the early embryonic GRN were unavailable. We will combine powerful cell-based methods with new in vivo approaches to fill this void, providing insight into the first cell fate decision during embryogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cervical cancers are a leading cause of death among women worldwide. Treatment by implantation of radioactivity into the tumor with MR-guidance (MR- brachytherapy) has significantly improved survival. We accelerate MR- bracytherapy with better tumor detection and real-time dose optimization during implantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Progressive chronic kidney disease (CKD), associated with intravascular hemolysis, is a steady predictor of morbidity and early mortality in sickle cell disease (SCD). This project seeks to determine that circulating heme, the hemolytic byproduct, downregulates endothelial protein C receptor (EPCR) through induction of endothelial P-selectin and neutrophilic proteinase 3 (PR3) resulting in renal microvascular endothelial damage and CKD development. The project will assess whether specific genetic variants and soluble form of EPCR are associated with the risk of CKD, and identify specific intermediate therapeutic targets to impede CKD pathogenesis in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work aims to elucidate the complex relationships between early life cardiovascular disease risk factors, epigenetic age acceleration, and midlife brain health. Knowledge gained from this study may contribute important insights into the biological pathways linking heart and brain health and provide novel strategies for the targeted prevention of epigenetic age acceleration and its brain health sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative - Public Health Relevance  Cochlear synaptopathy is the permanent damage to nerve fibers connecting the sensory cells of the inner ear to the brain, which occurs in noise-induced and age-related hearing loss well before changes in the threshold audiogram. This nerve damage is likely a major contributor to difficulties understanding speech in a noisy environment that characterize many types of sensorineural hearing impairment and may also be a key elicitor of tinnitus and hyperacusis. The research proposed here will directly address the mechanisms by which this pathology arises, how the signal-carrying capacity of the auditory nerve is compromised in this condition, and how the condition can be diagnosed non-invasively. The proposed research will also extend our work on the development of therapies for this type of neural damage. The ultimate success of these therapies holds promise to improve the hearing abilities of millions of people with sensorineural hearing loss and to eliminate the suffering produced by hyperacusis and tinnitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All of the brain’s functions, even basic functions like processing sensory information, are powerfully shaped by experience-driven synaptic plasticity and learning. Experience-dependent changes in the timing rules governing synaptic plasticity could support improvements in the temporal accuracy of learning, whereas improper tuning of the timing rules for plasticity could corrupt the learning process and contribute to an array of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury leads to acute loss of kidney function that may progress to the point of needing dialysis treatment (the artificial kidney) and may also lead to chronic kidney disease and endstage kidney disease. Older age is a major risk factor for acute kidney injury and there is evidence that a certain type of aged cells (senescent cells) can cause kidney disease. This grant application will test the involvement of these cells in acute kidney injury and determine whether a new therapy (called senolytics) that destroys these cells will protect against acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Depression remains among the most refractory psychiatric comorbidities in people living with human immunodeficiency virus despite the universal use and success of combination antiretroviral therapy. Nonetheless, lack of pathophysiological mechanisms underlying this comorbidity hampers advances in its prevention and treatment. In this study, we aim to identify aberrant gut bacterial-fungal interactions-mediated inflammatory mechanisms underlying HIV-induced depressive-like behaviors in EcoHIV mouse model, and also explore the novel mechanisms whereby pachyman may normalize HIV infection-induced gut microbiota dysbiosis, inhibit sustained inflammation, and provide antidepressant effect via inhibition of dectin-1 signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Veterans have a high rate of suicide, but prevention efforts have focused mostly on veterans who use Veteran Health Administration (VHA) healthcare. This work lays a foundation for healthcare-based suicide prevention among an understudied group at very high risk of suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: 8 – Project Narrative Driven by changes in the microbial community that colonizes the gingiva next to the tooth, periodontitis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by the destruction of the connection between the teeth and the bone that supports them. We have been studying an antimicrobial protein produced by gingival epithelial cells and neutrophils, and have shown that this protein, named calprotectin, causes suppression of the early inflammatory response around teeth when the disease begins. We now seek to understand why.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Angiogenesis is an important biological process essential for tissue repair following injury or disease. In this project we will use a tissue-engineered model of brain microvessels to establish the role of pericytes during angiogenesis. Elucidating the mechanisms of angiogenesis in the brain will enable the development of new therapies for cerebrovascular repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Homology-directed DNA repair (HDR) removes deleterious DNA lesions that are the result of exposure to environmental and chemotherapeutic agents, and defects therein lead to genomic instability, cancer, and other diseases. We will delineate the novel mechanisms by which the opposing actions of HDR factors and regulators help determine the timing and overall efficiency of HDR. Our findings will provide actionable information to identify predictive biomarkers of cancer drug response, and to help guide the development of targeted therapies to treat HDR-deficient cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to leverage the large quantity of diffusion MRI datasets from shared ASD databases, such as the National Database for Autism Research (NDAR) and Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange (ABIDE), as well as from normative databases (e.g., the Human Connectome Project and Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development study), to 1) create a curated resource of diffusion MRI datasets in ASD and typically developing individuals, and 2) study cross-sectional lifespan trajectories of white matter tracts in ASD, at the group and individual levels (relative to typical development). Insight gained from this project may inform policy and treatment development for lifelong support of ASD. The dMRI data resource will also help promote reproducible diffusion MRI research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Neonicotinoids are commonly used pesticides and humans are exposed to them daily through food, water, and soil. The proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which prenatal and adult exposure to a neonicotinoid can causes deficits in learning and memory systems in mammals. Identifying how neonicotinoids can act on memory centers in the brain is relevant to public health since it will enable us to improve strategies for prevention or reduction of risks following exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) are blood-forming stem cells that support life-long blood production and can restore all blood lineages when transplanted into patients suffering from hematologic disease. Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is an inherited blood disorder that effects thousands of patients in the United States and damages HSCs, although this has yet to be deeply explored. To illuminate opportunities to restore function to HSCs in individuals with SCD, here we will investigate their function and molecular programs in both mouse models and patients with SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States there are approximately 10-15 million carriers of gene mutations that cause cystic fibrosis (CF), an autosomal recessive disease. Although having one defective copy of this gene was not thought to be related to poor health outcomes, CF carriers in small studies, and in our own preliminary work, appear to be at higher risk for respiratory infections. We propose to determine the risk for respiratory infections attributable to the CF carrier state and to investigate the potential future feasibility of preventing or treating respiratory infections in CF carriers using currently existing medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with congenital vestibular disorders (CVDs) experience delayed motor development and challenges in maintaining posture and balance that never achieve normal adult levels. The proposed experiments involve surgical manipulation of the developing chick inner ear to generate a highly reproducible, sac-like inner ear that resembles the most common malformation found in children with CVDs, followed by experiments to determine how the sac-like inner ear pathology alters connectivity in the peripheral and central vestibular system. The goal of this research is to provide basic science understanding of the mechanisms underlying CVDs that can support devising new approaches to treat causes rather than the symptoms of CVDs and improve the quality of life for CVD children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) mediates the toxicity of dioxin-like environmental contaminants and has been implicated in the etiology and progression of inflammatory diseases and cancer, but a comprehensive, mechanistic understanding of how chemicals cause toxicity via the AHR has been hindered by the complexity of its physiological functions and the diversity of its ligands (AHR promiscuity). The proposed research will reveal the properties of the primordial ligand-activated AHR and the molecular mechanisms underlying the evolution of promiscuity. This basic research will provide fundamental new insights into the natural physiological ligands and biological functions of the AHR, reveal the genetic and structural mechanisms underlying AHR ligand recognition, and elucidate how and why AHR function is disrupted by exposure to anthropogenic environmental contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The complexity human facial development means that it is vulnerable to environmental and genetic perturbations, such that craniofacial malformations are one of the most common classes of birth defects, occurring in ~1.5 in 1000 newborns. The presence of an orofacial cleft requires multiple operations to correct the defect and this frequently reduces the quality of life for both the child and the parents and imposes a significant psychological and economic burden on families. Here, we are using mutant mouse models that mimic a genetic cause of human orofacial clefting to test if in utero treatments can prevent such clefts from occurring during fetal development and so alleviate the need for later post-natal treatment and surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To advance prediction and prevention of suicide, a leading cause of death, we need more precise understanding of who needs what intervention and when through investigation of proximal risk factors, and impulsivity is an ideal candidate. The proposed research will use digital monitoring of patients at high risk for suicide to conduct the first intensive longitudinal assessment of multiple components of impulsivity and suicidal urges in real time among individuals at high risk for suicide. Findings will improve understanding of impulsivity as a transdiagnostic short-term risk factor for suicide, laying the groundwork for development of targeted interventions for suicide prevention, and may be generalizable to other impulsive behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Human diseases with multi-organ comorbidities are often misdiagnosed and require more complex clinical management. These comorbidities commonly include congenital defects present at birth including heart, lung, and limb defects, with some requiring immediate corrective surgery. Understanding how and why these comorbidities form in the first place can provide clinicians with more information about which disease symptoms are likely to co-occur, and whether we can devise treatment strategies compatible across disease groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance (IR) is a pathological state strongly associated with both obesity and aging, and represents a major risk factor for metabolic dysfunction, frailty, heart disease, stroke and dementia. Other than exercise and weight loss, limited mechanism-based strategies exist to improve IR and physical function. Here, we propose to examine the role of a specific cell population in IR associated with obesity using our novel animal model along with a cutting-edge technology, single cell transcriptomics. This project is likely to provide a deeper understanding of IR and lay the foundation for the drug development to alleviate IR and physical dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: The proposed research project is a feasibility and usability study of utilizing cutting-edge computer science methods – conversational agents, neural attention, transformers, supervised policy learning, variational autoencoders, and adversarial training – to develop an artificially intelligent agent for automated motivational interviewing counseling with a focus on weight loss. The proposed agent will circumvent barriers to healthcare providers' adoption of motivational interviewing, lack of fidelity to MI theory by human counselors, mitigate the issue of limited access to counseling services and complement human counselors in the behavioral healthcare delivery model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Studies in mammals have identified the FoxA family of regulatory proteins as among the most important in forming and maintaining internal organs during normal development and in preventing cancer and metabolic disease. Nonetheless, the complexity of mammalian (human) development and the redundant activities of the three mammalian FoxA proteins make it challenging to fully understand how these key proteins do their jobs. By focusing on the single family member in Drosophila and on a single relatively simple organ, we can begin to understand important details about how FoxA proteins control organ size, shape, position and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will study the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton within cells, which regulates their shape and motion, such as during organism development, differentiation, neuron function, or cancer cell metastasis. If successful, this basic science would underpin future medical research based on an understanding of cellular function.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Marfan Syndrome is a genetic disease that affects about 1 in 5000 people. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer among American women. To minimize the morbidity and mortality of this disease, we propose to develop a single photon emission breast tomography scanner with great imaging performance to carry out radionuclide tracer based molecular breast imaging. This scanner will use much less radioactivity and be able to detect smaller tumors than its state-of-art counterparts. In this proposed work, we will design, evaluate, and optimize the configurations of the scanner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and subsequently type 2 diabetes are increasingly common in pubertal youth, and with a greater degree of insulin resistance, earlier onset of beta-cell failure, and earlier need for insulin therapy than in adults. Medication responses in existing studies in youth-onset type 2 diabetes are poorer than similar studies in adults, with evidence that this aggressive phenotype is leading to earlier onset of diabetes complications. As a result, we now propose to recruit youth with obesity early in puberty and follow them longitudinally over time with serial assessments of insulin sensitivity and secretion, free-living glycemia, physical activity and sleep, mental health and stress, body composition, pubertal stage, and store samples for additional future analyses, with a new focus on understanding the unique, early contributors to development of type 2 diabetes in youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteroviruses are ubiquitous pathogens causing a number of important human diseases including poliomyelitis, myocarditis, acute flaccid myelitis and the common cold. Rhinovirus infections are a major cause of severe asthma exacerbations and non-poliovirus enteroviruses such as EV-A71 cause severe neuropathogenesis in children. Our contributions will have wide-reaching impacts as the identified cellular genes and molecular mechanisms are likely to provide new targets for therapeutic interventions, in addition to fundamentally advancing the fields of viral infection, immunity and protein methylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced maternal age represents a steadily increasing public health concern and is a poorly studied risk factor for cardiovascular disease in offspring later in life due to an unfavorable intrauterine environment during fetal development. We propose to use a combination of minimally-invasive imaging and sampling techniques to follow pregnant female monkeys over time to compare maternal cardiac function and placental blood flow in aged vs. young pregnancies, while also evaluating current adult offspring from aged vs. young pregnancies for evidence of early cardiovascular disease. Through a better understanding of abnormal changes that occur in both mothers and their offspring from pregnancies at advanced age, we may be able to identify new targets for therapies and critical timing for intervention that can prevent or delay the onset of cardiovascular disease.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is aimed at elucidating the mechanisms of the biosynthesis of β-lactam antibiotics by isopenicillin N-synthase (IPNS), and the oxidation of cysteine by the tumor suppressor enzyme cysteine dioxygenase (CDO). Small-molecule intermediate-analogues, low-temperature electronic absorption and Mössbauer spectroscopy, spectro-electrochemistry, and T-dependent kinetics will be used to probe key steps in the enzyme mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative My research program is devoted to understanding fundamental DNA repair mechanisms and their influence on cancer etiology and response to therapy. We will continue to approach these central questions by utilizing unique systems that we have developed to investigate the molecular events underlying (1) the influence of chromatin on DNA repair mechanism, and (2) interactions between repair mechanisms that affect genome maintenance. These pursuits will provide insights into adaptive responses of cancers that use noncanonical homology directed repair mechanisms to maintain telomere length.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington’s Disease and spinocerebellar ataxias are caused by inherited mutations in which the affected gene contains many extra copies of the three bases CAG. This research will develop new tools capable of imaging single RNA molecules to study how these mutations alter the mRNA structure and cause it to aggregate with other RNAs, resulting in cell death. The goal is to understand how these abnormal RNA structures harm neurons and cause deterioration of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Over one hundred de novo loss-of-function mutations in SYNGAP1 have been unambiguously associated with autism and intellectual disability. We uncovered a conserved SYNGAP1 alternative splicing event that is coupled with nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (AS-NMD) during normal mouse and human brain development. This research project aims to determine whether it is feasible to rescue SYNGAP1 haploinsufficiency by suppressing AS-NMD using genetically engineered mice and splice-switching oligonucleotides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emotion regulation (ER) impairments in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) exacerbate social difficulties and contribute to high rates of co-occurring psychiatric and behavioral problems, psychotropic medication prescription, and inpatient hospitalizations in this population. The proposed study will be a first step toward identifying early mechanisms and markers of ER impairment by examining emotional dynamics in parent-child interactions and their relation to ER development. By examining time-linked biological and behavioral markers of child emotional distress and parent responses, and applying machine learning approaches to examine multimodal relations between variables, the study has the potential to identify specific targets for interventions focused on ER development within the parent-child dyad.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  I aim to develop in vivo genome editing therapeutics to treat dilated cardiomyopathy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA hypomethylation is a nearly universal feature of cancer but the consequences of this epigenetic change are not well understood. This research proposal will investigate how DNA hypomethylation drives changes in genome organization and transcriptional programs, including activation of endogenous retroviral elements. Defining the functional consequences of DNA hypomethylation is critical for ongoing efforts to apply demethylating therapies for clinical benefit.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in human cell and genome engineering have facilitated the establishment of “disease-in-a- dish” approaches in which the molecular mechanisms of neurological disorders can be investigated directly in human cultured neurons. Using such a system, we will investigate how mutations in genes that cause the neurodevelopmental disorder Tuberous Sclerosis Complex affect human brain cell development and function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nature of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) suggests genetically susceptible individuals are persistently colonized with mildly pathogenic microbial strains or lack colitoprotective strains. The majority of human gut microbiota strains remain stably colonized in our gastrointestinal tract from years to decades. Using microbial strain tracking methods and gnotobiotic mouse models of colitis, we will assess if colitogenic and colitoprotective human gut microbes stably or transiently colonize the human gut microbiota and explore the practical implications for this stability in the context of fecal microbiota transplantation for ulcerative colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: BrightSpec Inc. NIH SBIR Application Project Narrative Novel Sample Introduction Methodologies for Molecular Rotational Resonance (MRR) Spectroscopy NIH SBIR Direct to Phase II BrightSpec, Inc. Project Narrative Small molecule analysis lies at the heart of basic research, and in particular pharmaceutical research, as the understanding and monitoring of biological systems through sensitive measurement of important compounds such as amino acids and sugars, drugs (and related metabolites), and potential toxins and impurities provide critical insight. The proposed project will significantly enhance the ability of researchers to identify and quantify small molecules by combining Laser-Induced Acoustic Desorption (LIAD) sample vaporization with Molecular Rotational Resonance (MRR) detection that is singularly selective to subtle changes in molecular structure. The resulting commercial LIAD-MRR instrument will dramatically expand the range of compounds accessible to this valuable technique with a sensitive, rapid, easy-to-use configuration, allowing researchers to learn more about their samples than currently possible with existing methods and improving the speed of new groundbreaking discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Tuberculosis (TB), caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), is a leading cause of human mortality in the world for a single infectious agent and drug-resistance to standard of care frontline and even second-line antibiotics is increasing, highlighting the need for new therapies. In this application, we propose to develop a series of small molecule compounds for the treatment of TB, resulting in the selection of optimized drug candidates. The proposed studies have the potential to result in the development of a new family of anti- mycobacterials to be used to treat both drug-sensitive and drug-resistant TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Subversion of cellular defense mechanisms is critical for robust Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) gene expression, replication and dissemination, and its ability to cause disease. This proposal investigates how cellular RNA quality control mechanisms regulate KSHV gene expression and viral replication as well as the mechanisms KSHV employs to disrupt these restrictive processes. Completion of this proposal will provide fundamental knowledge regarding the interactions between KSHV and cellular gene expression machinery and provide a framework for further therapeutic exploration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because IgG antibodies are widely used therapeutically to treat cancer, autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, allergies, infectious disease, as well as transplantation. Although sialylated IgG1 exerts anti- inflammatory properties, little is known regarding the contribution of sialylation to the other IgG subclasses (IgG2-4), or how extracellular sialylation is regulated. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because they will establish basic immunology knowledge relating to how IgG glycosylation modulates its biological activity, and will enable precise design of tailored effector functions for therapeutic immunoglobulins.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The consortium for the study of the Pathophysiology to Youth- Onset Type 2 diabetes is designed to understand which youth are at greatest to develop type 2 diabetes and how youth-onset type 2 diabetes develops. Cincinnati Children’s Hospital will contribute to the ongoing work of the consortium by providing clinical and research expertise, participating as a high volume center with diverse clinical cohorts, and proposing and supporting future studies using the platform of the consortium. The overarching goal is to develop effective strategies to prevent youth-onset type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure-based therapies are the current gold standard of care for anxiety and fear disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and success in exposure therapy depends on the process of extinction of conditioned fear. We have recently demonstrated that exposure paired with vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) enhances extinction of fear-based memories in rats. In the proposed studies, we further test whether VNS-paired exposure also produces longer-lasting and more generalizable extinction of learned fear, and we examine the neural mechanisms by which VNS enhances fear extinction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Child physical abuse is the source of hundreds of thousands of injuries, hundreds of deaths and billions of dollars in avoidable costs each year. This application will create data infrastructure to support a sustainable, multicenter research network dedicated to the care of physically abused children. By increasing research capacity related to physical abuse, these research resources will allow a new cadre of scientists to improve clinical care, decrease disparities and dramatically advance our understanding of child physical abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Anxiety and stress disorders including generalized anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, phobias and panic disorder are among the most prevalent mental illnesses, affecting approximately 40 million Americans (18.1%) and costing more than $42 billion a year. Critically, we have evidence suggesting that the development and maintenance of anxiety disorders are attributable to maladaptive fear and avoidance learning, a process partly modulated by the insula. Thus, in this proposal, we aim to investigate the involvement of insular single cell ensembles in aversive learning and develop a novel computational tool to predict future maladaptive aversive learning phenotypes based on the neural signaling in the insula.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE US children, especially low-income and Latinx, eat too little fruits and vegetables and whole grains, and too many energy-dense snacks and beverages, dietary behaviors associated with increased morbidity from cardiovascular diseases. The proposed research will build upon prior pilot work to test the efficacy of a novel home-based intervention to improve the diet quality and family food environment of preschool age, low-income, Latinx children. The intervention will target healthy food access, engage parents with video-clips of their own meal time behaviors together with motivational interviewing, in-home cooking demonstrations, and tailored materials based on their child’s appetitive traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Minority youth are at elevated risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D) relative to non-Hispanic whites (NHW), with African-Americans (AA) and Hispanic-Americans (HA) showing the greatest increase in prevalence since 2000. Our overarching hypothesis is that underlying differences in genes and physiology in minority children interact with environmental factors in an adverse manner to increase risk for T2D. This study will follow 100 at-risk youth aged 8-16 yr for 5 years to identify factors that predict conversion to T2D, and determine why conversion to T2D is more likely among minority youth.

ORG_NAME: NYU LONG ISLAND SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: High plasma lipids are a major risk factor for cardiovascular/metabolic diseases. MTP inhibition is a proven target to lower plasma lipids. However, current inhibitors completely block all MTP activities and are associated with serious side effects. Our studies involve understanding the dynamic three dimensional nature of this protein and how it can be used to generate new drugs that target specific regions of the protein to limit drug side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Our studies are relevant to a vascular disease, so-called hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. The studies focus on a previously unknown mechanism of arteriovenous malformations in hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Understanding of this new mechanism may lead to the opportunities for the treatment of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease that is the result of multiple factors including biology, behavior, and environment. This study will examine how various factors interact in very high risk youth to cause T2D early in life. Findings from this study will help advance the understanding of T2D in youth in order to design better prevention and treatment programs for children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PPROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is the most common heart arrhythmia and the development of new therapeutic approaches requires better understanding of the causes of this arrhythmia. This proposal will focus on the role of molecular pathways that regulate metabolism in the electrical and structural remodeling of the atria. We will test whether drugs targeting metabolic stress pathways can prevent atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public health relevance statement Disorders and disruptions to brain health from disease, traumatic injury, and ageing lead to cognitive functional disabilities affecting a significant population of the United States. The proposed project will use a genetic model system to study the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which brain chemicals function to integrate different senses, as well as how deficits are caused and ameliorated. The proposed research is expected to facilitate broader understanding of normal brain function, and thus better understand dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative A multitude of environmental agents from food, air and water bombard cells inducing accumulation of reactive oxygen species that lead to oxidative DNA damage, genomic instability and disease. DNA repair pathways, such as base-excision repair and non-homologous end- joining have evolved to counter that damage, yet little is known about the molecular details and structural transactions underlying efficient and mutation-prone or mutation-free repair. Here, using state of the art structural and functional approaches, we determine the impact of the mechanism of DNA polymerase-mediated synthesis that enables repair of oxidative DNA damage in multiprotein DNA repair complexes and the maintenance of genomic stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early pre-cancerous lesions in the oral cavity can be managed effectively until they become invasive, but currently, we lack an understanding of the biological factors that contribute to or protect against progression. In this study, we will use exciting new advances in tissue imaging that enable the measurement of many proteins expressed within individual cells to investigate the immune response to these tumors. We will test the hypothesis that the types of immune cells present in pre-cancerous lesions and the activation state of these cells are major determinants of progression into invasive cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: The majority of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cannot be cured with currently available therapies; however, our team has demonstrated that targeting leukemia antigens using chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells (i.e. 8F4-CAR-T cells) is a safe and efficacious approach to eradicate leukemic cells, including stem cells. Published clinical and preclinical data in hematologic and solid tumor malignancies show that fucosylation of T cells enhances T cell homing and cytotoxic functions. The studies proposed in this grant application will build on these data, and will allow us to obtain preclinical data to study the effects of fucosylation on CAR-T cell function, which will form the basis to develop future clinical trials evaluating adoptive T cell therapy with fucosylated CAR-T cells as a novel therapeutic strategy for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of innovative medical devices and technologies depends on a biomedical engineering workforce capable of identifying unmet clinical needs and working in teams to develop design solutions. Clinics in urban environments present unique health care issues, and this clinical immersion and team-based design program will challenge students to engage in engineering design in this context, with socioeconomic considerations in mind. The project will implement the novel INdiana Summer Clinical Residency in Innovation for Biomedical Engineers [(IN)SCRIBE] Program at Indiana University–Purdue University Indianapolis, in collaboration with the IU School of Medicine, to prepare biomedical engineering students for clinically-relevant, team-based design in an urban setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Red blood cells are generated through a process of extreme terminal differentiation, whereby thousands of proteins are lost from the cell and replaced primarily by hemoglobin, which eventually constitutes ~98% of soluble protein. It has been a mystery how so many proteins could be eliminated from cells while specific proteins such as hemoglobin are preserved, but our recent work has implicated the protein modifier ubiquitin in this process, and in the proposed studies we will map this novel biological process by applying quantitative global proteomics and biochemical analysis to numerous mutants of ubiquitinating enzymes that are specifically induced in the late phase of red blood cell differentiation. These studies are providing a fundamental new perspective on cellular differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suppression of anti-tumor immune response is a major mechanism facilitating the progression and therapeutic resistance of glioblastoma (GBM), the most malignant primary brain tumor. The objective of this project is to gain mechanistic insight into how differential accumulation and function of myeloid-derived suppressor cell (MDSC) subtypes in males versus females contribute to persistent GBM growth via suppression of local and systemic immunity, regulation of the complement system and re-programing the tumor microenvironment. The successful completion of this proposal will elucidate novel interventions targeting MDSC subset variation and account for sex as a biological variable for improved immunotherapy response, which will further be developed as part of my independent research program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transforming growth factor beta2 (TGF-β2) is an important secreted protein that directs the proper development and functioning of the cardiovascular system. Disruption of TGF-β2 is associated with disorders such as Loeys-Dietz Syndrome Type 4, scleroderma, and Kawasaki disease that can cause severe defects in the heart and blood vessels. This grant will deepen our structural and biochemical knowledge of how TGF- β2 is activated in the body and will have broad implications for our understanding of these diseases while setting the stage for the development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In cancer, arginine metabolism is often shunted into the pathways that produce polyamines, essential for cell growth and immuno-suppression; however, there is a critical gap in developing a method to correct arginine metabolism to suppress cancer growth. The proposed project aims to test whether sepiapterin, the naturally- occurring precursor of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) cofactor BH4, could normalize arginine metabolism to prevent breast cancer formation or enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy for breast cancer. The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will justify the use of sepiapterin as an adjuvant to immunotherapy or preventative agent for breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Currently, the vast majority of cancer single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) studies utilize cell-level gene expression to explore intratumorally heterogeneity. We propose to maximize the information gained from scRNA-seq data by integrating assessments of Single Cell-specific Expressed Single Nucleotide Variants (sceSNVs) with cell phenotypes, including gene expression, cell type, developmental stage, and cell fate. We will integrate recently developed by ours and other groups tools to correlate sceSNV expression to cell phenotypes and will catalog sceSNVs and their functional annotations in a public pan-cancer single cell Variome (scVariome) catalogue for community use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The flavivirus genus contains many mosquito-borne human pathogens, including dengue, yellow fever, Zika, and West Nile viruses, that pose major public health threats but exhibit distinct tissue tropism and disease manifestations in infected humans, ranging from inapparent infections to severe and sometimes fatal disease. We recently demonstrated that flavivirus NS1 proteins mediate endothelial dysfunction and vascular leak in a tissue-specific manner reflecting the disease tropism of the distinct viruses. Using in vitro human endothelial cell systems, in vivo mouse models, and clinical samples from severe dengue and yellow fever patients, this proposal aims to identify and characterize host factors and viral NS1 determinants critical for NS1 cell binding, internalization, and signaling, which will improve our understanding of flavivirus pathogenesis and result in potential biomarkers for severe disease and novel viral and host therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Over 1,800,000 dental implants are placed in the U.S. annually, and by 2020, an expected 45,000,000 patients worldwide could benefit from at least one dental implant. Since bone quality is a key consideration for both short and long-term success of dental implants, new strategies of augmenting bone regeneration in the oral cavity are needed to support their use as the need continues to grow. Exosomes, a cell-secreted product containing bio-instructive molecules, show great promise in causing regeneration of bone and mineralized tissue when paired with an appropriate delivery platform, developed and validated in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the roles of distinct cell types in the pancreatic tumor microenvironment would inform on the complex biology of this intractable disease and help to identify potential strategies for therapeutic intervention. The studies proposed here will test the novel hypothesis that particular cells within healthy pancreas tissue known as stellate cells give rise to a tumor-promoting, functionally significant subset of the expansive fibroblast population of pancreatic tumors, and therefore represent a viable therapeutic target. Together, these studies will help us understand the mechanisms and consequences of pancreatic cancer stromal evolution, and may identify novel functions of these fibroblastic cells to be targeted for therapeutic benefit.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Advances in high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) offer unique opportunities to study the human exposome and the development of adverse health outcomes. Despite advances in non-targeted analysis, the number of confirmed chemicals remains fairly limited compared to the number of detected chemical features. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel computational methods to derive chemical structures and apply them to a large dataset of HRMS data from blood samples of pregnant women to study the influence of the exposome on pregnancy outcomes with a focus on preterm birth.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans, who were exposed to loud noise during training and while in theater, are more likely to experience dizziness, imbalance, and poor postural control. Vestibular organs transmit key information to central vestibular nuclei that control body position and movement in space as well as posture. Compromise of these critical cues for maintaining postural control and balance puts our Veterans at higher risk for falls as they age. Falls account for more than 50% of accidental deaths. Peripheral vestibular organs project to central vestibular nuclei responsible for transmitting signals for control of posture. Identifying and testing interventions for vestibular dysfunction in humans and in pre-clinical models requires central assessment tools, which are currently lacking in the field. We will examine differential noise effects on activity in vestibular central pathways while validating tools for future assessment of chronic effects.
