IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE  Chronic pain and disability after bone fracture is common. Approaches to pain management following orthopaedic surgery often include the use of opioids. We have identified a new targeted bone healing agent that may not only improve bone healing but may also decrease the associated pain. The latter could replace the necessity of opioids for pain management and serve as an important step in fighting the current opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older people sleep less, have more fragmented sleep, and nap more during the day, but the cause of these changes is not known. However, we now know that neurodegenerative processes deposit the hallmark proteins for Alzheimer’s disease (Abeta and phospho-tau), Parkinson’s disease (phospho-α-synuclein) and fronto-temporal lobe dementia (phospho-TDP-43) in neurons in the brain for many years before the neurological disorder can be diagnosed. We will investigate whether the aging changes in sleep are due to the deposition of these pathological proteins in neurons in the wake-sleep and circadian circuitry in the brain and may serve as a biomarker for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The incidence and prevalence of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are rapidly rising worldwide, but an effective pharmacotherapy is lacking. This project will apply state-of-the-art approaches to comprehensively characterize senescent hepatocytes that accumulate during NAFLD progression, uncover the underlying mechanisms for their senescence and determine whether targeting these mechanisms improves NAFLD. Successful complete of this study will provide the groundwork for future studies that exploit cellular senescence as a novel therapeutic strategy to treat liver diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This project will utilize clinical data from several hundred Veterans who have received and will receive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) for depression as part of the nationwide “VA TMS Pilot Program” to develop a generalized model of TMS treatment response. This project will replicate and expand a nonlinear modeling approach of the TMS treatment response that we have developed using clinical data from our lab (n=97) as well as published group-level data from multiple large clinical trials of TMS. This nonlinear modeling approach uses an exponential decay function to quantify the magnitude, speed, and outcomes of TMS treatment response. This model provides a comprehensive characterization of the total TMS treatment course as well as an approach to predict treatment outcomes based on early response. This CDA2 will replicate and expand this work using the largest dataset of TMS response in Veterans to date and will yield precision psychiatry tools that would be widely applicable to many psychiatric interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA sleep medicine clinics exceeded 720,000 patient visits in 2018, and Veterans continue to have high rates of sleep disturbances and insomnia disorders. Rapidly expanding legislation in the U.S. has engendered widespread beliefs about cannabis’ therapeutic benefits, and Veterans often use cannabis for sleep despite equivocal evidence supporting its efficacy. Moreover, it remains uncertain which cannabis modes, formulations, or THC:CBD ratios are most harmful (or helpful) to sleep. This CDA-2 application will implement an innovative approach using different technologies to assess Veterans’ cannabis use and sleep over time, and in the natural environment. Results from this proposal and subsequent grants extending those findings will address a crucial knowledge gap concerning bi-directional links between cannabis, subjective sleep quality and sleep physiology (e.g., efficiency). Implications of this new knowledge cannot be overstated as sleep and several mental health issues common to Veterans (e.g., cannabis use disorder) are inextricably intertwined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cardiorespiratory diseases are the most common causes of mortality and morbidity worldwide, including high rates of psychological distress symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety, PTSD). Although symptomatic patients experience worse outcomes from their cardiorespiratory conditions, there are few interventions designed to address this problem at the population scale needed. This application is designed to test Blueprint, a self-directed mobile app-based intervention for psychological distress versus an Education Program control in a multicenter efficacy-focused clinical trial with specific targets for enrollment by race, ethnicity, gender, and Spanish spoken as a first language.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Older Veterans are more likely to die by suicide, as well as have more physical and cognitive challenges than the general population of the same age. Also, older Veterans with depression have major challenges that affect social involvement in their community, and connections with friends, and family. This can negatively affect their lives in many ways. VOICES Veterans Socials is a peer intervention in the community that creates weekly social groups for Veterans and has the potential to improve social functioning, mental health symptoms, and create lasting social support. These goals are consistent with the National Strategy on Reducing Military and Veteran Suicide, priority goal 4, addressing upstream risk and protective factors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over 200,000 veterans suffer from chronic kidney disease, and nearly 30,000 of them already require dialysis to save their lives. Despite all technological and surgical advances, hemodialysis vascular access failure remains the primary source of hospitalization and complication, especially in veteran patients. This study identifies the molecules responsible for the most common vascular access failure in veterans, the arteriovenous fistula. Outcomes from these studies may represent a breakthrough that will provide new therapeutic targets and strategies to improve vascular access dysfunction, reduce medical complications, and ultimately save lives.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A crucial component of treatment success in HCC is early and appropriate diagnosis, currently done via CT/ MRI scans with or without biopsy. We propose a new way to enhance the detection and accuracy of staging of HCC, by using PSMA PET in addition to standard CT/MRI, in three different clinical settings (surveillance, untreated, and previously treated veterans). We anticipate that PSMA PET will improve HCC detection in indeterminate lesions, enable additional visualization of entire tumors in a more functional manner, and decrease reliance on invasive and limited biopsies. The overall impact of the study is to enhance treatment capabilities by decreasing time to initiation of therapy based upon improved detection of HCC or potential HCC by using PSMA PET and early initiation of systemic therapy in patients with otherwise undetectable metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is one of the leading causes of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in the elderly, and bleeding from the leptomeningeal vasculature has recently been implicated in the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying CAA-related ICH. The proposed research will use a multimodal approach combining neuropathological analysis of human tissue and in vivo imaging of mouse models to investigate the causes and consequences of leptomeningeal bleeding in CAA. This project has the potential to uncover novel, and much-needed, therapeutic targets for the prevention of CAA-related ICH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current paradigm of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) pathogenesis is based on progressive renal cysts growth over the patient's life, with the most prominent cysts being those that emerged in utero. However, data obtained with our new lab-made image analysis tools show that individual cysts' growth is a dynamic process with highly variable cysts' growth rates that change over time. Therefore, we plan to provide mechanistic insight into the pathobiology of cysts formation’s dynamic and regression phases using a model of injury-induced cystogenesis in our new Pkd2K874A*1/+ rat (with and without C3 complement deficiency) and complement these studies with single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Veterans are at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma (CCA)—a type of liver cancer—due to their advanced age and increased incidence of hepatitis C virus and chronic liver disease. Despite the use of systemic chemotherapy, CCA is deadly with a 5-year survival of 10% in the advanced setting. Recent work has defined distinct molecular subtypes of CCA, however tuning precision strategies for an individual remains limited to a few select biomarkers and chemotherapy remains a standard of care, despite significant clinical toxicities. I hypothesize that cyclin-dependent kinase 7 (CDK7) regulates response to DNA damage after chemotherapy in patient-derived organoid and xenograft models of CCA. By characterizing the mechanism of this response in combination with chemotherapy, we can develop biologically informed combination therapy. Together, this project utilizes human models of CCA to better understand both therapeutic sensitivities and resistance mechanisms to inform rational strategies to improve the survival of Veterans with this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The demographics of the veteran population clearly demonstrate that illnesses afflicting the elderly are a major concern of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Currently, the number of veterans over 50 years of age represents over 70% of the total veteran population. Research has shown that chronic, low-grade inflammation increases dramatically with age and that inflammation is a major risk factor for a variety of age- related diseases that affect elderly veterans, especially neurogenerative diseases like Alzheimer's disease. The research in this application will study a novel mechanism involved in neuroinflammation: the activation of necroptosis specifically in neurons is proposed to induce the release of necroptotic extracellular vesicles from neurons that activate microglia and astrocytes leading to neuroinflammation, which results in neuronal dysfunction and reduced cognition. Data from this project has the potential of leading to new therapies to treat neurodegeneration and the loss of cognition that occurs with age in elderly veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental exposures to metals (e.g., lead) early in life have long-term adverse health effects, partly due to dysregulated epigenetic reprogramming that includes genomic imprinting. The proposed study seeks to investigate molecular mechanisms governing genomic imprinting following early life lead exposure by characterizing sex-, tissue-, and developmental stage-specific imprinted gene dysregulation. Evaluation of exposure-relevant mechanisms during gestation will elucidate toxicoepigenetic reprogramming by fetal sex to lay the groundwork for potential interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Existence of disparities in health in disadvantaged populations in the country is a major problem. The lack of sufficient diverse representation among researchers and scientists who work on lung, sleep, and pandemic related consequences on lung and sleep problems has become a critical and urgent challenge. Our proposed training program is designed to help address these problems by increasing the number of well-trained early career faculty from institutions across the country that will be positioned to contribute to research geared to resolve health and healthcare disparities in the area of lung, sleep, and pandemic consequences to lung and sleep conditions and thereby promote health equity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cryptococcus is a ubiquitous fungal pathogen that causes substantial morbidity and mortality in Veterans and other patients. Veterans have an increased risk of infection due to higher rates of immunocompromising medical conditions relative to the general population. Current therapies for patients infected with Cryptococcus are lengthy, highly toxic, often ineffective, and may contribute to inflammatory complications linked to pathological tissue damage, mortality, and/or the development of lasting disabilities in these patients. Antibody immunotherapies neutralizing targeted pathways already have revolutionized the treatment of autoimmune diseases and some types of leukemia, through their specificity allowing for the elimination of a single immune factor which has a causal role. This validation study will test the effectiveness of anti-CXCR3 antibody treatment in limiting detrimental immune responses during cryptococcal CNS infection using a mouse model of cryptococcal meningitis and promises to create much safer alternative to the existing treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Current therapies for prostate cancer aimed at targeting the androgen receptor (AR) fail due to development of drug-resistance. A possible mechanism is AR axis therapy stress-induced elevation of protein kinase CK2, a major player in cancer pathobiology and progression through its promotion of cell survival. The present work is to identify the mechanism of CK2 function in prostate cancer and to establish that using CX-4945/Silmitasertib (a clinical grade inhibitor of CK2) as a co-therapy may lead to improved precision management of prostate cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the protein tyrosine phosphatase N2 (PTPN2) gene are confirmed risk markers in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and are associated with earlier onset and increased severity of disease. There are a lack of suitable model systems to study how PTPN2 variants compromise the function of intestinal epithelial cells, the critical cell type that comprises the gut barrier. In this proposal, we will utilize the unique resources of the IBDGC to develop cutting-edge models to uncover a greater translational understanding of how PTPN2 variants contribute to gut barrier dysfunction in IBD, and create novel tools for future ‘personalized’ drug development studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders represent a major public health problem with a great need for better treatments that can delay, slow, or prevent the disease. Based on recent data from our lab, we are determining the mechanisms via which T cells, antigen presenting cells, and microglia interact to lead to tau- mediated neurodegeneration. We are also exploring novel treatments based on targeting T cells and T cell signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiorespiratory diseases are the most common causes of mortality and morbidity worldwide, including high rates of psychological distress symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety, PTSD). Although symptomatic patients experience worse outcomes from their cardiorespiratory conditions, there are few interventions designed to address this problem at the population scale needed. This application is designed to test Blueprint, a self- directed mobile app-based intervention for psychological distress versus an Education Program control in a multicenter, efficacy-focused clinical trial with specific targets for enrollment by race, ethnicity, gender, and Spanish spoken as a first language.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a debilitating blinding disease of older age that is prevalent in the Veteran population. Although perturbed vitamin A and ocular retinoid metabolism have been implicated in AMD pathogenesis, limitations in our understanding of these pathways has hampered efforts to therapeutically intervene in this disease. The goal of this proposal is to genetically or pharmacologically modulate pathways linked to vitamin A metabolism and retinal disease pathogenesis to gain insights necessary for development of novel therapies to treat retinopathies including AMD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mesothelioma is devastating to Veterans. Inadequate therapies exist for the treatment of mesothelioma, as the median survival for treated metastatic mesothelioma is approximately 1-2 years. Many Veterans were exposed to asbestos via shipbuilding. Ongoing studies suggest that the incidence of mesothelioma is not declining. This may be in part due to issues with exposure to asbestos fibers via mining. Carbon nanotubes have been shown to induce mesothelioma in mice. Many people who develop mesothelioma have significant co-morbidities that preclude aggressive treatment. The last FDA approval for a new drug for mesothelioma was in 2020, but this immunotherapy-based regimen has modest benefits. Validation of targeting pyrimidine biosynthesis via inhibition of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) as a promising and novel approach to treating mesothelioma will de-risk further development of targeting DHODH as a potential therapeutic strategy against mesothelioma in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PET radiotracers targeting amyloid beta and hyperphosphorylated tau, the two major hallmark neuropathologies in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), have been successfully developed and are now widely used in clinical research. However, strong evidence suggest that additional pathophysiological processes, such as myelin pathology and vascular dysfunction, may coexist and contribute to the etiology of the disease. We propose to characterize the PET radiotracer [18F]3F4AP’s properties and performance in human subjects with AD, mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and cognitively normal (CN) individuals for detecting and quantifying demyelination and cerebral perfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People experiencing homelessness have been substantially and disproportionately impacted by the opioid overdose crisis. Though retention in opioid use disorder treatment reduces mortality in this population, retention is suboptimal. In this proposal, the investigators will use a community-engaged approach to develop and pilot test a tailored peer recovery support intervention to promote opioid use disorder treatment retention among people experiencing homelessness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Suicide is a major health crisis within our Veteran population. Inflammation is associated with suicide risk. Understanding the biological mechanisms linking inflammation and suicidal thoughts and behavior is critical to developing diagnostic tools and preventative treatments for Veterans at risk of suicide. This study will assess the contribution of inflammatory processes in the brains of suicide decedents at the molecular level, with the goal to identify genetic factors that contribute to inflammation and risk of suicide.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistance is one of the greatest medical challenges of our time; to effectively treat resistant bacterial infections it is critical to have accurate and personalized data on which drugs can kill infecting strains. We have discovered that a widespread yet vastly underappreciated form of antibiotic resistance (heteroresistance) that is undetectable by current tests can cause treatment failures. We have developed a novel antibiotic susceptibility testing technology that is more sensitive, highly accurate, and faster than current tests, and has the potential to significantly improve the care of Veterans and other patients, potentially saving lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Babies born with complex heart defects often experience a lifetime of surgeries and hospitalizations accompanied by both short and long-term injury to their vital organs (including their brain, heart, kidneys, and intestines). In this project, we will use new laboratory tests capable of measuring hundreds of proteins and metabolites from a tiny blood sample to explore how our children’s bodies respond to their heart surgery and subsequent vital organ injury. We will also use the millions of data points collected to train a new generation of young scientists to improve outcomes for children with complex heart defects using data science techniques.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Oxidized phospholipids containing phosphocholine (PC-OxPLs) are pathogenic in multiple diseases and their deleterious effects are blocked by the natural antibody E06 IgM. Transgenic expression of E06 causes bone anabolism and prevents age-and high fat diet-associated bone loss by increasing osteoblasts and bone formation; in addition, it prevents atherosclerosis, steatohepatitis and cardiovascular diseases. Therefore, anti- PC antibodies, may be a novel therapy to ameliorate multiple diseases. We will investigate the mechanisms by which E06 causes bone anabolism, and whether injections of a murine monoclonal E06 IgG increase bone mass in young and old mice. Endogenous levels of anti-PC IgM antibodies are inversely correlated with bone density in humans. We will measure the levels of anti-PC IgM in a cohort of patients from the Osteoporotic Fractures in Men (MrOS) study and the Study of Osteoporotic Fractures (SOF) in women and determine whether the levels of these antibodies correlate with longitudinal changes of BMD and fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular and cellular mechanisms that contribute to the modulation of mechanotransduction and mechanosensitivity under normal, pathological, or adaptive conditions remain to be fully elucidated. The objective of this proposal is to investigate biophysical basis of mechanosensitivity under conditions of prolonged hypothermia, using hibernating thirteen-lined ground squirrels as a naturalistic model. Insights gleaned from these studies will facilitate rational development of pharmacology to alleviate symptoms associated with neuropathic somatosensory dysfunction in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Ischemic heart disease due to non-obstructive coronary stenosis and small vessel dysfunction (coronary microvascular disease, CMD) is more common than previously thought. The underdiagnosis of CMD and lack of therapeutic options have resulted from our myopic view of obstructive coronary stenosis as the only reason for chest pain and the requirement for invasive coronary testing. We aim to improve the management of CMD by further targeting our high-resolution cardiac MRI framework and developing methods for non-invasive estimation of patient-specific coronary hemodynamic parameters; both will enable detection, monitoring, and testing of therapeutic interventions for CMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms after a myocardial infarction (MI) is common (>35% of patients), with serious implications for increasing risk of rehospitalization and mortality within 1 year. To address the NHLBI Research Priority regarding mechanisms whereby psychosocial stress contributes to ischemic heart disease progression, the proposed K23 study will test psychological and physiological stress reactivity as a mechanism linking PTSD symptoms with elevated ambulatory blood pressure during the post-MI adjustment period. Using ecological momentary assessment and ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, the proposed study will advance our understanding of stress reactivity as a promising modifiable mechanism in MI patients and inform the future development of a larger study of diverse MI patients with PTSD symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The progressive neurodegenerative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) became a major global health crisis, with ineffective treatment of amyloid plaque-removal, even the latest drug (Lecanemab) can only extend the self- sustained lifetime with 6 months. We aim to characterize the sequential order of complex neurogliovascular events in a longitudinal multi-modal animal study using novel simultaneous MRI and fluorescent Ca-imaging methods before, after, and at the onset of AD. The simultaneous functional activity and connectivity, cerebrovascular reactivity, metabolism, and vascular health in AD model will reveal views of when these dysfunctions occur and improve the option to intervene before the late state of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects more than 90% of the human population and is important in a variety of malignancies in humans including Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin Lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), and gastric carcinoma. EBV infection of the epithelium is a complicated process that has not been fully elucidated. The proposed studies will contribute to a mechanistic understanding of EBV entry as well as entry process for other herpesviruses into healthy epithelium and may result in the development of novel virus entry inhibitors for EBV as well as other herpesviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intensive searches of the human genome have identified more than 200 genetic risk loci for inflammatory bowel disease. However, understanding how these genetic factors confer risk for inflammatory bowel disease and clinical application are unmet challenges. We will use a cutting-edge single cell trimodal omics approach to study specific subtypes of immune cells isolated from study subjects with European, African American or West African ancestry to gain a better understanding of how human genetic variations predispose individuals to the dysregulation of the immune system that underlies inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative We propose an extensive set of genome-wide association studies of PTSD, which are important for veterans because they can identify specific genetic variants associated with an increased risk for developing PTSD after exposure to trauma. By identifying these genetic risk factors, we create the potential to develop personalized prevention strategies and treatment plans for veterans. Furthermore, these studies can also provide important insights into the biological mechanisms underlying PTSD, which can inform the development of new and more effective treatments for this debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia can initiate sepsis, a leading cause of global morbidity that causes immense socioeconomic burdens as the most expensive hospital treated condition. This research will define host- pathogen interactions during K. pneumoniae bacteremia, with the goal of identifying pathways that can be targeted or enhanced by future therapies to aid in the clearance of bacteremia. By defining immunomodulatory processes of K. pneumoniae bacteremia that could result in novel therapies, this research directly advances the NIH mission of defining the nature and behavior of living systems to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Repetitive, mild traumatic brain injury is increasing seen in soldiers deployed to combat areas and linked to persistent, debilitating neurological symptoms in Veterans. Currently, only supportive therapies exist and pharmacotherapies that improve neurological function years after the initiating event are desperately needed. We are developing nanomaterials for delivery of therapeutics to the brain. With this approach we aim to reverse neurological injuries like those linked to traumatic brain injury. If successful, the work could put forth the first pharmacotherapy for Veterans suffering from debilitating symptoms that persist in the years following the initiating brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia and characterized by pathology beginning in hippocampus and adjacent brain regions implicated in memory. Among the memory impairments are social cognition memories that allow us to recognize and discriminate familiar individuals. These memory traces may be stabilized by extracellular matrix structure, perineuronal nets (PNNs) that surround hippocampal neurons and we found these to be disrupted in AD and hypothesize that proteolysis of PNNs in hippocampus are causal of social memory decline in AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) comprises a spectrum of liver pathologies from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH; hepatic inflammation and fibrosis) and cirrhosis. This condition is an important issue for the VA healthcare system considering the increased liver-related, cardiovascular disease, and all-cause mortality associated with progression to NASH. This study will examine the novel relationship between endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) and the regulation of hepatic de novo lipogenesis in the development of NAFLD and a novel role for eNOS in the activation of Kupffer cells and hepatic stellate cells in the development and progression of NASH. The outcomes of this study will improve our understanding about the mechanisms responsible for NASH development and progression and highlight potential therapeutic targets for the future treatment of NASH.

PHR: Narrative  A generalized deficit in motivation is a behavioral symptom associated with mental health disorders. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Melanoma is an aggressive skin cancer and the fifth most common cancer in the US population. US Veterans are particularly impacted by skin cancer because of radiation and UV exposure. Most melanomas are diagnosed at an early, localized stage, but approximately 10-15% of these melanomas eventually metastasize despite appropriate treatment. This progression of localized melanoma to metastatic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. No treatment exists for melanoma patients who are at high risk of future metastasis, but whose clinical stage does not qualify for existing adjuvant treatments. Preliminary data suggests that use of statins, a class of cholesterol medication, may decrease melanoma metastasis. This study will evaluate the relationship between statin use and melanoma outcomes from multiple angles and generate data that could lead to a decisive clinical trial and to the first treatment to prevent metastasis of genetically high-risk melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative PDA ligation is a life-saving intervention for some extremely preterm infants but is associated with severe post- interventional cardiorespiratory instability [Post-Ligation Cardiac Syndrome (PLCS)] due to impaired heart function, which may lead to death, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or neurodevelopmental impairment at 2 years of age. In many centers PLCS is recognized late, when hypotension is severe, prompting use of harmful vasopressor drugs (increase afterload); however, preliminary evidence suggests that prophylactic use of intravenous milrinone (decrease afterload) decreases the risk of PLCS. This randomized trial is designed to evaluate whether a preemptive approach to milrinone treatment will reduce the risk of death or postinterventional cardiorespiratory deterioration. By mitigating the risk of PLCS, patients will require have decreased duration of postinterventional ventilation, and decreased risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia and adverse neurodevelopmental outcome. Of note, this trial will be the first and only randomized trial of milrinone in premature infants to appraise both short and long-term treatment safety.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Thyroid hormone (TH) is essential for brain development and for normal brain function in the adult. Traumatic brain injury (TBI) has a high prevalence among the Veteran population, up to 20%, with associated morbidity and mortality. TBI is associated with reduced levels of thyroid hormone (TH) in the serum as well as in the brain. In rodent TBI models, treatment with TH shortly after injury, has been shown to protect the brain from injury, reduce brain edema and promote recovery. In a cell culture model of neuronal damage from low oxygen, which occurs in TBI, TH treatment protects from injury and promotes neuronal regeneration. Understanding the mechanisms of thyroid hormone protection of neuronal injury and the pathways activated could have important applications to limit brain injury and promote recovery in Veterans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing behavioral postpartum weight interventions have largely failed to produce substantial improvements in maternal cardiometabolic health in part due to high participant burden and failure to address the psychological needs (e.g., fatigue) and competing demands (e.g., childcare) of postpartum women. Early time-restricted eating focuses on a single target behavior (i.e. timing of intake), making it a straightforward dietary approach which may confer benefits behaviorally (e.g., improved adherence) and physiologically (e.g., improved insulin sensitivity) that are especially relevant postpartum. This project will test the feasibility of such an intervention, which can then be tested in an adequately powered R01 randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The major objective of this research project is to determine whether molecular mediators, generated by injured peripheral nerves or genetically engineered to bind the low-density lipoprotein receptor related protein (LRP1), regulate Schwann cell physiology, and prevent the development of painful peripheral neuropathy. We hypothesize that activation of Schwann cell LRP1 will limit neuroinflammation in DRGs and change the cellular landscape of peripheral nerves induced by toxic chemotherapy drugs. Identifying novel activators of the SC Repair Program will provide innovative strategies for treating painful peripheral neuropathies which is highly prevalent in veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative As our knowledge about brain pericytes and their functions in CNS diseases grow tremendously in the last decade, the lack of specific marker or genetic tools for brain pericytes has become a major hurdle in the field to key questions such as brain pericyte's heterogeneity. We have developed new genetic tools based on a brain pericyte specific marker Atp13a5, and found interesting heterogeneity of brain pericytes between regions inside and outside the blood brain barrier (BBB). Therefore, we propose to further investigate the genetic and functional difference between BBB pericytes and non-BBB pericytes using our new genetic tools based on the Atp13a5 model, and understand their changes associated with aging and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most prevalent service-connected disability of all the respiratory disabilities for which Veterans receive benefits. Between 2015-2018, OSA burden has increased from 664,000 to 1.3 million Veterans, generating nearly $234 million in sleep apnea supply cost, despite fewer than 50% of Veterans using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) devices as prescribed. There are multiple mechanisms underlying sleep apnea pathogenesis, each of which may be amenable to tailored treatment beyond CPAP alone. The purpose of this proposal will be to identify the mechanisms underlying an understudied mode of pharyngeal collapse called negative effort dependence. This work will pave a path towards individualized Veteran sleep care based on individual physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth with early juvenile justice involvement engage in high rates of problematic cannabis use; however, existing intervention approaches to address this issue are either overly intensive in nature or not designed for the unique needs of youths in the juvenile justice system (e.g., addressing concurrent HIV/STI risk behaviors and/or delinquency). The proposed study will provide important data on the acceptability, feasibility, and initial efficacy of an adapted modular and personalizable family-based intervention for cannabis use among early justice-involved youth. The proposed project also has implications for the effective development of substance use interventions which can be implemented as part of a continuum of care within the juvenile justice system.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The human brain makes and releases endocannabinoids in order to allow the body to perform certain tasks. The internal detection system for the endocannabinoids is present in a large fraction of human nerve cells and can also be used by drugs like cannabis. Cannabis and related drugs have been increasingly used by US Veterans to try and treat several diseases including chronic pain, epilepsy, and posttraumatic stress disorder. Unfortunately, cannabis and related drugs also cause unwanted side effects that limit their usefulness. Cannabis and related drugs appear to have several actions on nerve cells but the relative strength of the different actions is not understood. In this proposal, we describe how we will increase our understanding about the various actions of endocannabinoids and cannabis-related drugs on individual nerve cells. By characterizing these drug actions, we will determine which represent plausible targets for new drugs that will improve the treatment of important diseases experienced by Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, one in three older adults in the U.S. dies with or from dementia, a progressive serious illness causing significant public health burden. Yet there are inequities in access to and quality of hospice care at end-of-life among Black, Latinx, and Asian Americans with dementia. This study aims to use multiple methods to generate data on current experiences with and preferences for dementia hospice care and (in collaboration with former caregivers, hospice and dementia experts, and policymakers) generate a prioritized list of recommendations for improving hospice care for racial and ethnic minoritized people with dementia and their families.

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative Some individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities engage in self-injurious behavior (SIB), which can result in injuries, disfigurement, and loss of function (e.g., blindness). Our research on the least understood type of SIB showed it was actually comprised of subtypes, including some that did not respond well to currently available treatments. With further study, we gained insight into how the subtypes differed, pilot tested novel-treatment procedures, and are now positioned to conduct a clinical trial evaluating an intensive treatment approach targeting the most treatment- resistant subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Currently there are no proven therapies to treat recurrent GBM largely due to our inadequate molecular understanding of the disease. Glioma stem-cells (GSCs) are critical determinants of intra-tumor heterogeneity, tumor propagation, therapeutic resistance, and recurrence following treatment. It is therefore imperative that we understand the molecular mechanisms underlying GSC plasticity to design rational therapeutics aimed at stopping the conversion of non-GSCs to GSCs to limit intra-tumor heterogeneity, eliminate transitions between cellular states, and block the emergence of therapy-resistant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this research is to determine the mechanisms by which Treponema denticola interacts with host tissue in the oral environment and contributes to the dysregulation of host tissue homeostasis pathways that leads to periodontitis. The proposed studies will directly support this goal by characterizing specific mechanisms by which T. denticola interacts with host cell proteins that control key pathways required for maintenance of tissue homeostasis. Our research team, with demonstrated experience in genetic manipulation and functional assays of T. denticola behavior, as well as in fine-scale analysis of host cell and tissues responses, is uniquely qualified to conduct these studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac hypertrophy and myocardial oxidative stress are two major drivers of heart failure progression and both processes require the activity of Rac1, a small GTPase. Rac1 is known to undergo palmitoylation, a post- translational lipid modification that influences protein activity and localization, however the ability of this modification to control Rac1 signaling in the heart remains untested. This proposal seeks to determine the role of Rac1 palmitoylation in regulating cardiac hypertrophy and oxidative stress using both in vitro and in vivo approaches, thereby testing a novel regulatory mechanism of pathologic cardiac signaling that could potentially be targeted for the treatment of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE “Triple negative” breast cancer (TNBC) is a subtype of breast cancer that spreads aggressively and often leads to metastasis and death; it is difficult to treat because it does not respond to current molecularly-targeted drugs. TIMP2 is a natural human protein with two anticancer activities: (1) it inhibits an enzyme involved in TNBC metastasis, and (2) it binds to a cell surface receptor to inhibit TNBC growth. We propose to develop a new cancer drug, based on TIMP2, with improved capability to inhibit both metastasis and tumor growth, providing a new therapy to improve survival for patients with TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative As human teeth have limited regenerative potential, tooth loss is a common and chronic condition that can deeply affect our lifestyles. The continuously growing mouse incisor offers an ideal system to study dental stem cells and a thorough understanding of the molecular process that regulates tooth stem cells is crucial to efforts to develop stem cell-based therapies for regenerating human teeth. We propose to investigate the role of tissue architecture and forces during dental epithelial renewal in mice and the proposed study will be transformative because it will for the first time reveal how these physical factors are coordinated to control gene expression in epithelial stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secondary active transporters are essential components of cellular physiology. In humans, they are implicated in numerous diseases and are considered targets of active pharmaceutical interest. We aim to structurally resolve human sugar transporters with medical relevance in type II diabetes, microbial infections, and other conditions related to sugar transport and metabolism. These structural studies will be complemented using spectroscopy, advanced X-ray scattering and Molecular Dynamics simulations in an effort to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of sugar transporter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Therapies that target tumor architecture (e.g., the stroma compartment) have proven efficacy in preclinical studies and have led to ongoing clinical trials. This is the proof-of-concept of the existence of tissue-specific properties that regulate tumor architecture during tumor progression and in response to chemotherapy. Our proposed study aims to identify the mechanisms that regulate tumor tissue homeostasis (i.e., multicellular dynamics) to find novel therapeutic strategies for patients with pancreatic cancer (PDAC), to define the role of tumor architecture in PDAC chemoresistance, and to discover new biomarkers to predict the response to multi- agent chemotherapy (i.e., FOLFIRINOX).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The glymphatic and lymphatic systems control fluid and waste disposal from the central nervous system, and are therefore pivotal for sustaining a healthy brain. However, the functional interplay between the glymphatic and lymphatic systems has been technically difficult to study. Consequently, targeting optimization of the functional cross-talk of the two systems for potential health benefits are still under-investigated. Our goal is to characterize the mechanisms regulating the glymphatic/lymphatic system coupling by introducing unique imaging, computational fluid dynamics analysis, and lymph “omics”. Successful completion of our studies will determine the physiological drivers of glymphatic/lymphatic coupling and fast-forward testing of beneficial alternative approaches based on posture and respiratory manipulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: The use of fetal bovine serum (FBS) to support cell growth is challenged by variability, limited supply, viral contaminants, and ethical questions. We propose to reduce FBS use by identifying the growth factors (GFs) that stimulate retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cell growth. These GFs will be encapsulated in a controlled-release GF microbead product for serum-free RPE cell research and manufacture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Poly polymerase inhibitor drugs (PARPi's) have emerged as important new therapeutic agents targeting a broadening class of gene mutations present in breast, ovarian, prostate and a host of other cancers. To further the development, clinical translation, and commercialization of [18F]Fluorthanatrace ([18F]FTT), a PET tracer of PARP1 expression and drug binding, we propose an Academic Industrial Partnership (AIP) comprised of The University of Pennsylvania (lead academic partner), MD Anderson Cancer Center, and Washington University with Trevarx Biomedical, Inc. The proposed effort by the AIP will generate elements to design and implement a pivotal Phase 3 trial for [18F]FTT FDA approval, as well as support [18F]FTT commercial supply and ongoing/future research evaluating the value of [18F]FTT PET/CT for guiding PARP inhibitor treatment to the benefit of many cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Atherosclerosis is initiated and promoted by the arterial accumulation of apolipoprotein B (apoB)-containing lipoproteins which activate a chronic inflammatory response. Our group recently made the novel discovery that a key blood clot lysis protein, tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), in hepatocytes limits the production of apoB-lipoproteins in mice and cultured human primary hepatocytes. The overarching objective of this proposal is to explore the underlying mechanisms by which hepatocyte tPA lowers plasma apoB-containing lipoprotein- cholesterol levels, and thereby alleviates atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ulcerative colitis (UC) is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affecting over 1 million people in the United States and its incidence is increasing. Our study addresses the challenge of identifying preclinical human IBD mechanisms and focuses on the role of the protein Sam68 as a critical mediator of tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and toll like receptor (TLR) induced inflammation in UC. Successful completion of this study will reveal Sam68 as a key player in UC pathogenesis and lead to the design of novel therapeutics targeting Sam68 for chronic inflammatory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leptin resistance is thought to be a major contributor to obesity, but its mechanisms are poorly understood. Deletion of LRP1, an endocytic receptor and putative effector of leptin transcytosis, in the choroid plexus epithelium replicates aspects of leptin resistance, suggesting leptin transcytosis through the choroid plexus as a potential bottleneck in leptin-mediated suppression of feeding. The focus of this proposal is to quantitatively dissect the role of choroid plexus transcytosis in mediating the CNS effects of leptin and to consider leptin transcytosis as a novel target for treatments of obesity and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: In 2019, over 1.7 million Americans will be diagnosed with cancer, and among the innumerable rigors associated with the diagnosis and its treatment, perhaps the greatest source of suffering is pain. Hypnosis has been shown to be a clinically efficacious and cost-effective nonpharmacologic intervention for pain, but few cancer care providers are trained in its use. The goal of the proposed R25E is to train cancer care providers in hypnosis to manage pain across the cancer continuum, so that providers may skillfully and competently deliver hypnosis to reduce the pain burden of their patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Social challenges are a major issue for young adult cancer patients (18-39 years old). Impairments in social relationships, referred to as social health, may decrease physical activity after a cancer diagnosis, leading to poorer quality of life after treatment and recovery. This study will investigate the relationships between social health, physical activity, and quality of life to expand our understanding of their interrelations to inform intervention strategies to foster healthy survivorship for young adult cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance Mediterranean-type diet has been increasingly identified as playing an important role in preventing Alzheimer’s disease and cognitive decline in the elderly, but the mechanisms remain unclear. Several reserve concepts, including brain reserve, brain maintenance, and cognitive reserve, collectively explain individual differences in cognition, function or clinical status relative to aging and brain disease. In this proposal, using data from two well-established imaging cohorts we will examine the respect roles of brain reserve, brain maintenance, and cognitive reserve in cognitive benefits of Mediterranean-type diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Centrioles and centrosomes are ubiquitous and ancient macromolecular structures that are altered both in cancer cells and Trisomy 21 cells from individuals with Down syndrome. Our current research aims to understand the control mechanisms that centrioles and centrosomes exert on primary and motile cilia. We will illuminate fundamental events that contribute to cancer and Down syndrome and future studies will test whether these events are promising targets for therapeutics.

This study will give broad insights into the basis for neuropsychiatric disorders such as intellectual disability, autism and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Changing contraceptive patterns, specifically the decline of oral contraceptives and rise intrauterine devices, could have important implications for future ovarian cancer risk. Leveraging data from 24 population-based studies including more than 700,000 women (>20,000 cases) as well as ovarian cancer tissue (>3,000) to examine local immune mechanisms with cutting-edge multiplex immunofluorescence technology, we will evaluate how this highly prevalent and modifiable risk factor may impact the population burden of this extremely fatal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Disturbances in visual perception are highly prevalent in psychotic disorders and deficits in the processing of stimulus contrast have been linked to cognitive deficits and functional decline in chronic schizophrenia. The integrity of this mechanism, however, remains understudied at disease onset and our understanding of its modulation by coordinated yet broadly distributed cognitive systems in psychosis is lacking, limiting our attempts to target primary sources of disease morbidity. This project will examine the neural basis of visual perceptual modulation and its association with clinical impairment at first-episode psychosis to inform targeted treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At this time, policy makers and health insurers are actively exploring covering Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction, but are not equipped with recent evidence syntheses to aid those decisions. These systematic reviews and meta-analyses, done in partnership with knowledge users, will provide the needed evidence for sound decisions and demonstrate knowledge gaps for researchers to fill. Overall, this project will provide evidence syntheses that could transform Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction health insurance coverage and access for millions of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 5-methylcytosine oxidase activity of TET proteins is critical for controlling DNA methylation patterns and gene expression, yet the mechanisms by which TET activity itself is regulated are completely unknown. We recently discovered that the protein SMCHD1 is a negative regulator of TET activity, and that SMCHD1 depletion activates gene networks that have been linked to an incurable form of muscular dystrophy. The objective of this project is to understand how SMCHD1 interacts with and controls TET-mediated epigenetic function in normal embryonic development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative To improve T cell based immunotherapy, it is necessary to understand how the local metabolic milieu impedes the multiple-step process of target cell recognition and killing. We pursue a causal chain connecting three metabolic pathways to mitochondrial function and serial killing in chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells. We will also determine the importance of extracellular fructose—which is upregulated in some tumor microenvironments—on tumor immune reactivity and response to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Our studies are directly relevant to the missions of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development and, in particular, research into reproduction, contraception, and population control because transforming growth factor β (TGFβ) superfamily signaling pathways play essential roles in a diversity of developmental and pathophysiological processes including reproductive disorders. Our studies will improve the reproductive health of women, better the quality-of-life of women and their offspring, improve the diagnosis and treatment of reproductive health conditions, including infertility, endometriosis, and preeclampsia, and advance the development of better contraceptive therapies for women. The objectives of this R01 renewal are to mechanistically define the TGFβ family-SMAD-mediated signaling in the ovary, during pregnancy and in maternal diseases and to uncover new drugs for interrogating the functions of BMPs, activins, myostatin, and GDF11 for treatments of clinically important reproductive and non-reproductive diseases.

PHR: Narrative Dr. Kim is an active and vital leader in the clinical trials program at The University of Michigan Rogel Cancer Center whose extensive, collaborative work has supported the NCI clinical trials infrastructure institutionally and nationally. Her major contributions institutionally include serving as Co-Chair of the Neuro-Oncology Clinical Research Team, active member of the Cancer Center Protocol Review Committee, and nationally as the Co-Chair of the NIH/NCI Brain Metastases Interest Group and active member of the NRG Oncology and Alliance Brain Tumor Committees. Through this Research Specialist Award opportunity, she will grow her institutional and national leadership contributions in support of NCI clinical trials research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The legalization of cannabis products has led to an increase in the self-medication of medicinal marijuana by users who believe cannabis to be “perfectly safe”, notwithstanding the impact cannabis components have on neuronal development. This project explores the modulation of CB1 cannabinoid receptor (CB1R) by its cellular protein partner Cannabinoid Receptor Interacting Protein 1a (CRIP1a), a protein associated with defects in neurosensory development and schizophrenia. Understanding the biochemistry of CRIP1a and its interaction with and mechanism of regulation of CB1R is essential for understanding the impact of cannabis usage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery that FFA4 stimulation improves beta cell function by a combination of delta cell-dependent and beta cell-autonomous mechanisms represent additive or synergistic ways to leverage local feedback as a novel way to treat patients with type 2 diabetes. Moreover, these mechanism complement existing treatment paradigms. Thus the proposed research is relevant to NIDDK's mission because it directly addresses a critical unmet need to improve the health and quality of life of the millions of Americans with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Proper control of the activity of resident stem/progenitor cells is important for building or regenerating a functional tissue. Too much self-renewal and proliferation may cause cancer, whereas failure to maintain stem/progenitor cells or undergo terminal differentiation will result in the inability to generate or sustain the desired tissue and lead to diseases. The proposed studies will help us understand how tissue epithelial stem/progenitor cell activities are regulated by factors within and outside of the stem cells, and may implicate new knowledge of cancer cell dormancy and molecular targets for treating diseases such as breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In response to the RFA-CA-20-027, we propose to conduct a Type 1 hybrid effectiveness-implementation trial to assess the effectiveness of a 4-session synchronous digital health insurance navigation intervention compared to 1) enhanced usual care and 2) an asynchronous delivery of the digital health insurance navigation intervention in promoting health insurance literacy among 520 survivors from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (survivors diagnosed before the age of 21). A rigorous implementation evaluation will be conducted, which will leverage our objective to establish a sustainable intervention to improve health outcomes of childhood cancer survivors through enhanced health insurance literacy and decreased financial hardship.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We propose to conduct transformative research aimed at elucidating the fundamental neural mechanisms underlying functional brain organization, connectivity and global brain dynamics. Our studies will bridge critical gaps in our knowledge by linking non-invasive fMRI measurements with its underlying cellular and neural-circuit organization. The proposed studies have significant public health impact as they focus on cognitive control circuits impacted in a wide range of brain disorders, which calls for innovative integrated experimental and computational approaches to the understanding of brain function and dysfunction. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of death in the U.S., disproportionately impacts persons of lower socioeconomic position (SEP) -- a disparity that has been attributed to heightened exposures to both traffic- related air pollution (TRAP) and chronic social stressors, in communities of lower SEP. We will test the hypotheses that: (1) TRAP composition (light- vs. heavy-duty vehicles) differentially influences cardiovascular function; (2) chronic stress may heighten animals’ cardiovascular response to TRAP; and (3) TRAP may compromise animals’ cardiovascular resilience to stress challenge. Using animal models to separate these synergies, we will directly inform on biologically-grounded epidemiologic model structure, realistic space-time exposure measures for both stress and pollution, and help guide policy towards identifying susceptible populations, improving health, clarifying safe air pollution concentrations, and reducing health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Central blood pressure is proven to be more valuable for cardiovascular disease management than the blood pressure commonly measured on the arm. However, current approaches for measuring central blood pressure are limited by either invasiveness, inaccuracy, or intermittency. This research project aims to develop a fully- integrated wearable ultrasonic device that allows automatic monitoring of central blood pressure in a noninvasive, accurate, and continuous manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: A central goal of neurobiology is to reveal how the brain generates and organizes action, but we lack sophisticated tools for objectively and comprehensively characterizing behavior. We have developed a next- generation method called Motion Sequencing (MoSeq) that affords unprecedented insight into how the brain organizes behavior; however, using this approach requires substantial expertise, which has slowed its adoption by the scientific community. Here we propose to streamline and package the underlying code, and to offer hands-on training, so that users without extensive computer science or math backgrounds can easily use MoSeq to characterize animal behavior as part of efforts to understand how genes, drugs or neural activity changes action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic candidiasis, mainly caused by the opportunistic yeast Candida albicans, is the fourth leading cause of nosocomial bloodstream infection in the US and worldwide. The innate immune response is critical for host defense against invasive candidiasis. This application aims to determine C. albicans proteins that govern Candida-immune cell interaction and Candida pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social interaction recognition is central to humans’ daily lives and highly relevant to NIMH as the ability to perceive and interpret social interactions is characteristically disrupted in autism. Despite its ubiquity and clinical relevance, the brain basis of social interaction recognition remains poorly understood. The proposed research will 1) uncover the neural computations underlying different aspects of social interaction recognition (from visual to high-level), and 2) formalize large-scale studies of social interaction recognition, paving the way for a rigorous examination of these abilities in typical and atypical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed work examines changes in plastic potential of the visual system with time from stroke affecting primary visual cortex. We will measure structural and mechanistic aspects of progressive degeneration along the early visual pathways, correlating them with changes in visual performance and responsiveness to visual restoration training in the blind field. This project will advance both scientific knowledge, as well as technical capability and clinical practices for restoring vision and quality of life for people suffering from cortical blindness.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the University of Kentucky Neuroscience Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program (UKNeu-PREP) is to serve individuals from underrepresented and disadvantaged backgrounds from under- graduate institutions without substantive research opportunities. The realization of this mission is the develop- ment of a diverse pool of well-trained postbaccalaureate participants that transition into strong, neuroscience and research-focused higher degree doctoral programs. A diverse scientific community and workforce are vital for increasing the quality of higher education, medicine (including reducing health care disparities), scientific research, and technological innovation to solve health-related problems and challenges.

The program will enhance the professional growth of health professionals and academic researchers through the strengthening of competence to conduct health research studies with high ethical standards and scientific rigor. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antiretroviral drugs can inhibit HIV infection but cannot eliminate all the infected cells in the body that hide from the immune system. In order to cure HIV, we need to develop methods that accurately quantify the number of infected cells that remain hidden and explore treatments focused around natural killer cells that effectively target these HIV-infected cells. This project has scientific and public health relevance by deepening our understanding of how HIV remains hidden and ultimately uses this knowledge to develop curative strategies that focus around engineering natural killer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety and anatomical sex represent major risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), with females being more susceptible than males. This K99/R00 proposal will first identify the impact of anxiety and anatomical sex on the neural ensembles mediating memory loss in a mouse model of AD and then use optogenetic techniques to rescue cognitive decline following AD development. Identifying the circuits underlying co-morbid anxiety and cognitive decline in female AD mice will provide the building blocks for specific and personalized therapeutic targets for females suffering from AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) has an etiologic role in several human cancers. KSHV infects tumor cells and persists in these cells in a latent state. This work investigates the mechanisms this virus uses to allow it to be maintained in cells since a better understanding of these mechanisms may allow development of strategies which prevent KSHV cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The one-carbon metabolism pathway plays a plausible role in the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in persons with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This proposal is designed to test the hypotheses that (1) inherited genetic variants, (2) acquired modifications to DNA, and (3) metabolic molecules of the one-carbon pathway play significant roles in HCC development in persons with NAFLD. Findings from this research are expected to improve strategies for prevention, risk assessment and stratification, and early detection of HCC, an often fatal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this study is to investigate how a family of myelin transcription factors regulates islet beta cell function and survival. The significance is that humans need to maintain fully functional beta cells to avoid debilitating hypoglycemia or diabetes. We expect to uncover basic molecular and cellular mechanisms to help improve the regulation of this mass to avoid these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we investigate a synthetic noncoding RNA molecule, TY4, bioinspired by the contents of extracellular vesicles. Preliminary data indicate TY4 is cardioprotective when administered orally or intravenously after ischemia/reperfusion. The studies will advance our mechanistic understanding of cardioprotection, while constituting an important translational step towards the development of a novel, orally-bioavailable agent adjunctive to reperfusion therapy for myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known regarding the etiology of mitral valve prolapse (MVP), one of the most common diseases, affecting 1 in 40 individuals. Uncovering the genetic causes for this disease will provide key insight into mechanisms that contribute to valve development and allow us to study why MVP happens. Based on our genetic, developmental and molecular discoveries, our goal for this proposal is to examine new mechanisms for valvular development and their link to the pathogenesis of cardiac valve diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With repeated opioid use, a driving factor for drug taking becomes the desire to avoid the aversive state of withdrawal, instead of the acute rewarding effects of the drug. However, it is not clear how chronic opioid use alters neural circuits involved in aversion processing to initiate and sustain this aversive withdrawal state. The goal of this project is to understand how chronic opioid use induces plasticity in brain circuits involved in aversion processing, and how these changes drive the aversive state of opioid withdrawal; outcomes of this project will ultimately inform targeted therapies in the treatment of drug withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding new roles for natural reward circuitry is a vital first step to understand the reward circuitry perturbed in addiction. This project aims to understand how discrete environmental cues integrate with natural rewards to change their subjective value. This can serve to explain why reward seeking is enhanced and persistent in certain environments, as occurs during drug addiction and relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Overuse of medications commonly prescribed for headache management can result in a contradictory increase in pain sensitivity, known as medication overuse headache. Our lab has identified two novel targets that block this medication exaggerated pain – the delta opioid receptor and the PACAP-PAC1 receptor. The aim of this proposal is to determine if these two targets commonly interact to inhibit medication overuse headache.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Traumatic brain injury causes damage and functional deficits associated with the site of injury, but also can affect afferent neurons that project to the injured regions from distal locations, affecting their ability to function properly and possibly causing them to degenerate. Basal forebrain cholinergic neurons, which project throughout the cortex, play a major role in many cognitive functions and are particularly vulnerable to degeneration in Alzheimer’s disease and other cognitive impairments. To understand the full scope of damage resulting from TBI, and to develop therapeutic approaches to minimize the consequences of the brain injury, we will investigate how damage to the cortex affects afferent neurons that project to the injured target, and whether they undergo degenerative changes as a consequence of the injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Hippo pathway is an evolutionarily conserved developmental pathway that controls organ size and tissue homeostasis in all metazoan animals. Dysregulated Hippo pathway has been implicated in a wide range of human disorders, including cancer. Despite the well-established Hippo pathway core signaling cascade, the upstream regulation of the Hippo pathway is less understood. This proposal aims to provide novel mechanistic understanding of how Hippo pathway upstream signals are coordinated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health White matter ischemia causes sensory and motor impairments and dementia. This grant identifies cellular and molecular mechanisms of white matter repair in white matter ischemia.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a major cause of death and disability among both civilians and military personnel, with about 1.4 million TBI’s occurring each year in the U.S. For military personnel, between 14-20% of surviving casualties had a TBI. Studies proposed investigate chronic effects of closed head brain injury, including cognitive decline and early-onset dementia. This work may lead to a new strategy for improving chronic outcomes after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative  This project is directed to developing a novel skin-safe hand wash product that will significantly decrease the C. difficile spore levels on hands (>3.5 log reduction) compared to traditional soap and water hand wash which is marginally effective (1-2 log reduction), and to alcohol based hand sanitizers which are entirely ineffective. The anticipated product is based on a new class of microstructured fluid that is highly functional in removing spores and pathogens from skin by a cardinally new mechanism of action. The product is expected to provide a robust solution to prevent transmission of C. difficile and hospital-acquired infections (HAI) in healthcare and community facilities, with additional potential applications in patient bathing and skin treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The role of mitochondrial type 1 ryanodine receptor in the regulation of cardiac function and energetics during the progression of cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure remains unknown. This proposal intends to fill this knowledge gap by using several mouse models to gain mechanistic insights into its regulatory role in cardiac function under healthy and failing heart. The findings from the proposed studies will provide novel insight for developing new therapeutic strategy to ameliorate cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this proposed research is to leverage unique features of a new animal model to study fundamental principles of neural systems, the integration of newborn neurons into functioning networks, and regeneration following injury. With this tiny, transparent organism, it is possible to examine cell migration, axon outgrowth and retraction, and the functional activity of the entire network simultaneously across the whole organism, in vivo, using genetically encoded optical techniques. Moving forward, these high-resolution studies will generate new theories and approaches towards understanding how nervous systems generate animal behavior, mechanisms linking neurogenesis to system function, and insights into novel regenerative capabilities.

PHR: The Emotional Well-Being and Economic Burden (EMOT-ECON) Research Network will bring together leading scientists across disciplines and institutions to understand how, and through which mechanisms, the economic burden of disease (e.g., due to costs of care and productivity losses) impacts emotional well-being. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes to establish a “visible” machine learning framework that systematically understands and efficiently maps higher-order genetic interactions (i.e. di-genic and tri-genic interactions) in cancer. Investigation of higher-order genetic interactions is critical for designing treatments that precisely target the genetic changes in individual cancer patients. Understanding the complex interplay among genes can further lead to effective design of combinatorial therapeutic solutions that maximize the synergy among treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Detection of pre-symptomatic Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is difficult to distinguish from typical aging; testing is expensive and invasive. We recently found that functional electroencephalography (fEEG) may detect individuals with pathological amyloid/tau level and higher risk of cognitive decline through conscious, subliminal, and autonomic (CSA) system evaluation. This project will also put to the test how well these new findings will predict who will or will not decline in a period of 2 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Determining whether a patient is both feeling better and improving physiologically when treating people living with HIV (PLWH) for methamphetamine use disorder (MUD) requires identification of a clinically significant measure separate from abstinence. My proposed K01 activities open the exciting opportunity to address this challenge by testing a gene expression pattern identified by the field of social genomics, which may provide insight into both psychosocial health and biological processes that impact chronic disease risk in PLWH receiving MUD treatment. Support from this K01 will facilitate my training in transcriptomics, clinical trial methods, and ethical/culturally competent practices, all of which will help me achieve my long-term career goal—to be a leading researcher of biomarker assessment tools for PLWH receiving addiction treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor muscle function is a pressing public health problem as half of all U.S. older adults meet criteria for muscle weakness. The goal of this proposal is to identify which features of the neighborhood environment are related to muscle function, physical activity and mitochondrial health in older adults. This study’s findings will enhance our understanding of what social and biologic risk factors matter most for muscle function and could be targets for future interventions.
