IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative (Relevance) Hypoxia is one of the most important features of the tumor microenvironment (TME) that leads to decreased sensitivity of tumor cells and poor therapeutic effects. We developed unique tools using engineered probiotic tumor-homing bacteria to selectively express cancer-killing proteins under the hypoxic environment. In combination with chemotherapeutic agents, our new probiotic bacteria-assisted approach will potentially provide effective treatment strategies that specifically target the hypoxic TME which is difficult by current therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils, a class of white blood cells that combat bacteria, can become overactive when fighting overwhelming infection in a condition called sepsis, releasing anti-bacteria compounds that contribute to life- threatening organ damage. I propose a new therapy that neutralizes these dangerous compounds without interfering with neutrophils’ ability to control infections. My goal is to further understand how this strategy works and to bring it to patient care to improve survival in sepsis and other conditions complicated by neutrophil-related inflammation, such as sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Patients with metastatic lung cancer receive standard chemo, radiation, and immune therapy. However, treatment resistance occurs in over 70% of the cases. Solid tumors suppress the immune system preventing effective systemic responses. We have found that tumors from unrelated donors fail to establish in new hosts because the immune system attacks unrelated tissue. Similarly, matched tissue type cancer injected with pooled antibodies plus an activator of the immune system can cause the eradication of tumors. We plan to use this immune activation strategy in a safety trial. Unrelated antibodies and an immune activator will be injected in a first-in- human single-center study Harnessing Allo-Immunity To Enhance Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors (HAITEN-ICI) in veterans with metastatic lung cancer who failed standard cancer treatment. We will evaluate the safety of this intervention and if safe, will be expanded to a randomized study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The relationship between adipose tissue and its resident lymphatic vasculature is complex and bidirectional. While defective lymphatic function, as seen in lymphedema, promotes fat deposition, obesity, conversely, compromises lymphatic flow. By exploring lymphatic endothelial cell communication with other adipose tissue cell types, this proposal aims to improve our understanding of how the lymphatic system contributes to adipocyte biology and overall metabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Despite age-related hearing and vision deficits, some older adults can identify audiovisual speech as accurately as their younger counterparts. This research project takes a novel neural-systems approach, integrating measures of neural function with structure, to characterize the age-related changes in cross-modal plasticity, multisensory integration, and frontal-cortical modulation of sensory input that may conserve the audiovisual speech perception of older adults. The findings may identify new targets for intervention to improve the communicative abilities of older adults with hearing and vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sleep and circadian rhythms, our 24-hour internal biological clock, are essential to human well-being and patient recovery, however current modifiable practices in intensive care units (ICU) are not optimized to support sleep or preserve circadian rhythms of patients. Among the contributing factors is the common practice of administering nutrition support through feeding tubes or intravenously overnight. Thus, using noninvasive and scalable monitoring technologies, we propose to determine whether modifying the timing of nutrition support from the current standard of overnight feeding to daytime feeding may enhance sleep quality, preserve circadian rhythms, and improve overall inflammation and cardiometabolic profiles in postoperative patients in the cardiac surgical ICU on enteral nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Errors in the genome can often give rise to plethora of genetic diseases, including cancer and neurodegeneration and, in recent years, the CRISPR-Cas9 complex has emerged as promising genome editing machinery to treat a myriad of human genetic diseases as shown for the first cancer patients treated with CRISPR-Cas9–modified T-cells. This prosed research will leverage state-of-the-art computational methods to answer critical biophysical questions and foster improved applications of the CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing technology. Understanding the fundamental functional behaviour of this complex is of utmost importance to ameliorate safety and efficacy for clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the number one cause of mortality in the United States, with different etiologies of heart failure associated with distinct changes in mitochondrial substrate selection, utilization, and gene expression mediating these differences. Here we test the hypothesis that one family of kinases that regulate this process (i.e., PDKs) play distinct roles in mortality, cardiac hypertrophy, mitochondrial oxidative metabolism, and signaling to transcriptional pathways in the nucleus mediated by epigenetics (i.e., histone acetylation). We have developed new animal model systems of inducible and cardiomyocyte specific loss-of-function mice of the two cardiac enriched isoforms of this pathway (i.e., PDK2 and PDK4) to determine the mechanism of this regulation and test the potential of their isoform-specific impact on pressure-overload induced heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

PHR: Project Narrative: Cocaine use disorder is a leading cause of drug overdose hospitalizations with no available FDA approved medication. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Genome instability, including changes in DNA sequence and chromosome structure, is associated with cancer, birth defects, and neurological and developmental disorders. This project uses genetics and cell biology in a simple yeast to study how cells protect their DNA to ensure faithful transmission of the genetic information. This organism uses many of the same genes as humans for this vital task, allowing us to investigate molecular mechanisms and identify proteins that preserve chromosome stability and prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding genome-wide patterns of genetic variation among individuals and how this relates to complex diseases is one of the primary goals of modern medical research. The proposed research will contribute to this goal by tackling a number of open problems in such a way that a coherent statistical framework and set of methodologies will emerge that can be applied to data sets of genome-wide genetic variation to produce a clearer picture of the genetic basis of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis use is known to alleviate common symptoms and complications in PWH on cART but its effect on neurocognition is not clear. With the use of in vivo calcium imaging the goal of the proposed study is to determine cannabis-induced changes on neuronal activity in a neuroHIV mouse model during performance of a behavioral appetitive learning task and its relation to the endocannabinoid system. This work will advance the understanding of cannabis use in the context of neuroHIV and may lead to new cannabinoid therapeutic strategies for recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The development of effective strategies to deliver therapeutic macromolecules will benefit from biologically inspired solutions already employed by cells to achieve this goal. This proposal aims to define matrimeres as a novel class of cell-secreted nanoparticles that deliver extracellular matrix molecules to the host after tissue injury and treat vascular leakage. Success of the proposed studies will inform new nanomedicine that can be leveraged to promote regeneration of vascularized tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The high level of HIV variability and the polymorphic nature of MHC-Ia alleles are major challenges to the development of a broadly effective CTL-based vaccine. This proposal aims to overcome these obstacles by leveraging the conserved MHC-1b allele HLA-E and mutation-resistant HLA-E-restricted CTL epitopes in a rationally designed, therapeutic CTL-based vaccine for HIV. Thus, the proposed work is relevant to the NIH’s mission to seek and apply knowledge to lengthen life and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This application aims to develop and evaluate a usable patient medical summary (PMS) imported from the state-wide community Indiana Health Information Exchange (IHIE) that updates a dental clinician about their patients’ medical history and can be used even in solo- and small-group dental practice settings. The two primary outcomes are reducing dental clinicians’ (DCs) reliance on patients and physicians’ office for information that delays treatment and reducing patients’ burden to share information with DCs. The proposed study will lay the foundation for bidirectional communication between dental and medical professionals that enhances dental and overall care among the US population, promotes preventive management, and reduces dental care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is one of the most powerful diagnostic tools available in clinics. However, the recent rising concern about the toxicity of gadolinium-based contrast agents has lead to renewed interest in finding alternatives. This project proposes to develop a new class of metal-free MRI contrast agents based on biocompatible and biostable organic triarylmethyl radicals.

PHR: NARRATIVE If successful, this proposal will significantly advance our understanding of how hypoxia, hypoxia-driven pathways, and bioenergetic metabolism control somitogenesis. The successful accomplishment of the experimental plan described in this proposal may identify the transcription factors HIF-1alpha and HIF2-alpha as novel regulators of somitogenesis. This knowledge could provide novels insights into the pathogenetic mechanisms underlying both Spondylocostal Dysostosis and Congenital Scoliosis due to gestational hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism represent a significant and growing healthcare and economic burden to the United States, yet effective pharmacological therapies for these debilitating conditions remain limited. We propose to apply a range of diverse neuroscience approaches to characterize a newly discovered role for a unique class of non-neuronal brain cells, oligodendrocyte precursor cells, in a late stage of postnatal brain development that goes awry in neurodevelopmental disorders. We expect the proposed studies to lay the groundwork for new therapeutic strategies aimed at manipulating oligodendrocyte precursor cell function early in life to correct the neurobiological deficits that underlie neurodevelopmental disorders, thereby ameliorating their symptoms across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: WONHWA CHO, PH.D. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Lipid signaling is an important target for drug development for diverse human diseases, including cancer. Based on our recent research showing that membrane lipids directly and specifically control cellular activities of diverse proteins that are critically involved in cancer, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms underlying complex lipid-mediated cell regulation and develop drugs targeting lipid- protein binding interfaces. Given the general and fundamental importance of lipid signaling, our pioneering, innovative research should have major impact on broad areas of biology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health This project will develop an open source suite of software for the processing, analysis, and visualization of rodent brain imaging data, which will enhance the ability of neuroscience researchers to perform preclinical studies on rodent models. This software will provide advanced capabilities for analyzing multimodal imaging data, including imagery from magnetic resonance imaging and optical microscopy studies, with the goal of improving understanding of processes and mechanisms underlying neurological diseases and disorders and their potential treatment. The software will include interactive processing to facilitate ease of use, as well as command line tools to enable large scale processing for larger studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a developing embryo, all cells must acquire appropriate fates, including germ cells, which make eggs and sperm and are thus absolutely required for reproduction and species survival. This proposal will uncover the mechanisms that ensure that germ cells acquire their fates correctly by virtue of special cytoplasmic aggregates, which are similar to aggregates that regulate other types of cell fates in many somatic cells. Thus, the experiments proposed here will shed light both on how cells like germ cells are normally specified, and on why mutations in the genes encoding the molecular components of the cytoplasmic aggregates can lead to human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our chromosomes are intricately organized in the nuclei of our cells, and the principles underlying this organization are important to understand since perturbations can cause disease. Here we propose to study the function of a protein, called Ldb1, that our prior work suggests to be a critical chromosomal organizer in red blood cell precursors. We will examine how Ldb1 contributes to chromosome folding and regulation of gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The immune suppressive tumor microenvironment in glioblastoma (GBM) contributes to the failure of immune checkpoint blockers (ICBs). By reprogramming the GBM microenvironment using Wnt-inhibitor and losartan, our project will i) provide unprecedented insights into the mechanisms of response and resistance to combined Wnt signaling inhibition and αPD1, and ii) utilize losartan, a safe, inexpensive and widely prescribed angiotensin receptor blocker, to alleviate edema and resistance to this combination and thereby improve outcome of ICBs in GBM. If successful, our results will inform the design – and catalyze the initiation – of clinical trials in GBM patients to improve the outcome of ICBs using agents currently in clinical trials for non-CNS tumors (WNT974: e.g., NCT01351103; and losartan: NCT03563248).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Over the course of a lifetime, 20% of adults in the United States will experience mental illness. Many neuropsychiatric disorders are characterized by dysregulation of affective or motivated circuits in the brain, both of which are highly sensitive to endogenous opioid signaling. Here, we seek to leverage next-generation, opioid specific technologies to determine the biological and computational function of endogenous opioids in regulating motivated behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to identify the distinct functional clusters of anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), an addiction hub in the brain, during attention deployment in nicotine addiction. Successful completion of this work will provide the evidence of the neural basis of addiction-derived attention alternations, leading to novel insights into the neurophysiological foundation of the addiction-related network interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Though any single rare disease is by definition uncommon, together these diseases affect nearly 30 million individuals in the United States, two-thirds of whom are children, and contribute significantly to morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. Exome and whole genome sequencing have the potential to provide a diagnosis to an estimated 25 to 50 percent of those patients struggling with undiagnosed rare diseases, but the downstream costs and benefits of this testing beyond diagnosis remain largely unknown. This study will contribute essential and timely data, new methods, and ethical analyses to inform both how we can, and how we should, define and measure the value of genome sequencing for pediatric patients with rare diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several aspects of the early stages of HIV-1 infection remain poorly understood. Our recent work identified two new classes of host co-factors that bind HIV-1 capsids through distinct strategies, including one that uses a previously undescribed recognition strategy that we hypothesize supports HIV-1 metastability and is an evolutionary driver for HIV-1's use of less conventional motor adaptors. This proposal will employ cutting-edge cryoEM, biochemical and functional approaches to test this hypothesis and understand how these factors engage the HIV-1 core to control early infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Arsenic is the most pervasive environmental toxin and carcinogen in the United States, causing cardiovascular and peripheral vascular diseases, neurological disorders, diabetes mellitus and various forms of cancer such as skin and bladder cancer. The overarching theme of this long-standing project is both a comprehensive and in depth understanding of the biology of arsenic, and, in this application we propose to elucidate the genes, enzymes, transporters and mechanisms in the pathways of arsenic biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative The Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic created disruptions in usual medical care delivery that could have devastating downstream effects. Older adults living in rural areas experience worse health outcomes than their urban counterparts, and may be particularly vulnerable to care disruption, particularly if they also live in poverty or are members of racial or ethnic minority groups. In this project, we seek to understand the magnitude and clinical impact of COVID-related clinical care disruption, with a focus on vulnerable rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will further knowledge about the cardiovascular risks, clinical predictors and molecular markers that drive nocturnal blood pressure dysregulation (nocturnal hypertension and non-dipper status) in children with proteinuric glomerulopathies. The long-term goal is to guide prevention and treatment for nocturnal blood pressure dysregulation to meaningfully improve cardiovascular disease outcomes in children with proteinuric glomerulopathies. The precision medicine approach employed in this study provides an individualized, patient-oriented approach to nocturnal blood pressure dysregulation, which is critical for the prevention of future cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in these high-risk children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in myosin binding protein-C (MyBP-C), a muscle regulatory protein, are increasingly linked to congenital skeletal muscle diseases including those that cause clubfoot and familial tremors, but the role of MyBP-C in normal muscle function and the mechanism(s) by which mutations cause disease remain poorly understood. Here, we describe a new approach developed exclusively in the PI’s lab that will allow us for the first time to selectively modify MyBP-C in working muscles in real time. Results from this study will provide critical insights into how MyBP-C regulates muscle function and how mutations cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant microstructural changes occur in the brain years before clinical manifestation of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, there is gap in reliable and sensitive in vivo measurement of early molecular and microstructural changes in prodromal AD. We will integrate advanced quantitative MRI markers of gray and white matter microstructural changes, network neuroscience, and longitudinal outcomes to examine subtle changes in brain microstructure in preclinical AD in association with AD pathology and cognitive decline, and to further improve our mechanistic understanding of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases, including cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure, are among the leading causes of morbidity and mortality, and are responsible for significant healthcare costs in the USA. This study seeks to identify the mechanisms of cellular calcium regulation that sustain the pump function of the heart, and to identify the disturbances and dysregulations of calcium signaling that lead to arrhythmias of the atria in the etiopathology of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Virus resistance remains the central vulnerability of effective bnAb use in HIV. This application proposes to address the problem of bNAb resistance by rationally selecting combination bNAb therapy that limits virus escape. Our scientific premise is that in vivo mapping of virus escape from bNAbs, identification of complementary bNAbs, defining the role of autologous antibodies, and rigorous in vivo testing in an authentic NHP model will elucidate basic mechanisms of virus resistance to bNAbs and inform more effective use of bNAbs across the HIV prevention, treatment and cure fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE β-Cell dysfunction and depletion are pathologic features of diabetes. A regenerative therapeutic strategy for diabetes, while promising in principle, is contingent upon successful development a method for selectively targeting replication-promoting compounds to the β-cell. The extraordinary power of medicinal chemistry and a rigorous experimental interrogation cascade will be leveraged to deliver a β-cell-selective regenerative compound and define the chemical/genetic “rules” that govern β-cell selective drug delivery based upon their unique biologic properties.

PHR: Project Narrative DNMT3A is a protein that is critical for proper differentiation of blood cells, and mutations of DNMT3A are commonly associated with a variety of blood disorders. Here, we propose to study the mechanisms through which DNMT3A works and how the mutations affect its function. The long-term goal is to find new strategies to treat blood disorders associated with DNMT3A mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disc degeneration and associated pain is a cause of physical and emotional distress, often leading to substantial financial burdens, due to missed work days and lost wages, but the current treatments are palliative, and do not address the underlying cause. Understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms associated with aging and degeneration will help in the development of therapeutic approaches for treatment. This proposal aims to fill this gap in the knowledge, with the focus on understanding the role of crucial developmental molecules in postnatal disc maintenance, and their potential for therapeutic use in reversing degenerative changes in the disc.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of suicide in youth have tripled in recent years, and although suicidality has been identified as early as the preschool period, little is known about the early emergence or development of suicidal thoughts and behaviors. This study will investigate how suicidal thoughts and behaviors are expressed in 4- to 7-year-old children alongside key correlates of suicidality (e.g., optimism, social functioning) at this early developmental point. The results will provide immediate clinical guidance regarding normative and non-normative expressions of suicidality in early childhood and will inform targeted preventive intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The United States is in the midst of an opioid epidemic, and many opioid addicts use oxycodone as their first narcotic analgesic. Here, we use cutting-edge neurobiological techniques in order to examine neuroadaptations underlying relapse to oxycodone seeking, with the goal of identifying novel pharmacotherapeutic targets for efficacious prevention of relapse. The experiments proposed herein have substantial promise for advancing our understanding of the brain, and as a potential treatment for addiction and other neuropsychiatric disorders in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the only disease of the top ten leading causes of death worldwide that we cannot prevent, cure, or significantly slow disease progression. The goal of this project is to establish biased signaling of the G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) GPR3 as an alternative and viable therapeutic target for AD that modulates both amyloid-β (Aβ) pathology and the innate immune response in AD. We will test the hypothesis that biased GPR3 signaling in microglia, astrocytes, and neurons reduces AD-related pathologies and cognitive decline by promoting protective immune responses and preserving neuronal function in in vitro human glial and neuronal models and in vivo in AD murine models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian rhythm disruption is common in bipolar disorder and highly predictive of a poorer clinical course. This study will test the effects of an established intervention which normalizes circadian rhythm disruption (low-dose afternoon melatonin plus time in bed scheduling) on the novel mechanistic biomarker probe of dim light melatonin onset (the gold-standard measure for circadian timing), depression, and other circadian and sleep mechanisms. Findings from the study will inform treatment targets and strategic therapies to reduce the major burden of bipolar disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a scalable and transformative technology for spatial co-profiling of epigenome, transcriptome, and a panel of proteins in the same tissue section, and deploy the high-resolution, high-content and high-throughput spatial multi-omics technologies to construct comprehensive maps of molecular and cellular events, and the associated environments underlying the etiology of Alzheimer’s disease as opposed to normal aging. It will improve our understanding of the relationship between tissue organization, function, and gene regulatory networks in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies of brain neuroplasticity during learning and memory have been so far restricted to animal research. A significant reason has been the lack of non-invasive imaging technology to probe neuroplasticity with high biological specificity. This project aims to develop and validate a non-invasive marker of neuroplasticity during learning in the human hippocampus subfields of living humans with the latest ultra-high gradient strength diffusion Magnetic Resonance Imaging technology. The marker can be used to detect early signs of pathological remodeling of the hippocampus in Alzheimer’s disease or assess the efficacy of invasive tools for memory function repair.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The project is relevant to veterans’ health because it will develop a novel wearable, portable device to help veterans with spasticity stretch themselves without additional human assistance. Manual stretching is a primary treatment to manage spasticity and can provide relief from spasms and joint stiffness, and normalize muscle tone. However, providing on-demand, reliable manual stretching is caregiver intensive. The project integrates a wearable exoskeleton and its control system to apply automated forces moving the legs at custom stretching rates while veterans lie on a bed and are sitting down. The study can lead to the development of a safer, personalized on-demand stretching tool compared to manual stretching provided by caregivers. This may provide the patient with more frequent stretching to ultimately decrease the burden of spasticity. The study examines the feasibility and performance of the device in veterans with spasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Glioblastoma is the most common primary brain tumor in adults and is uniformly fatal. We have identified a rare population of tumors cells that may be responsible for treatment resistance resulting from signaling/interactions within its local tumor microenvironment. We now seek to study these cells and their interactions in hopes that inhibiting their signaling mechanisms will result in treatment sensitivity and lead to the identification of novel therapies for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because medication-related adverse events are a major cause of preventable hospital admissions, morbidity in the United States, and contribute substantially to health care costs. The proposed project will generate data that will inform our understanding of the contribution of gene-x-drug interactions (pharmacogenetics), in combination with multiple medical conditions and risk factors, to Emergency Department visits and hospital readmissions within 90 days of hospital discharge. The results from this project will advance knowledge on the impact of gene-x-drug reactions on adverse medical outcomes, and it will inform predictive models to better identify patients at the highest risk of hospital readmission attributable to adverse drug reactions. If patients at the highest risk of adverse drug reactions could be more accurately identified, we could better justify preemptive pharmacogenetic testing for the highest risk patients to prevent hospital admissions and better manage chronic health conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The overarching goal of my program is to understand how genetic and environmental factors interact to determine non communicable disease risk. For the past 15 years my VA supported research has characterized and validated a lipid signaling pathway as a unique determinant of heritable cardiovascular disease risk. To support these studies, we developed expertise in biomedical mass spectrometry which has become a major focus of my work. This latter issue is of great concern to veterans and active-duty military personnel as recently acknowledged by the Honoring our Promise to Address Comprehensive Toxics Act. I have set up an analytical laboratory that can measure multiple classes of environmental chemicals in small volumes of human biofluids. This laboratory is currently supporting population health studies of health effects of per and poly fluorinated substances using the Million Veteran Program and I am more broadly involved in efforts to enable routine biomonitoring of environmental exposures across the lifespan of Veterans and Service Members.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Sepsis and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are both life-threatening disorders that are prevalent in the Veteran population; the former caused by a dysregulated host immune response to infection and the latter a severe form of acute lung injury that may be non-infectious in etiology. In our animal models, neuro-inflammation develops in both conditions, and this alters ventilatory patterns. We propose to map changes in the respiratory network activity and brainstem neuro-inflammation due to septic and sterile injuries and test whether these changes can be reversed by central anti-inflammatory therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease becomes a leading cause of the death for aged people in developed countries, and understanding the progression of Alzheimer’s disease is crucial for finding the cure for this disease. In this project, we will determine how a transmembrane protein called CD151 regulates the progression of Alzheimer’s disease. Our study will also provide insight into the general mechanisms that govern the brain inflammation and identify promising candidates to combat degenerative diseases and chronic inflammation of brain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDPs) present a unique opportunity to improve the health of reproductive-age individuals with elevated cardiovascular disease risks. However, key evidence gaps have limited interventions. Through the proposed K23 research, I will advance our understanding of cardiovascular health (distribution and determinants) after HDPs; pilot test a novel intervention to improve cardiovascular health after HDPs; and develop the skills to become an independent investigator who can develop and disseminate effective, equity-focused interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Globally, 3 million people die from excess salt as the leading dietary risk factor for CVD each year and this is a significant public health problem that must be addressed. The U.S. is one of the top three countries with highest population sodium intake per day and one of top four countries with the largest CVD burden; however, there are not much data regarding which sodium reduction policy ‘has been’ adopted, what ‘might be’ the health gain and its distribution in nationwide policy implementation, and what ‘could be’ implemented in the multi-level system in the U.S. The proposed research is innovative in applying RE-AIM to policy implementation science and developing an interactive tool that can be used in the future as part of a strategy to improve policy implementation to ultimately eliminate preventable cardiovascular health disparities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The apolipoprotein E (APOE) E4 allele represents a major genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) that is known to cause brain blood vessel damage, compromise the transport of glucose to nerve cells for generating energy, and impair toxic Abeta waste removal from the brain. This proposed work will evaluate and identify ways to regulate the usage of fats as a source of energy in brain blood vessel cells, thereby improving the transportation of nutrients within the brain and supporting the energy needs of astroglia and neurons. Correcting fat utilization in the blood vessels will also restore the astroglia’s ability to remove toxic Abeta from the brain. Ultimately, this will lead to the development of therapeutic interventions for E4 carriers who have an increased risk of developing AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Female patients have been excluded from prior clinical trials evaluating groin hernia management, which may result in worse outcomes among females following surgery (e.g., higher rates of recurrent hernia, worse pain) compared to males. This Career Development Award will provide the candidate with the necessary training as well as establish the infrastructure and critical foundational data to conduct the first ever patient-centered clinical trial for females with groin hernia. This work will inform the development of evidence-based guidelines and training to improve care for tens of thousands of females with groin hernia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer's disease is one of the most common and progressive genetic neurodegenerative disorders in the US with more than 5 million people currently living with Alzheimer's disease with risk factors often associated with age and sex. Women are more likely to develop a rapid progression of Alzheimer's disease, than men when predictive factors such as obesity, lifespan, and enhanced stroke severity are considered. We describe protein arginine methyltransferase 4 modulation as a therapeutic potential against Alzheimer's disease and other vascular cognitive impairment disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial subset of follicular lymphoma (FL) patients has an early relapse and a poor clinical outcome; however, little is known of the molecular mechanisms responsible for these aggressive features. We have demonstrated that the tumor microenvironment (TME) plays a key role in treatment failure and found that FLs with increased expression of IRF4 have dysregulated immune signaling, a suppressive TME, and a poor prognosis. In this project, we aim to elucidate the mechanisms by which IRF4 controls tumor immunity and define the concordant immunophenotypic changes, ultimately paving the way for novel precision therapies for this unfavorable patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative U.S. veterans are an increasingly racially/ethnically and geographically diverse population that may be at increased risk of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) due to their high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and heightened exposure to ADRD risk factors such as traumatic brain injury, posttraumatic stress disorder and depression (military-related exposures). The relationships between hypertension, blood pressure targets, and ADRD risk within potential high-risk subgroups are not well understood, but an integrated nationwide healthcare system like the Veterans Health Administration (VHA) provides a unique opportunity to rigorously examine these relationships in a large, national, and increasingly diverse population. In this study, we leverage VHA data to estimate the association of hypertension and ADRD risk, assess how military-related exposures influence this relationship, and estimate hypertension treatment effects at various treatment targets for optimized reduction in ADRD burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with malignant primary central nervous system (CNS) tumors experience significant distress about their diagnosis, poor prognosis, and expected neurological decline, often leading to avoidant coping behavior that negatively impacts their mood and quality of life. The proposed research project aims to refine and pilot test a psychosocial intervention designed to alleviate distress, facilitate coping and promote values-driven behavior in patients with newly diagnosed malignant primary CNS tumors. Study findings will drive future research in this understudied area and inform development and delivery of interventions to support patients with malignant primary CNS tumors, with potential application to patients with a wide range of neurological illnesses and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial myopathy is a novel biomarker for cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk that can be detected by measuring left atrial function before left atrial enlargement occurs, offering a potential opportunity to identify and treat high risk individuals before clinically symptomatic CVD occurs. We propose to randomize 80 individuals without diabetes and at risk for heart failure to either empagliflozin or placebo and conduct assessments of left atrial and left ventricular function and change in plasma proteins after 9 months of intervention. Results from this trail will provide novel preliminary evidence about the hypothesized effect of empagliflozin on left atrial and left ventricular function in an understudied population and inform a larger R01-funded RCT evaluating the effect on clinical outcomes in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is designed to further train Sasha Prisco, MD, PhD in molecular and cellular cardiac physiology and multiple omics techniques to help in the transition to becoming an independently funded physician-scientist who studies the mechanisms of right ventricular dysfunction in pulmonary hypertension. Her project investigates if Lactobacillus supplementation modulates the gut microbiome, systemic inflammation, the microtubule cytoskeleton, and right ventricular function in pulmonary arterial hypertension. During her training, she will refine skills that will enable her to perform clinically-relevant, translational research that will hopefully allow for future development of novel therapies for this rare and devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mold infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and are among the hardest-to- treat fungal infections due to limited efficacy of current antifungal drugs. There is an urgent need for antifungals to treat these infections and in this proposal, we aim to meet that need by performing a high throughput antifungal drug screen directly with the mold Aspergillus fumigatus. The goal of this work is to identify mold- active antifungal scaffolds with novel mechanisms of action for preclinical development to fight life-threatening mold infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how persistent,pathogenic exosomes promote cerebrovascular disease during and after zoster, thereby accelerating vascular dementia risk, is significant because it will potentially change clinical practice with regards to duration of antiviral therapy and use of anti-platelet agents for zoster, as well as increase support for vaccination to prevent rash and stroke, as well as to decrease vascular dementia risk. Furthermore, our findings will serve as a model for how other pathogens can have long-lasting effects at sites remote from regions of infection and stimulate further research on the biological consequences of pathogen- associated exosomes and potential therapeutics, including agents that block exosome release and fusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Placentally-mediated adverse pregnancy outcomes (APO), including hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, preterm birth, and fetal growth restriction, may play an underrecognized role in the development of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD), through biological processes such as vascular endothelial dysfunction and angiogenic dysregulation. The overall goal of this study is to capitalize on an ongoing, multi-ethnic cohort study, the Nulliparous Pregnancy Outcomes Study: Monitoring Mothers-to-be Heart Health Study, to 1) determine whether those with and without history of APO differ in brain magnetic resonance imaging ADRD risk markers, 10-15 years after the first pregnancy, and 2) correlate levels of the angiogenic regulatory protein placental growth factor (PlGF), measured during and after the index pregnancy, with the same imaging markers, in study participants with and without a history of APO. This will be the first study to use prospectively collected pregnancy data and biomarkers to investigate the relationship between APO, angiogenic dysfunction, and future maternal ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and a leading cause of death in the United States, with no effective treatments to slow or halt disease progression. This proposal will develop an assay to visualize the secretion and spreading of nano-sized extracellular vesicles (EVs) in the brain, a process with great relevance to AD pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Population-bases studies have observed a long-term association between “silent brain ischemia (SBI)” and an increased risk of dementia and Alzheimer's disease (AD). Therefore, research studies to determine the underlying mechanisms and search for approaches to prevent or treat SBI-accelerated AD dementia are urgently needed. This proposal meets this critical need as it will examine the pathogenesis of SBI-accelerated AD dementia by using a SBI model combined with a novel clinically relevant transgenic AD rat model, and will evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of non-invasive pulsed laser therapy for the treatment of SBI-AD dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health since in Mexico, marginalized urban populations have a disproportionately high physical inactivity and noncommunicable disease burden. It is imperative to identify and deploy effective approaches that improve the uptake of evidence-based, contextually-relevant physical activity interventions in high need areas. A project of this scale can have a profound effect on health inequities in Mexico, and has the potential of informing translation and scale-up of evidence-based urban health interventions in other global settings, including Latino communities in the US.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this K24 renewal is to provide ongoing salary and research support for Dr. Hoffman to allow him to focus 25% of his time mentoring clinical fellows, students, junior faculty and other trainees in patient-oriented research on the microbial determinants of chronic diseases in children. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying new laboratory tests that can measure the progression of ME/CFS will directly improve the diagnosis and treatment of ME/CFS and contribute to our understanding of mechanisms underlying ME/CFS. This research develops an interdisciplinary approach to assess the recently discovered, oxygen tension-regulated red blood cell capillary velocity as a new laboratory test for ME/CFS and investigate previously unrealized red blood cell cytokine signaling in ME/CFS. Because ME/CFS is a poorly understood, complex, debilitating disease with no specific laboratory diagnostic tests yet, we believe the proposed project is directly relevant to the NIH's mission and should be broadly valuable for research efforts and clinical studies of chronic diseases including recently emerged long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: This research aims to establish novel markers of cerebrovascular disease (CVD) for the sensitive and specific evaluation of vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) by studying non-invasive vascular specific MRI markers in CADASIL, the most common heritable cause of vascular dementia. Through this, we aim to understand the influence of both macrovascular and microvascular disease on CADASIL neurodegeneration and cognition. The degree of vascular disease involvement at various stages (normal cognition, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia) of CADASIL (Notch3 mutation carriers) will then be compared with cognitively unimpaired normal aging participants without known neurodegenerative diseases including Notch3 mutations, thereby facilitating examination of other types of VCID and mixed dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia affecting over 55 million people worldwide, and this number is expected to triple by 2050. This project aims to examine the role of a new mechanism – N- glycosylation – in AD pathogenesis. Findings of this study are anticipated to provide important new insight into AD pathology and are likely to lead to novel therapeutic tools against AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid globalization and urbanization continue to escalate the burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) across the world, disproportionally affecting low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). To date, trials have documented that task-sharing with Community Health Workers reduces systolic blood pressure and fasting blood glucose and achieves smoking cessation. However, most trials have been done in rural areas, and most trials of CHWs tested management of a single condition, e.g. just hypertension. In this context, we propose to conduct an implementation research study on task-sharing with CHWs for concurrent management of hypertension, diabetes, and smoking in a metropolitan city of Nepal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a major public health problem that requires interdisciplinary and diverse teams to significantly reduce or eliminate its impact on cardiometabolic health outcomes. The OHD PRIDE research training and mentoring program is designed to provide comprehensive mentorship, education and networking opportunities in obesity health disparities research to early career faculty from underrepresented backgrounds. Mentees who are employed or who were trained at Minority Serving Institutions will participate in a two-year program intended to enhance their skills in research, grant writing, and scientific writing. The work of OHD PRIDE Program will contribute to the diversification of biomedical research by increasing the number of early faculty from underrepresented backgrounds who launch independent research careers focused on obesity disparities and related chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are currently no FDA-approved therapeutics for psychostimulant use disorders, and our understanding of the neurobiological changes underlying the intensification of methamphetamine craving over increasing periods of abstinence is limited. The role of key projections from the nucleus accumbens in mediating the incubation of methamphetamine craving will be delineated. This project will also use state of the art molecular techniques to identify cell type-specific changes in gene expression and chromatin accessibility in the rat nucleus accumbens associated with the incubation of methamphetamine craving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this project are to determine the protective effects of APOE-R136S on APOE4-driven neural network dysfunction, behavioral deficits, pathologies, and transcriptomic alterations in novel mouse models of AD and to explore the underlying cellular, molecular, and transcriptomic mechanisms. The findings from this study will help to identify novel mechanisms and targets for therapeutic development for treating Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative For this Ancillary R01 study proposal, we will be working with the NIDDK IBD Genetics Consortium to apply the latest high-throughput omics approaches to one of the largest post-operative Crohn’s disease (CD) cohort to better understand the pathophysiology of CD. This proposal focuses on better elucidating how the complex relationship between host genetics, microbial and immune factors contribute to recurrence of CD from a “disease-free state” after resection of disease. Through the insights gained, we hope to reduce the risk of post- operative CD recurrence, change the nature course of disease, and improve the quality of life of individuals affected by CD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Activation of the innate immune system has been recognized as a significant component of numerous forms of neurodegenerative disease. This project aims to characterize the factors influencing microglia, key mediators of inflammation in the retina, to switch from homeostatic to proinflammatory functions as part of disease progression in age-related macular degeneration. Using novel methods for gene knockout of key pathways in human stem-cell derived microglia-like cells, single-cell RNA sequencing analysis, and highly multiplexed molecular mapping in tissue with digital histologic analysis, this work will identify tissue microenvironment factors and immune checkpoints representing novel therapeutic targets for retinal degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While some genes can increase the risk of disease, other genes may reduce the effect of these risk genes as well as the effect of environmental factors. In this study, we will identify genetic variants that contribute to resilience to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) by attenuating the effects of genetic risk variants and cigarette smoking. This will result in greater understanding of the ways that genetic factors contribute to variable disease risk, and this information might be used to better predict risk for COPD and identify new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The short-interval intracortical inhibition (SICI) is a biomarker of brain excitability that can be readily obtained using non-invasive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). Higher SICI scores – indicating reduced inhibition – are consistently reported in prior studies of schizophrenia; yet the clinical impact and implications of this finding are unknown since there is little evidence of the neural systems related to SICI, and how SICI may relate to clinical variables such as the extent of cognitive impairment in schizophrenia. This proposal aims to evaluate the cognitive and neural correlates of SICI in schizophrenia and conducts a pilot mechanistic clinical trial aimed at enhancing SICI in schizophrenia to identify novel targets for treatment in future clinical research studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal aims to continue training and mentoring underrepresented junior scientists/clinicians and those with disabilities by enhancing their research skills in cardiovascular health disparities. The ultimate goal in increasing diversity among the ranks of underrepresented scientists/clinicians, is an important step towards alleviating heart disease related health disparities. In the 17 years since its inception at Brooklyn SUNY Downstate Health Sciences University, the program has trained 129 underrepresented junior faculty, the majority of them are now funded or on their way to obtaining research funding and pursuing independent academic careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of extended-spectrum β-lactamase producing Enterobacterales (ESBL-E) has increased by over 50% in the US over a 5-year period - with upwards of 30% mortality associated with ESBL-E bloodstream infections (BSI). Our preliminary data across Enterobacterales species indicate that 3 ESBL gene families comprise ~99% of ESBLs (i.e., blaCTX-M [60%], blaSHV-variants [25%], and blaTEM-variants [15%]); however, little progress has been made to characterize the prevalence of non-CTX-M gene families across Enterobacterales species and it is unknown if piperacillin-tazobactam may be an effective carbapenem-sparing treatment option for SHV and TEM ESBL-E infections. We would like to investigate if a mechanistic-based treatment approach (i.e., optimal antibiotic treatment selection is dependent on the ESBL gene identified) will improve the outcomes of patients by (1) characterizing the epidemiology of ESBL genes in a multicenter cohort of 2,000 consecutive clinical Enterobacterales BSI isolates and (2) determining if meropenem is the preferred treatment for ESBL-producing Enterobacterales BSI regardless of the ESBL gene family present.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Many of the symptoms of long COVID [i.e., post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC)], including learning and memory impairments, fatigue, anxiety, and depression, are likely mediated through the central nervous system. A protracted reaction to the virus, possibly via prolonged inflammation, may contribute to cognitive and mood impairments. Prospective neuropsychiatric, neuroimaging, and biological data will be collected to identify biomarkers, genetic risk factors, and clinical endpoints associated with neuropsychiatric PASC (neuro-PASC) progression or severity, and biomarkers for promoting brain repair and attenuating those symptoms. This research will advance our understanding of the long-term effects of COVID-19 on neuropsychiatric functions, identify clinically relevant biomarkers, provide evidence-based guidance for clinicians working with this unique population, and facilitate the development of therapeutic interventions to treat neuro- PASC and will be a unique contribution to overall VA priorities and Veteran health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WENCESLAU, CAMILLA F.  Growing evidence supports a robust and likely causal association between hypertension and Alzheimer's disease (AD). Here we claim that the causative connection of these conditions is an exacerbated endothelial-to- mesenchymal transition and, subsequently, synthesis of amyloid-β protein oligomers to form amyloid plaques. We will reprogram and rejuvenate endothelial cells to prevent endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition and treat AD and hypertension.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 700,000 people are diagnosed with liver cancer and 600,000 people die each year worldwide; the incidence is increasing in the US and it is estimated that 42,220 new cases will be diagnosed and 30,200 people will die of liver cancer in the next year. Part of the increased incidence in the US is thought to be due to HCV infections acquired during the 1960s and 1970s but aside from viral infection, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis and cirrhosis are major risk factors for liver cancer. The 5-year survival rate is only 18% underscoring the lack of effective therapies in liver cancer so a detailed understanding of the mechanisms involved in triggering liver disease and hepatocellular carcinoma would greatly help the prevention and treatment of liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Our goal is to develop better therapies for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Our published results show that pharmacologically high doses of thiamine (vitamin B1) are effective in mouse models of AD and produce encouraging clinical benefit in AD patients. The research will discover the mechanism of the thiamine sensitivity with measures in AD autopsy brain and in brain and blood samples from mice with low and high thiamine in order to develop better therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a blinding disease world-wide, but for reasons that are unclear, African- Americans are at disproportionate risk, yet, very little is known about this disease in this population. Therefore identification of IOP-regulation in African Americans is a major task that must to be overcome before therapeutic interventions for the treatment of glaucoma in this population can be developed. Therefore the overall goal is to elucidate the cellular, molecular and biochemical mechanisms that regulate IOP; African American and Non-Hispanic Whites donor eyes will be used in this study, aimed at identifying novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm infants have immature gastrointestinal function, small bile acid pools, and adrenal insufficiency that limit their development and response to enteral nutrition. Fibroblast growth factor 19 (FGF19) is a potent fetal growth factor that is upregulated postnatally and functions to regulate bile acid homeostasis. In this proposal, we seek to determine the impact of perinatal glucocorticoids and FGF19 on gastrointestinal, hepatic and metabolic outcomes in preterm pigs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The burden of depression, both from a societal and economic standpoint, ranks second only to ischemic heart disease. The World Health Organization projects that depression is the leading cause of disability, worldwide. Depression and suicide (44/day) are particularly prevalent in military returning from deployment and the population of Veterans they become. As many as one third are resistant to antidepressants and they are at greatest risk for suicide. We have identified a proteomic biosignature for depression and responsiveness to therapy. Most recently, we have learned that platelets from depressed subjects show this biomarker and those from subjects undergoing successful treatment revert to “normal”. We are currently doing a larger- scale study of this is a veteran population. Knowledge gained from this study should help to develop a rapid and inexpensive screen for depression and antidepressant responsiveness, and create a platform for development of novel antidepressant compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will provide Dr. Frank Schwebel with training in mindfulness-based interventions, psychosocial and pharmacological treatment approaches for opioid use disorder, advanced mobile health approaches and quantitative methods, and research ethics. The proposed research will evaluate the efficacy of a microrandomized intervention designed to increase state mindfulness, decrease craving, and increase self- efficacy among individuals who take daily medication for an opioid use disorder. Together, the well-integrated research and career development plans will support Dr. Schwebel’s independent research program focused on developing mobile health treatments for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroinflammation (inflammation in the brain) causes reductions in cognitive functions like learning and memory during aging, and it increases the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other neurodegenerative disorders. The purpose of this research project is to determine if a novel pharmacological treatment that specifically inhibits key cellular drivers of neuroinflammation can improve cognitive function during aging, and/or in the context of Alzheimer’s disease-like pathology. This work may help us understand how and why aging increases the risk for Alzheimer’s disease, and it could provide insight on potential therapeutic strategies for inhibiting these events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal application for a PRIDE Academy: Health AI and Data Science in Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Disease: Application and Bioethics (HARP-BIO) will select junior faculty scholars under- represented in science and medicine and bring them for two consecutive summer academies at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus. Here, the scholars will be introduced to state-of-the-art multiomics approaches to study the impact of ancestry and gender on cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases as well as how biases in coding can influence artificial intelligence and machine learning outputs and contribute to health disparities. By examining biases in coding in artificial intelligence and machine learning we will generate fundamental information regarding these technologies and how to apply them ethically and equitably. Scholars will be mentored by experts in personalized medicine and bioethics as well as experts in cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases and will participate in career development activities including social science approaches to ensure scholars' long-term academic persistence. Our overall goal is to create a workforce of pulmonary and cardiovascular researchers who are as diverse as the communities they serve.

PHR: NARRATIVE The loss of cognitive ability in aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is highly variable between individuals as they age, and mechanisms that underlie the heterogeneous aspect of cognitive function have not been investigated. In this application we address whether cell-specific metabolic deficits predict heterogeneity in cognitive function with age. These studies are essential to understanding the molecular mechanisms that can potentially be leveraged to treat cognitive dysfunction with age and in AD.

PHR: Acute respiratory failure is common in children and can cause death if clinicians do not support a child’s breathing correctly. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Statement To date, few clinical trials for tauopathy have specifically targeted pathological tau, yet neurofibrillary tangles are the diagnostic neuropathological hallmark of AD and CTE that is most closely associated with cognitive decline. To help fill this gap, we propose to develop novel neuroprotective strategies that target pathological tau in AD and CTE related dementia disorders. Specifically, we propose to develop therapeutic ideas for targeting pathological tau. These novel agents will provide a proof-of-concept demonstration that inhibiting targeting pathological tau deposition can improve neurodegenerative outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The most common cause of hospitalization for Veterans, acute cardiovascular disease, commonly injures the kidneys, and can cause long-term chronic kidney disease. Chronic kidney disease in turn is closely associated with worsening of cardiovascular disease, particularly high blood pressure. The current study will evaluate the development of new high blood pressure in a model of acute cardiovascular disease, which is very similar to the human clinical condition. We propose a mechanism in which a factor released by the heart changes kidney function, causing high blood pressure; this mechanism is potentially interruptible with drug therapy. Successful completion of this project is therefore expected to evaluate a new potential means for the heart and kidney to interact in causing disease which is highly relevant to Veteran and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Relevance HIV-1 establishes reservoirs that resist drug and immunological treatments, indicating that basic studies are needed to understand how to target these sites. We have described an SIV model in which a mutation in the envelope cytoplasmic tail leads to cellular immune control but with persistent reservoirs. Our proposal takes advantage of unique attributes of this model to assess novel interventions that can reveal vulnerabilities in the reservoir and inform targeted approaches to eliminate HIV-1 reservoirs in humans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: It is estimated that diabetes affect 25% of the VA patients and with more than 70% of patients in VA facilities being overweight or obese, type 2 diabetes becoming a major health concern. Diarrhea is one of the most common gastrointestinal complications in diabetes, and yet understanding and treatment for diabetic diarrhea are lacking. The proposed study is aimed at understanding the underlying cause of diarrhea in type 2 diabetes where diarrhea is often associated with medications. We will explore the role of a sodium-hydrogen exchange in the intestine as a major cause of diabetic diarrhea and perform a pre-clinical study to test the efficacy of biological agents for the treatment of diarrhea.

PHR: Project Narrative Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death and disability in the Western world, however, the mechanisms underlying atherosclerosis are complex and remain obscure despite intense research in this area. I propose to establish for the first time the cause-and-effect relationship between the enzyme lysyl oxidase and atherosclerosis using unique animal models developed by our team. This study could provide new therapeutic treatments that reduce the risk of developing cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A wide range of cognitive functions depend on brain mechanisms that support decision-making. The project will elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying an encephalographic signature of complex decisions made by normal humans by establishing its underpinnings at the level of neural circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common arrhythmia, affecting 33.5 million people globally with a growing prevalence. AF is associated with significant morbidity and mortality, including 20% of all strokes, 33% of hospitalizations related to cardiac arrhythmias, and a two-fold increase in risk of death. To reduce AF-associated risks such as stroke, it is important to be able to diagnose AF early in the AF trajectory when it is asymptomatic and paroxysmal in order to initiate effective stroke prevention interventions including anticoagulation. We propose an integrated data and algorithm strategy as well as a prospective study to fully exploit and validate the power of deep neural networks, interpretable survival models, and Big Data to achieve both high sensitivity and precision in using photoplethysmography (PPG) to detect AF and to use EHR data to identify patients with high risk of AF post stroke to benefit from continuous AF monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Over 726,000 individuals in the U.S. have end-stage renal disease (ESRD) with about 87% of patients on the life-sustaining treatment of dialysis at over 6,000 dialysis facilities across U.S. The proposal involves developing new methods for studying time-dynamic effects of patient-, facility- and region-level factors (across U.S.) of hospitalization and mortality risk among dialysis patients, a cohort with frequent hospitalizations and very high mortality rates. The overarching goal is to provide the knowledge base for improving patient care by identifying modifiable multilevel risk factors and time periods of elevated risks after transition to dialysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major depression (MD) is a leading cause of disability worldwide, arises from the action and interaction between genetic and environmental factors, and is often comorbid with other psychiatric and medical conditions. Although recent progress has yielded modest insight into the genetic architecture of MD, most studies have been in European ancestry populations, seriously limiting our knowledge of human genomic variation, disease etiology, and precision medicine efforts. Here, we propose cross-population genetic studies of MD to advance our understanding of the genetic architecture in all populations and ensure that genetic research is broadly applicable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolism is the process by which food is converted into energy and the molecular building blocks necessary for life. It is highly dynamic and changes rapidly with different conditions, for example after a large meal or vigorous exercise. We can measure a great number of metabolites in chemical extracts or biofluids, but there are few methods to measure metabolites in living systems. This project is to develop a better method to measure metabolism in a living microorganism in different conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic disease is resistant to current therapies and remains the primary cause of cancer related death. We identified that specific distant organs away from the primary tumor can create the “pre-metastatic niches” for future metastasis initiation by recruiting platelets to vessel wall which will in turn support circulating tumor cell to slowdown and attach on the vessel wall, thus affecting physical transport of cancer cells. Objective of this proposal is to elucidate the both biological and physical roles of the pre-metastatic niche for initiation of metastasis and we anticipate that the proposed research will bring a strong scientific framework for elucidate unknown role of platelets for initiating metastasis and rational prevention of metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Depression and cognitive problems are extremely common in people with HIV and may have a shared cause. Since iron is needed for balanced production of chemicals in the brain that are linked to mood and cognition, changes in iron due to HIV infection can upset this delicate balance. This study will determine whether changes in iron, and in genes that control iron metabolism, can predict development of depression and cognitive problems in people with HIV, leading to new treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are influenced by genetic variation and environmental exposures, yet little work has been done to understand how upstream social, built, and physical environmental exposures interact with polygenic risk to influence biological mechanisms that cause ADRD. In the proposed research, (F99) I will identify key environmental exposures associated with ADRD, independent of and interacting with polygenic risk. (K00) I will then investigate the changes in transcriptomic and proteomic profiles that mediate the associations between the environment and ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The blood vessels deliver oxygen and nutrients and remove waste to and from every organ of the body. Endothelial cells line all the blood vessels forming a barrier between blood and tissues. In specific organs, endothelial cells form specialized subcellular structures called endothelial fenestrae and endothelial diaphragms. Recent data show that endothelial diaphragms are critical for life and their components and malfunction are implicated in a large host of human diseases (protein losing enteropathy, cancer, preeclampsia, kidney failure, diabetes and inflammation). There is little known on how endothelial fenestrae and diaphragms assemble their molecular components, which are addressed in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social relationships are crucially important to human health; however, we do not fully understand what in our brains drives us to form relationships, to feel loss when the relationships end, or to allow our partners to reduce our stress levels (also called “social buffering”). In this project, we will study titi monkeys, which form adult pair bonds, using imaging and drug manipulations to examine the neurobiology of social buffering and separation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Data are limited regarding risk factors for progression of gastric intestinal metaplasia to gastric cancer in the Unites States (US) population, and regarding which individuals may benefit from preventative interventions such as endoscopic screening/surveillance. The proposed research will utilize pathology data from across the US to characterize the prevalence of extensive and limited gastric intestinal metaplasia, and the respective risks of progression of these lesions to gastric cancer. Subsequently, we will utilize simulation modeling to assess how targeted screening and surveillance can impact health outcomes in patients across 64 specific, diverse risk-factor profiles, both on a patient level and a population level.

PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need for the development of non-invasive therapies for the degenerative process of the temporomandibular joint. The proposed project addresses a novel hypothesis that intermittent administration of parathyroid hormone (I-PTH) exerts a chondroprotective role, and the anabolic effects caused by its administration would partially reverse degeneration of the TMJ of mice. Furthermore, we propose that these effects are mainly regulated by FGFR3 signaling. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: These experiments will provide tremendous insight into the mechanisms of RNA processing in humans, and how RNA binding proteins regulate their own levels and the levels of other RNA binding proteins. As the vast majority of human genes are alternatively spliced, it is likely the discoveries we make will be of direct relevance to human health. This work will also provide insight into the mechanisms of adaptation in the immune systems of prokaryotes. In addition to enhancing our understanding of the basic science of prokaryotic immune systems, there is tremendous potential that this work could lead to the development of new tools that can be used for genome editing applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Penn Human Pancreas Analysis Program – T2D Narrative The past decades have seen a dramatic improvement in our ability to phenotype and molecularly profile human tissues relevant to the etiology of type 2 diabetes with unprecedented resolution, at the genomic, epigenomic, protein, and functional levels. Here we will employ state-of-the-art technologies to determine all aspects of pancreas biology as it pertains to type 2 diabetes, profile human pancreatic islets with multiple assay modalities, and make the vast data accumulated available through the highly accessible PANC-DB. This comprehensive profiling of the natural history of Type 2 diabetes will pave the way for future discoveries of new treatment modalities for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A thorough understanding of cells and molecules that regulate skin wound healing is essential for the generation of tissue-specific regenerative therapies to effectively treat human disease. Since the manner in which lymphatic vessels function during skin wound healing is largely unknown, we will define how these major but poorly understood cells function during skin wound healing. Our work will improve our understanding of the cells and molecules that control basic skin regeneration, how lymphatic endothelium function in this process, and will have global relevance for other regenerative tissues in patients with lymphatic disorders.
