IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers in the world, with over 70% of breast cancers harboring the activation of the estrogen receptor α (ERα), a key oncogenic transcription factor. We have, made a striking discovery that ERα has an RNA-binding protein that acts to change gene expression at the post-transcriptional level, which is critical for tumor development. The findings of this proposal will be instrumental in revealing a new “Achilles’ Heel” of ERα oncogenic activity in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In 2018 suicide was reported as the 2nd leading cause of death among Black Americans ages 10-14-years-old; suicide prevention resources designed specifically for Black youth, however, remain scant. Where therefore propose the development of a multilevel cultural adaptation of the Signs of Suicide (SOS) prevention program and will conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial with students, parents, and school personnel in Chicago Public Schools to assess feasibility and examine underlying mechanisms that contribute to suicidality among Black youth. Findings derived from this project will contribute to public health priorities by offering unique insight into the factors that either prevent or promote suicide among Black youth and could be replicated in other schools serving Black students and their families across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE microRNAs are important in many biological processes because they downregulate gene expression to control cell fate decisions, and mis-regulation by microRNAs contributes to multiple pathological states. Understanding how a miRNA controls cell fate decisions requires both identifying the genes it downregulates and demonstrating how that regulation contributes to a cellular pathway. This is the goal of the proposed project, which develops an experimental strategy to unravel the biological roles of speciﬁc miRNAs, using miR-1 and miR-206 in skeletal muscle cell differentiation as a model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying older adults at-risk for falls is critical for implementing preventative interventions aimed at reducing adverse outcomes, but developing prediction models for fall-risk remains challenging due to analytic shortcomings, missing data, and limitations of electronic health record (EHR) data. This K25 Mentored Quantitative Research Development Award provides Dr. Jaime Lynn Speiser with essential training in aging, missing data methodology, EHR data analysis, and career development to facilitate her transition into an independent biostatistical researcher in aging. The prediction model developed in this K25 research proposal and validated with EHR data will aid in identification of at-risk individuals for falls through an automated mechanism.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The extent to which African HIV universal treatment programs can reach all HIV-positive persons and suppress them over their entire lives as well as reverse rising trends in HIV drug resistance remains unknown. Moreover, the introduction of the COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted HIV treatment and prevention services. This study aims to measure the impact of COVID-19 on key HIV programmatic outcomes, including HIV viremia, drug resistance, and new cases of HIV in a Ugandan population with a high HIV burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Biliary atresia is the leading cause of pediatric liver transplantation in the United States, however little is known about the pathogenesis and factors which influence outcomes. The gut microbiome has multiple effects on other disease processes involving the liver. This proposal is the first to longitudinally characterize the microbiome in a multicenter study to identify how the microbiome contributes to outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone post-translational modifications (PTMs) are some of the most widely studied epigenomic factors, and alterations in histone PTM abundance and distribution have been implicated in numerous disease etiologies. However, efforts to map histone PTMs in limited samples and single cells, such as rare primary immune cells and clinical samples, have been hindered by the lack of high-quality antibodies. To meet this need, EpiCypher is developing a novel antibody development pipeline to create ultra-efficiency antibodies that enable low and single cell genomic mapping assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Male sex workers (MSW), or men who exchange sex for money, drugs, or other items of value with other men, are at exceptionally high risk for HIV infection, and many are ideal candidates for pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) – an effective biomedical intervention for reducing HIV transmission – but use in this population has been essentially nonexistent. Currently, HIV prevention efforts for MSWs are limited, with no existing evidenced-based PrEP interventions for this population. A successful theoretically-grounded intervention that addresses the unique individual, interpersonal and contextual challenges to PrEP uptake and optimal adherence has the potential to decrease HIV incidence among MSWs and reduce forward transmission to their clients and partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Essential tremor is a common neurological disorder that has been linked to an increased risk of developing dementia. A large gap remains in the understanding of neuroanatomical correlates of cognitive changes in essential tremor, particularly whether they represent cerebellar dysfunction alone or potentially more widespread neurological processes, such as those seen in age-related neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed study will examine biomarkers (i.e., neuroimaging, plasma) in individuals with essential tremor in an effort to better understand the link between essential tremor and cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants outside protein-coding genes can control the expression of genes important for the development of many human diseases, with specific variants linked to increased risk of specific diseases. This proposal will define the regulatory variants in selected human skin diseases and characterize how they dysregulate gene expression. This effort is designed to help understand the principles whereby inherited variants predispose to disease. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative (Public relevance statement) This project addresses the need to improve identification of developmental language disorders in children who speak a language other than English at home. We will investigate two novel approaches to language assessment that both aim to measure a child’s underlying language- learning ability. By rigorously evaluating these assessment approaches, including how well they predict English language growth over time and how well they index risk for language disorder, we will advance clinical and theoretical knowledge of language assessment with minority language learners (i.e., those who speak languages such as Spanish, Somali, Hmong, or Karen).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Recent rise in the levels of antimicrobial resistance is highly alarming. Clinicians broadly use Ciprofloxacin, but resistance level to it is spreading at a high rate, specifically among Escherichia coli that cause urinary tract infections in community or hospital settings. We will study alternative mechanisms of emergence, transmission and spread of the Ciprofloxacin resistance by E. coli strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    The proposed studies will use parasympathetic influences on heart rate to assess, in humans  and rats, neurocognitive aging. We will further examine whether the basal forebrain supports a  common regulatory capacity on both cognitive and autonomic control, and thus underlies their  common aging- related decline. The proposed research may further advance the use of a  noninvasive, low- cost digital biomarker of neurocognitive aging and serve to identify those who  may progress to mild neurocognitive disorder and ultimately convert to Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will define new mechanisms for the imitation and propagation venous thrombosis. Specifically, the project will examine how factors that control protease activated receptor 4 (PAR4) signaling leads to venous thrombosis. The project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to identify and characterize the underlying biological mechanisms that have the potential to become dysregulated in pathological states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study will address a need for motivational strategies to achieve therapeutic levels of task repetition in upper extremity rehabilitation post-stroke. To do so, we will characterize the motor, affective, physiological and neural effects of music improvisation in stroke survivors. The findings from this study will contribute to a framework for optimizing music-based interventions for upper extremity rehabilitation post-stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease is one of the fastest growing neurodegenerative diseases and is often accompanied by progressive, eventually debilitating cognitive decline to dementia. The goal of the proposed project is to determine whether a more comprehensive approach for assessing neurobiological dysfunction will better predict current and future cognitive disturbance. Broadly, improving the assessment of cognitive risk could inform both clinical prognosis for individuals with PD and allow for a more targeted selection of participants into experimental trials aiming to slow impending cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) uses magnetic fields sent from a “wand” placed on the head to safely treat brain disorders without drugs. However, existing TMS devices have limited ability to stimulate the brain precisely and doing so requires expensive equipment and uncomfortable headgear. This project will develop a cheaper and more comfortable tool to position precisely the TMS wand based on tracking of the patient’s face, which could improve the patients’ experience and clinical outcome. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-associated cognitive decline is a significant public health challenge with no effective treatments that will only have increased disease burden with an aging population. Studies of age-associated changes in the gut microbiome and its effects on disease, especially cognitive decline, are limited. Determining the role of the microbiome in age-associated cognitive decline has the potential to identify novel mechanisms and therapeutic targets to combat aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To overcome the scarcity of donor livers for transplantation, hepatocytes generated from human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSC) could provide an unlimited supply of cells to treat liver diseases with cell therapy; however, preparing hiPSC-derived hepatocyte-like cells (HLC) that can repopulate diseased livers remains a challenge and a major gap which the current proposal targets. Given the known immaturity and poor survival of HLCs in vivo in comparison to primary cells, we propose that engineering HLCs to express key regenerative and maturation factors represents a potential strategy to overcome the obstacles of HLC therapies. This approach includes HLCs engineered to express maturation factors and activate mitogen pathways in combination with the use of clinically safe nucleoside-modified mRNA technology, with the goal to develop successful HLC-based treatment for liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leptin is a hormone that acts on multiple organs, including the immune system and bone. The proposed research tests the hypothesis that leptin, acting on subsets of immune cells, is a key positive contributing factor to normal bone accrual and turnover balance, but also enhances bone loss caused by chronic inflammation. This knowledge is important because failure to accrue sufficient bone mass and bone loss due to chronic inflammation contribute to bone fractures in the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Working memory (WM) deficits are a transdiagnostic feature of adolescent psychopathology that substantially contribute to poor clinical and functional outcomes. This proposal will utilize a multimodal neuroscientific approach to investigate whether non-invasive brain stimulation can modulate the neural mechanisms underlying adolescent WM deficits. Directly in line with NIMH priorities, we will identify the contributing roles of prefrontal and parietal regions in WM processes, as well as identify optimal targets and parameters for novel brain-based treatments in adolescent psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is rising worldwide, with an estimated 3 million cases in the United States alone. IBD poses a substantial socio-economic burden, as patients diagnosed with the illness tend to have far higher healthcare use and often go on to develop comorbidities, and many treatment options remain ineffective. This research proposal aims to identify a novel mechanism of tissue protection governing intestinal health and inflammation, which in turn will elucidate targets for therapeutic intervention to prevent or treat IBD.

PHR: Project Narrative Despite improvements in cardiovascular care, heart failure and arrhythmia remain the most common late manifestations of heart disease, and are poorly defined in heritable/congenital heart disease populations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will identify new genes and genetic variants that increase risk of Alzheimer’s Disease. Our work will break down existing barriers by massively increasing the speed, throughput, and accuracy with which we can identify causal SNPs and their mechanisms of action. This will provide new Alzheimer’s Disease risk genes for further study and drug development, establish a tractable biological system in which to study these genes, and establish a new paradigm for GWAS SNP interpretation that can be applied to other cell types and other diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Lipid droplets are central to regulating intracellular energy availability. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Biofilms have been associated with a number of intestinal diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease and colorectal cancer. I propose further characterize the role of biofilm formation in E. coli colonization of the intestinal tract and to use this model system to understand more generally the role of biofilms in disease pathogenesis at the intestinal mucosal interface. The goal of this project is to develop a deeper understanding of bacterial competition in biofilms and use this knowledge to engineer the mucosally-associated microbiota to modulate intestinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Members of the transient receptor potential ion channel (TRP) family act as biological sensors by decoding various physiological cues in the environment to regulate vascular and neuronal function. The proposed study is relevant to NIH’s mission because it will provide the molecular basis by which bioactive lipids modulate the function of vascular and neuronal TRP ion channels. The proposed research is relevant to public health because dietary consumption of polyunsaturated fatty acids, among other bioactive lipids, is known to prevent cardiovascular diseases and ameliorate neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) has an etiologic role in several human cancers. KSHV infects tumor cells and persists in these cells in a latent state. This work investigates the mechanisms this virus uses to allow it to be maintained in tumor cells. A better understanding of these viral mechanisms may allow development of strategies which prevent KSHV cancers.

PHR: Project Narrative The ability of clinicians, health systems and researchers to identify patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (ADRD) is limited. This project will apply machine learning to natural language processing (NLP) of electronic health record data and automated speech analysis (ASA) of patient-doctor conversations during primary care visits to identify patients with MCI and ADRD using automated and scalable procedures. The analytic algorithms will be developed with neurocognitive assessment data on 800 primary care patients in New York City and validated in an independent sample of 200 patients in Chicago. 1

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal application proposes to continue a progressive and tiered training program that will further develop researchers and research teams able to carry out the research agenda of the Eastern Africa GEOHealth Hub and to facilitate the translation of the research findings into impactful actions by key stakeholders. The Hub will train 6 Hub Scholars (building on 11 Hub Scholars from the first funding cycle), degree level trainees (5 PhD and 12 MS/MPH degree candidates), research team trainees across the three LMIC primary partners, and additional trainees from stakeholders as well as three more training partner countries who are all expected to become national leaders in environmental and occupational health research. The Hub will continue to train multidisciplinary research teams, develop curricular materials for academic and stakeholder institutions, and foster evidence translation and implementation with a long-range goal of establishing a sustainable Hub for the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long term success of human hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation is curative in many blood and other disorders but challenged by lack of sufficient numbers of HSCs. Studies proposed here are designed to enhance human HSC potency by modulating their non-nuclear organelles specifically the activity of lysosomes and their communication with mitochondria. To achieve this goal, the work will elucidate mechanisms of lysosomal regulation of human HSC potency and likely to identify a new lysosomal-based mode of intervention to improve human HSC engraftment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Workforce diversity in STEM is critical to our success as a nation and our ability to address major public health challenges. However, as a nation, we have fallen short of our STEM workforce diversity goals, a failure that has been long attributed to the “leaky academic pipeline” but in reality, is related to a convergence of complex and interrelated social and environmental factors. The Brain Explorer Academy uses neuroscience and a digitally connected social-ecological framework to deploy and evaluate a multi-year, interdisciplinary training program for high school students from underrepresented minorities to stimulate their interest and persistence in STEM disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative: Native Tribes have been, and continue to be, exposed to significant amounts of toxic waste as a product of environmental injustice and are at an increased risk of adverse health outcomes due to contaminated soils that grow traditional food sources, degraded qualities of water, food, and air, and loss of infrastructure, and cultural practices that build community strength and resiliency. Such is the case for the Ramapough Lunaape Turtle Clan in NJ (1 of 3 Clans of the Ramapough Lunaape Nation) who live in a 500 acre toxic waste site created by a decade of industrial dumping of thousands of gallons of paint sludge in northern NJ. As no culturally-meaningful interventions have been implemented for theTribal community that could promote health and well-being to date, we propose to build on our long and equitable Tribal-academic partnerships with the Ramapough to advance tradition-centered, evidence-based best practice strategies for sustainable environmental food systems that address food insecurity, nutritional deficiency, and chronic disease health outcomes among the Ramapough Turtle Clan communities disproportionately affected by environmental contamination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative To behave properly cells must integrate information coming from many extracellular stimuli. Cells accomplish this by forming transient complexes of multiple proteins, and causing these proteins to change their shapes and surface charges. We are developing new techniques to make this process visible, so we can study its role in immune cell function, cancer metastasis and basic cellular mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Although treatment with immune checkpoint inhibitors (CPIs) has significantly improved outcomes for patients with cancer, CPIs are associated with a diverse spectrum of immune-related adverse events, the majority of which are skin related (ircAEs), which may result in CPI dose interruption or discontinuation. The overall objective of our current grant application is to identify pathways to mitigate ircAEs associated with cancer immunotherapy. Elucidation of the diverse mechanisms leading to ircAEs will result in actionable approaches for their management and improve cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Quick and confident recognition of stroke at initial clinician contact increases the odds of successful treatment and positive outcome. The proposed clinical study aims to determine whether the detection of molecules originating from damaged brain tissue in the blood can indicate if a stroke is occurring in patients who have neurological symptoms. If successful, the work will lay the immediate groundwork for the development of rapid blood-based diagnostic tests that could be used to aid in the recognition of stroke in emergency medicine settings.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative  Our proposal will be focused on increasing capacity in the Middle East and North Africa in environmental health research and especially with regards to climate change. There is a major gap in research capacity in this field despite the region is already suffering the health consequences of climate change in terms of increased frequency of heatwaves, desert dust storms, and drought and low frequency of precipitation. The hub will create the platform to expand and sustain this focus as the state-of-art go to entity in the region to help the populations and decisions makers address the climate change health impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radical S-adenosylmethionine enzymes, which are iron-sulfur-dependent proteins, catalyze myriad cellular reactions using free radical mechanisms, including the methylation of small molecules, DNA, RNA, proteins, and lipids. Many of these methylation reactions are involved in numerous processes important in human health, such as antibiotic biosynthesis and resistance, and the biosynthesis of essential cellular molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative The Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS), Division of Public Health (DPH) is applying to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for the Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) Funding Opportunity Announcement Number: RFA-DP-21-001, Component A: Core Funding. PRAMS is an ongoing survey of mothers who recently had a live birth, conducted by the CDC and local agencies. This fourth cycle of funding will allow Wisconsin PRAMS to continue for the project period May 1, 2016 – April 30, 2021. PRAMS will survey mothers asking about maternal behaviors before, during, and after pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Since the ancient Greeks, sulfur containing molecules have been used in a medicinal context, and they continue to represent a large portion of new FDA approvals. Despite their prevalence, existing methods to prepare C-S bonds lack the chemo- and enantioselectivity that is necessary in targeted pharmaceutical synthesis. This proposal describes the regio- and enantioselective preparation of thioethers from feedstock olefins using copper(I) hydride catalysis in conjunction with a sulfenamide-based sulfur transfer reagent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Many individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) receive no treatment, including evidence-based medications. Prior studies of AUD medication use primarily relied on claims data and so could not account for whether someone received a prescription in the first place. This study, using linked electronic health record data on medication orders and claims data (combined with qualitative methods), will allow more precise identification of where individuals fall off the path of AUD medication use, and the outcomes associated with different treatment trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Copper is an essential trace nutrient critical to human health. A significant number of diseases, including Wilson disease, Menkes syndrome, or Alzheimer’s disease, are caused by impaired copper transport and regulation. The goal of this project is to create molecular tools that will enable the elucidation of copper trafficking pathways in these diseases, and thus support the development of novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches that will aid in combating copper related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative – public health relevance  Perturbation of inositol metabolism is associated with pathologies as diverse as psychiatric and neurological illnesses, myopathies, cancer, and diabetes. The proposed studies will lead to the first molecular model of regulation of inositol synthesis in mammalian cells and demonstrate how inositol deprivation affects mitochondrial function and the cellular stress response. The identification of specific pathways that are perturbed as a result of inositol deprivation will provide insights into the tumor-suppressive effects of upregulating inositol synthesis and may suggest candidates for new mood stabilizing inositol-depleting drugs for the treatment of bipolar disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This application describes a research plan for a longitudinal study in bipolar disorder and typical developing young adults aimed at capturing biological risk factors that are predictive of alcohol use disorders. The goals of the research are to investigate longitudinal changes in subjective response to alcohol, placebo response, corticolimbic neural trajectories, stress, and emergence of alcohol misuse and problems during the young adult epoch and interactions with bipolar disorder. Findings may inform prediction models of alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative disorders are a significant public health and economic problem affecting about 450 million people worldwide are the leading cause of disability and ill-health according to world health organization. The main objective of the proposal is the development, validation and translation of a non-invasive diffusion MRI assay, that enable efficient encoding of diffusion parameter space to characterize the neurodegenerative processes that drive the progression of neurodegeneration. We validate the framework in a cohort of Huntington's disease, with the prospect of extending these studies to understand the neurodegenerative cascade in the entire class of neurodegenerative diseases, including Parkinson's and Alzheimer's.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compulsive drug seeking despite negative consequences is a hallmark of opioid addiction, and such behaviors are associated with abnormal activity patterns in the prefrontal cortex. Characterizing the precise neuronal circuits in prefrontal cortex that contribute to drug seeking is therefore critical for developing effective treatment strategies that can normalize brain activity and reduce relapse vulnerability. Here, we use cutting edge neuro- technologies to determine the function of precisely-defined prefrontal circuits for cue-induced heroin seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered that the metabolic state of ketosis profoundly inhibits - and even reverses - the progression of polycystic kidney disease (PKD) in animal models. Inducing ketosis with dietary interventions or mimicking it by administration of the natural ketone body β-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) all proved highly effective in inhibiting renal cyst proliferation and ?brosis. Here, we propose to identify the most effective treatments and study the underlying mechanisms in order to be able to design a future clinical trial to test the ef?cacy of dietary interventions and/or treatment with BHB, an inexpensive and safe compound that is FDA-classi?ed as a dietary supplement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative I discovered that CDK13, a gene expression kinase, is mutated in patient melanomas and is required to activate a nuclear RNA surveillance pathway. When CDK13 is mutated, prematurely terminated RNAs accumulate and are translated, resulting in more aggressive melanoma. Having recently identified recurrent mutations in RNA surveillance pathway members in cancer, I propose to determine how CDK13 mutations and loss of nuclear RNA surveillance members cause more aggressive melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with anemia, including sickle cell anemia, are at risk for not having enough oxygen for full brain growth and development. Upon conclusion of this study, we will have a greater understanding of the interaction of lower oxygen supply and brain development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Generalized approaches for laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR), a prevalent syndrome in which laryngeal symptoms are attributed to gastroesophageal reflux disease, have resulted in poor patient outcomes, inappropriate utilization of healthcare resources, and tremendous expenditure. Information from this biomarker targeted randomized sham-controlled clinical trial of the upper esophageal sphincter assist device will be analyzed using novel latent class and microbiomics methods in order to define a phenotype guided treatment approach for LPR and inform the mechanistic understanding of reflux associated oral microbiome changes as a source of chronic inflammation in LPR. These findings will ultimately contribute to developing modern practice paradigms for LPR in order to optimize patient care, as well as provide fundamental knowledge about mechanistic pathways and symptom generation in LPR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unchecked intestinal inflammation predisposes inflammatory bowel disease patients to colitis associated cancer (CAC). Delineating the epithelial-specific and immune pathways that contribute to CAC is critical to identifying genetic factors in patients that place them at increased risk for developing CAC. In this application, the candidate outlines a detailed scientific plan to mechanistically dissect the role of an intestinal epithelial repair protein, LINGO2, in control of colitis and its complications with the goal of unraveling the pathophysiology of CAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE: Individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) often suffer from depression, but the underlying neurobiological reasons for this co-occurrence are poorly defined. The current application will utilize a rodent model of AUD, similar to the human condition of alcohol dependence, to understand why individuals continue to drink despite negative affect during withdrawal - at the molecular, cellular, and behavioral levels. If our hypotheses bear out, this work will (1) identify the biochemical underpinning of the antidepressant/negative reinforcement properties of ethanol, (2) have broad implications to other complex brain disorders, and (3) help inform future applications with new druggable targets and reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria are central hubs of eukaryotic cells, playing essential roles not only for energy production but also in the regulation of metabolic pathways, innate immune responses and cell death/survival fate. Post-translational modifications (PTMs) of mitochondrial proteins are numerous and provide an important link between the regulation of mitochondrial functions and inter-organelle communication, and the availability of cellular metabolites. A better understanding of the role of mitonuclear communication pathways in modulating mitochondria functions through ubiquitination and ADP-ribosylation may provide important insights about metabolic regulatory strategies to be exploited therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Severe bilateral loss of vestibular sensation – the inner ears' sense of balance – causes chronic dizziness, blurry vision during head movement, a constant need to exert conscious effort to do things that are normally automatic (like walking without wobbling or falling), and inability to drive or swim safely. In an already FDA- approved and actively recruiting first-in-human trial, we have recently shown that a vestibular implant that senses head motion and artificially stimulates the vestibular nerve – much like the way a cochlear implant helps treat people with severe hearing loss – helps to improve the signs and symptoms of bilateral vestibular loss caused by medicines that are sometimes toxic to the inner ear. The research project we now propose will (1) determine whether a vestibular implant can help the nearly 1 million adults disabled by bilateral vestibular loss that is idiopathic (has no identified cause); (2) assess the long-term safety and effectiveness of vestibular implants by supporting and tracking the performance of the pioneering subjects already implanted; (3) lay the groundwork for the first pivotal multicenter trial of vestibular implantation; (4) help ensure that vestibular implantation is available at centers in the United States; and (5) create a solid foundation from which vestibular implantation can grow, as did cochlear implantation, to become a routine and effective treatment, a robust and diverse field of clinical investigation, and a technology that opens new lines of scientific inquiry into how the inner ear and brain work together to help you see clearly, walk automatically, and focus your thoughts on where you are headed and why rather than on how to avoid falling on your way there.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The healthy human immune system responds to pathogens in the body by rapidly increasing the number of lymphocytes, specialized cells that can identify and attack the invaders. This proposal focuses on the enzyme CTP synthase, which controls production of a key molecular building block that is needed to increase lymphocyte numbers. By learning how CTP synthase is controlled and how it can be inhibited we will lay the groundwork for therapies that suppress the immune system, for example in the treatment of hyperactive immune response in autoimmune diseases, or to prevent the rejection of transplanted organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because kidney cancer is one of the top 10 most common cancers in both men and women. The most common and aggressive subtype of kidney cancer is clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC), where the 5-year survival rate for patients with advanced disease remains only 11%. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NIH, and the NCI, because it will provide mechanistic insights into the mechanisms driving metabolic reprogramming in ccRCC through RNA methylation and will provide the foundation for a novel class of therapeutic agents in the treatment of this lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the absence of new therapeutic strategies, the goal of providing universal HIV-1 treatment and ending the HIV-1/AIDS epidemic is unattainable. HIV-1 persists in a stable reservoir of latently-infected cells, representing the major obstacle to achieving HIV-1 remission. As part of NIH’s mission to end the HIV-1 epidemic, this project seeks to understand whether the CARD8-inflammasome can be harnessed to eliminate infected cells, which may lead to control of HIV-1 without the requirement for lifelong treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is an incurable primary brain tumor. The Wnt pathway is frequently dysregulated in many cancers, including glioblastoma, underscoring it as an important therapeutic target. This work will reveal a novel mechanism by which Wnt signaling is activated independent of Wnt ligand-receptor binding. If successful, the findings of this study will provide new strategies to improve treatment for glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malignant gliomas, which include glioblastoma, account for 46.6% of primary (de novo) brain tumors that often progress or recur as a more aggressive phenotype and are nearly uniformly fatal. Currently, the monitoring of recurrence and progression is performed by imaging which is limited by its sensitivity, dependent on the tumor size-threshold, the lack of specific criteria to diagnose and/or differentiate glioma from other conditions (e.g. CNS lymphoma, pseudoprogression or radiation necrosis), and availability and feasibility for some patients. This study proposes to establish a non-invasive approach using DNA methylation to improve detection and surveillance of glioma, with the ultimate goal of fine-tuning treatment by providing insight into the evolving tumor biology in real time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There exists a knowledge gap in obesity and adipocyte biology, as there are still no effective anti-obesity drugs or treatments. Recent identification of previously unannotated microproteins in human and mouse genomes has been made possible by breakthroughs in genomic and proteomic technologies. By applying these new methods on adipocytes, this study will characterize adipocyte microproteins that affect adipogenesis and insulin signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The continued generation of new neurons in a region of the brain known as the hippocampus is involved in regulating various types of cognitive behavior. We have found that noggin, a molecule that modulates a specific signaling system in the brain, regulates neurogenesis and behavior. The proposed studies seek to understand how noggin works in the brain with a long- term goal of defining specific targets for drug treatment that may help to maintain normal cognitive function.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because millions of Americans suffer from sleep disturbances that contribute to persistent pain. The mechanisms underlying this contribution are largely unknown and require rigorous, multidisciplinary studies to increase our scientific knowledge of this clinical problem. The project is relevant to NIH's mission because identifying mechanisms that that link the comorbidity of sleep disturbances and persistent pain may result in new complimentary treatment paradigms that improve patient quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study seeks to develop and test an intervention designed to reduce vaping behaviors and the likelihood of future combustible cigarette smoking onset among young adults. The study provides support for a very brief, inexpensive, single-session, and mobile phone-based intervention that can reach a wide range of diverse and vulnerable youth populations who may not otherwise seek vaping cessation services. By developing and testing an intervention that reduces vaping and the likelihood of smoking onset, the study also has the potential to reduce the burden of both smoking and vaping long-term effects, including addiction, pulmonary and cardiovascular disease, and cancer.

PHR: In anticipation of this application to become a clinical center with the MFMU Network, we have spent the last decade cultivating a culture amongst our academic Maternal-Fetal Medicine (MFM) team of 38 physicians which encourages clinical research as part and parcel to reducing maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. In addition to far exceeding the requisite diversity and number of patients with “high risk” conditions our vibrant and cohesive large academic MFM Division cares for, we have gained MFM clinical trials experience with a well-versed and high performance 24/7 research staff, and developed several unique special strengths to enrich the impact and science of the MFMU. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative We will use an innovative approach allowing identification of activated neurons at single-cell resolution throughout the entire brain to identify the whole-brain functional networks that are associated with four fundamental phases in the development of tobacco use disorder: acute nicotine, chronic dependence, acute withdrawal, and protracted abstinence. The overarching hypothesis is that coordinated activation of long-range cholinergic neurons is associated with decreased whole-brain modularity and withdrawal-related behaviors that can be partially normalized using FDA-approved medications. This project will identify the networks activated during critical phases relevant to tobacco use disorder and electronic cigarette use and identify the mechanism at the network level that underlies the effect of FDA-approved medications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: An epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) occurs in almost all animals, moving cells that originate in an epithelium to produce the connective tissue of the embryo. In embryos this process must be completed, and in carcinomas the EMT process is co-opted and must be stopped. Thus, in order to prevent birth defects, and to stop metastatic events it is crucial to understand how the EMT works, which is the goal of this project.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Congenital heart disease is the most common birth defect and can be missed during pregnancy scan and newborn exam leading to delayed detection, poor outcomes, and death. This application seeks to test and develop a critical congenital heart disease screening machine learning algorithm that combines the current screening standard, oxygen saturation, with additional features to assess blood flow and perfusion and incorporates dynamic data from both inpatient and outpatient settings. This approach has the potential to increase infant survival and will develop neonatal specific devices using artificial intelligence driven diagnostics, which are priorities to the NICHD Pregnancy and Perinatology Branch and Obstetric and Pediatric Pharmacology and Therapeutics Branch.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To reach HIV epidemic control, Zambia needs to develop local implementation science capacity to create innovative ways to reach key and vulnerable populations with HIV service delivery. To train this cadre of implementation scientists, we propose the Zambia Education Network for Implementation Science Training in Health (ZENITH), a partnership between Zambia's University Teaching Hospital (UTH) and the University of Maryland Baltimore (UMB) that focuses on building implementation science (IS) capacity at UTH. ZENITH will build IS capacity through 1. an Implementation Science Institute at UTH (short-term training); 2. an online MHS in Implementation and Dissemination Science at UMB (medium term); and 3. PhD at UMB (long term); all coupled with twinned senior and junior mentors and a monthly research ECHO seminar.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): LESCANO, Andres G. Emerging infections continue to be primary concerns in Peru, South America and the world. Zika erupted in the Americas after quietly circulating in Brazil for nearly two years with a catastrophic and yet unexplained impact on microcephaly and the overall Zika congenital syndrome. The Peruvian north coast of Peru recently suffered its largest dengue outbreak on record after the 2017 Coastal El Niño event appeared without warning, leading to nearly 70,000 cases and 89 recorded deaths. Antimicrobial resistance continues to advance worldwide despite major efforts to promote the rational use of antibiotics while Chapare arenavirus re-emerged in neighboring Bolivia just a few weeks ago. Early detection and effective response to future outbreaks of emerging diseases will required better-trained epidemiologists, in larger numbers, and present in high-risk areas. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ER+/HER2+ breast cancer comprises ∼13% of all breast cancer, with intensive crosstalk between ER and HER2 signaling. Various combinations of endocrine and anti-HER2 targeted agents are under clinical evaluation, yet only a partial response has been achieved. This proposal seeks to identify mechanisms of ER/HER2 crosstalk at the single-cell level that accounts for the partial response of ER+/HER2+ patients to dual ER/HER2 blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Musculoskeletal disorders affect over 250 million people worldwide. The ability to accurately measure musculoskeletal kinematics is necessary to advance our understanding of normal joint function, the changes associated with musculoskeletal diseases, the effects of treatment, and results of treatment refinement. The aim of this proposal is to develop a state-of-the-art, open-source software program to simplify and improve image- based musculoskeletal analysis. The software we develop will broaden access to image-based kinematic analysis and provide a dynamic platform for the sharing of novel analysis algorithms, methodologies, and data, which will hasten translation to clinical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: There are no biomarkers to identify individuals at increased risk of developing Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Related Disorders (ADRD) in the preclinical period. Current tests focus on the proteinopathies associated with these diseases, but once these pathological variants develop it may be too late for treatments to be effective. We will identify a set of RNA and protein biomarkers in extracellular vesicles isolated from saliva to identify individuals in the preclinical period prior to the onset of proteinopathy when treatments may be more successful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychosis prevents individuals from meeting their basic needs and leading meaningful lives and early intervention mitigates its effects, but services are often undermined by problems of engagement. The objective of this proposal is to advance the literature on effective pragmatic interventions for engagement, processes that lead to successful engagement, and the nature of engagement with services across time and contexts with a focus on individuals with FEP from hard-to-reach communities. Findings may help improve individuals’ engagement with public mental health services during the early stages of psychotic illness across the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) represent a group of highly aggressive soft tissue sarcomas with poor prognosis that occur in distinct clinical settings: neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1)-associated (45%), sporadic (45%) or radiotherapy (RT)-associated (10%). Most MPNSTs have NF1 loss (>90%hence, NF1- deficient), CDKN2A loss (~80%) and PRC2 loss (~60-80%), but they are resistant to MEK inhibitor alone due to feedback reactivation of PDGFRA/B pathways. Here, we propose a phase I/II study of a novel combination of ripretinib and binimetinib that targets both the PDGFR and MAPK pathways in patients with NF1-deficeint MPNSTs and to evaluate for biomarkers for MAPK pathway inhibition, as well as to investigate the MPNST tumor heterogeneity and plasticity during tumor evolution and in response to combination treatment using single cell analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain stroke often leads to permanent disability of the hands. We are studying a new approach that can help restore hand function by using a device that delivers electricity to the brain during sleep. Sleep is known to improve learning and memory and here we plan to find out exactly how we can harness it in two brain regions to help people recover the use of their hand after a stroke.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Signals from the gastrointestinal tract have strong effects on pancreatic endocrine control of glucose metabolism. The proposed research will investigate direct neuronal connections between the gut and the pancreas, so called entero-pancreatic plexus, and the role it plays in regulation of insulin secretion. This work will assess a novel way in which the gut can influence the pancreas providing for opportunities to identify novel targets for understanding the etiology and treatment for pervasive metabolic diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer in women worldwide and is a leading cause of cancer- related death in women in underdeveloped countries. Although most cervical cancer is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), HPV infection alone is not sufficient for women to develop cancer. Our goal in this proposal is to determine if Chlamydia infection can serve as a co-factor that can trigger women infected with HPV to develop cancer, by showing that Chlamydia infection can make HPV infection more efficient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Narrative  Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC) is a slow-growing salivary gland tumor that is treated by surgery and radiation, often leaving patients disfigured and with significant morbidity. Many ACC patients survive more than 10 years after the standard therapy of surgery and radiation, but a fraction succumb much more quickly and others acquire distant metastases or relapse 5 or more years after the initial treatment. This project will use detailed RNA sequencing analyses to learn more about the biology of ACC tumors, to identify the patients at highest risk of relapse and to translate our findings to clinical laboratories so the information can be successfully used to help patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Genome sequencing of melanomas and other skin cancers have identified many mutations that reoccur in tumors derived from different patients, and it has been presumed that these recurring mutations have important roles in causing the tumor. However, our data indicate that many of these recurring mutations are likely not important for carcinogenesis, but instead arise from elevated UV damage caused by the binding of transcription factor proteins to DNA. This proposal will use a new method to map the levels of UV damage at recurring mutation sites, in order to prioritize likely driver mutations in skin cancers by triaging those mutations that are merely caused by elevated UV damage levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease is a leading cause of death in the U.S., partly due to the inability of muscle cells in the adult heart to divide. In sharp contrast, muscle cells in young mice divide robustly after a heart attack and can regenerate. Completion of the proposed studies will identify proteins in the young mouse heart that promote cardiac cell division, with the hope of applying these findings to treat human cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Nerve damage during neurosurgery is often caused by the challenge of differentiating nerves from their surrounding tissues. This project seeks to design, construct, and implement a new tool that can visualize nerves across the whole surgical field and place it directly into the hands of skull-base surgeons. In the long term, a tool such as this could result in a decrease in nerve injury rates and a reduction of the related morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Home radon is a ubiquitous carcinogen that is known to alter inflammatory activity in the body and poses a significant threat to families across the United States. Despite abundant research linking even low-grade chronic inflammation to aberrations in neural development, and to the development of psychological symptoms, research has yet to examine the degree to which radon exposure is linked to these neural and behavioral phenotypes. The present study will leverage a robust multimodal neuroimaging approach, coupled with blood-based markers of peripheral inflammation and psychometrically-sound neuropsychological assessments, to investigate the pathways through which chronic radon exposure and toxin-induced changes in inflammation are associated with brain function, and cognitive and mental health in youths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Continuing to reduce the rate of tobacco smoking in the US depends on the availability of rigorous training programs to ensure the availability of scientists trained in patient-oriented tobacco dependence research. For the first cycle of my K24, I provided training to 32 mentees (21 new since 2018), yielding 50 papers with mentees and 7 papers with mentees under review or in revision (>230 total by mentees) and 32 grants, including 5 Ks and 11 R01s, 3 as a New Investigator PI, vs. 25 mentees, 34 publications with mentees, and 2 Ks and 2 R01s in the preceding 17 years. For the first cycle of the K24, I also augmented my tobacco POR by building expertise in implementation science through training and by pilot testing the use of the nicotine metabolite ratio for personalizing tobacco treatment as an implementation strategy to increase use of tobacco treatments, which has led to six new grants in tobacco and implementation science, 4 focused on testing the NMR in varying clinical settings. In this renewal, I will sustain the mentoring program in tobacco and implementation science POR that I established with the first K24 cycle and continue to grow our tobacco and implementation science research, including in the context of HIV clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Transporters in the kidney play important roles in the elimination of drugs, nutrients, and hormones. SLC22A24, a transporter, has been shown to transport drugs and hormones across cell membranes. In this study, we will discover its role in the kidney of mice and healthy volunteers; our studies will lead to a new understanding of the role of SLC22A24 in human biology and drug response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal expansion of blood cells carrying acquired mutations in DNMT3A is common in older adults and associated with an increased risk of developing hematological malignancies and cardiovascular disease. Molecular mechanisms underlying these associations are poorly understood. The objective of this project is to examine the impact of DNMT3A mutations on the inflammatory response of human myeloid cells, with the ultimate goal of identifying novel therapeutic approaches for the prevention and treatment of inflammatory diseases associated with DNMT3A mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to determine how higher-order thalamus interacts with different populations of GABAergic interneurons to mediate inhibition in the mouse prefrontal cortex (PFC). Using a combination of electrophysiology, optogenetics and 2-photon microscopy, we will examine how two thalamic inputs interact with a variety of interneurons, how these cells synapse onto other excitatory and inhibitory cells, and how a subset of interneurons contacts the dendrites to inhibit local Ca2+ signaling. Our experiments will help elucidate how the thalamus interacts with the PFC to support cognitive function and how this may go awry in mental health disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Of the 12 million children in the USA growing up bilingual, about 1 million experience Developmental Language Disorder (DLD), a disorder in language learning and use. Currently there is no guidance for speech language pathologists (SLPs) as to the language of intervention for bilingual children with DLD with differing degrees of proficiency with English or Spanish. This project will examine the relationship between relative language proficiency and the language of intervention, considering monolingual intervention in English and Spanish and bilingual intervention presented by alternating English and Spanish treatment sessions with the goal of improving language outcomes and thereby strengthening long-term academic achievement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is growing at an alarming rate in the U.S, and these patients are at significantly greater risk for developing hypertension and cardiovascular disease. Women are twice as likely as men to develop PTSD, a chronic stress disorder that may negate the cardiovascular protection conferred by female hormones before menopause. This study of the neural and vascular consequences of PTSD in premenopausal women will help inform the development of therapies to improve cardiovascular health in this growing and high-risk population of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project aims to understand both how complex neuronal tissues differentiate during human development and how genetic variation can affect this process by studying two highly medically relevant, in vitro, temporally dynamic differentiation systems that faithfully recapitulate fetal differentiation patterns of the brain. For each of these differentiation systems, we will carry out aims that span efforts toward mapping, perturbing, modeling, validating, and learning from single cell derived molecular data sets, with a goal of learning DNA sequence elements that drive gene expression programs during developmental timepoints. This understanding will provide mechanistic insight into how DNA sequence elements cooperate to bring about cell state and fate changes and help identify the genetic determinants of diseases of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative T cell receptor recognition of peptide-MHC epitopes is the nexus of adaptive immune recognition. “Decoding” this interface has the potential to drive innovation in diagnostics and therapeutics, but is currently limited by the lack of sufficient data for modeling and new computational approaches incorporating sequence, structure, and transcriptional data. We propose an integrated program of experimental, statistical, and structural biological expertise to define the TCR:pMHC interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Ultrasound beamforming, the process of transforming ultrasound into an image, is based on the principles of wave propagation which are complex due to the soft tissue structure in the human anatomy. Currently, ultrasound imaging uses simplified models of wave propagation. Here we address these limitations with physically and anatomically realistic propagation models based on the human anatomy that can effectively train and harness the power of machine learning beamformers. This technique directly addresses the principal challenge and objective of ultrasound beamforming, which is to limit unwanted acoustical effects from superficial tissue while maximizing signal from deep targets. The advancement of the proposed technology addresses the clear clinical need to provide diagnostic imaging to the growing population of body-limited imaging cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The loss of an intimate relationship is a tragic fact in life that impacts 8 million individuals in the US annually. While there are well-defined and characterized animal models for understanding many neuropsychiatric conditions in humans, there are currently no laboratory animal models of social or relationship loss to evaluate the underlying neurocircuitry and develop targeted therapeutics for the most disruptive psychiatric disorder following loss, i.e., prolonged grief disorder. This proposal constitutes a significant advancement in developing a neurocircuit of social loss in an animal model, targeting the neuromodulation of corticostriatal brain regions by the mesolimbic DA system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite public awareness that tobacco smoke is harmful, many people still assume that marijuana smoke is benign. Moreover, cardiovascular effects of secondhand smoke exposure have remained relatively un- explored in human studies. The impact of the proposed project is that an improved understanding of the adverse cardiovascular effects of intentional or involuntary exposure to cannabis will better inform personal health behavior, advice of physicians to their patients, public health policy decisions, legal doctrines, and potential regulation of the cannabis industry and its products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Title: C-terminal Peptide of Cardiac Troponin I for the Treatment of Diastolic Heart Failure Program Narrative  Troponin I (TnI) regulates cardiac muscle relaxation and is a therapeutic target in diastolic heart failure that is a clinical condition lacking effective treatment. The C-terminal 27 amino acid peptide isolated from cardiac TnI forms a functional reagent that selectively enhances diastolic function of cardiac muscle. Our research project investigates this myofilament-based mechanism for translational development toward a targeted treatment of diastolic heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate diagnosis of the subtype of interstitial lung disease (ILD) is critical for guiding both prognosis and therapy for patients. However, ILDs with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) patterns on imaging can be difficult to discern due to their similar symptoms, pulmonary function tests, and radiographic findings. This proposal will leverage the power of peripheral blood single-cell RNA-sequencing to determine immune cell aberrations that may drive specific ILDs with UIP patterns to advance diagnoses and therapeutics for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction is a leading cause of metabolic disease, affecting 1 in ~5000 individuals and this high incidence of disease is likely due to the complex genomic basis of mitochondrial function, which requires coordinated expression of 37 genes in the mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) and more than 1000 genes in the nuclear genome. This project will dissect the joint contribution of mtDNA- and nuclear-encoded genes to gene expression variation in Drosophila and determine how environmental factors can modify these responses. These experiments will provide information about the genetic basis of mitochondrial function for pathways related to environmental stressors, and may contribute to our understanding of the genetics of mitochondrial replacement therapy and the development of pharmaceuticals that compensate for reduced mitochondrial function.

PHR: NARRATIVE With the rapid progress in oncology, there is a great need to train academic surgical oncologists who can not only deliver state-of-the art surgical care, but can also lead multidisciplinary teams as well as research programs leveraging molecular oncology and new technologies. The goal of this T32 training program is to train surgical trainees in the essential research skills necessary to be productive independent surgical investigators and leaders in surgical oncology. Our program is now entering its 35th year, and is now a sought-after program with a deep record of producing future leaders in surgical oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tuberculosis (TB) is a leading infectious disease killer among people with and without HIV in South Africa where antibiotic resistant forms of the infection are a significant public health concern. Newer treatment regimens for antibiotic resistant TB are shorter, better tolerated and have greatly improved treatment outcomes, yet access to these regimens is limited to physician-led, hospital-based programs. The BringBPaL2Me Trial will test whether it is safe and effective to offer such treatment in a primary care clinic using a nurse-led treatment model, as such, this trial has the potential to improve access to care and significantly reduce patient and health system costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT The CDC estimates that 3 million people are living with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in the United States and there is an annual infection rate of 34,000 new infections. This pU19 proposal focus on the development of a vaccine that will elicit broadly protective antibodies and cellular responses that are long-lasting. We expect that at the end of this program project, we will have a candidate vaccine to begin pre-clinical studies that will progress to Phase I/II clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – Overall Component We will use a systems biological approach to address two fundamental questions in vaccinology: (i) What are the mechanisms by which novel COVID-19 vaccines stimulate immune responses? (ii) What is the impact of the microbiome on immunity to vaccination? The highly collaborative projects and cores of the Stanford-HIPC will address these issues leading to new and potentially actionable insight about human immunity to vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The cell wall of Streptococcus mutans, the primary etiological agent of human dental caries, is composed of peptidoglycan decorated with serotype-specific glycopolymers. The proposed research investigates the structure, biosynthesis and function of the serotype c- specific glycopolymer. The outcomes of this research are expected to have a positive impact on the development of highly targeted therapeutics to control S. mutans infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: While sleep and wake dynamics are critical to animals' survival and are intertwined with psychiatric diseases, how sleep- and wake-promoting signals are integrated from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex remain unclear. In this proposal, we focus on the role of astrocytes—the most abundant non-neuronal cell type in the brain—in sensing and responding to histaminergic neuromodulatory signals, and determining the sleep/wake state of the cortex. Our results will illuminate mechanisms by which astrocytes coordinate the activity of populations of neurons across brain states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance: In this project, we seek to improve the predictive accuracy of a computerized histomorphometric predictor (OHbIC) for risk stratification, outcome prediction and added benefit of adjuvant chemotherapy for patients with oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OC-SCC) from routine H&E tissue slide images. The success of this project will pave the way for its adoption as a tissue non-destructive Affordable Precision Medicine (APM) companion diagnostic tool, allowing for the identification of OC-SCC patients for whom therapies could be either left as standard, or require “escalation”, depending on the OHbIC risk score.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A Cereblon Signaling Network in Wnt-driven Cancers In the United States, colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death. The goal of this study is to determine how a network of signaling proteins results in the initiation and growth of colorectal cancers, to discover what happens to colorectal cancer cells when proteins from this network are blocked, and to identify new strategies to inhibit the growth of colorectal cancer cells based on these discoveries. Therefore, the knowledge gained from this study may provide new ways to treat colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant disparities in maternal and infant mortality and morbidity exist in the U.S. Novel strategies, including new therapies and technologies, innovative study designs and interventions, inclusion of diverse study participants into clinical trials, and input from the stakeholders impacted by health disparities are needed to improve outcomes for pregnant and lactating people. Although California accounts for nearly one eighth of annual U.S. births, the MFMU Network lacks a West Coast site. The University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) is a pioneer in innovative research techniques and has a racially and ethnically diverse patient population, so could contribute important perspectives to the MFMU Network goals to improve pregnancy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental, behavioral and neurological disorders are the primary cause of disability, measured as disability adjusted life years lost in the United States healthcare system. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is central to our understanding of such disorders as one of the most powerful methods to study the human brain, but suffers from long exam times. In this work, we will develop and validate new techniques for rapid brain MRI using artificial intelligence tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative Brucellosis is a world-widespread disease of animals and humans inflicting significant public health burden worldwide, which is caused by the zoonotic bacterial pathogen Brucella. Brucella resides and proliferates within host cells during infection, by injecting proteins that modulate cell functions to the bacterium’s advantage. This proposal aims to characterize how several of these proteins work together to promote two key events of Brucella pathogenesis, generation of a protective intracellular niche and bacterial proliferation, which will advance our knowledge of the disease process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are proposed to underlie the toxicity of important antibiotics and antitumor agents, but these ideas have been challenged by contrary data and concerns about methodologies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative Mitochondria provide energy for cell function. Environmental insults like fluorosis or genetic diseases like Down syndrome (DS) affect mitochondria but how they affect the mitochondria of ameloblasts causing enamel defects is poorly understood. We will address this in DS mouse models and in newly developed reporter mice segregating enamel developmental stages treated with fluoride.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The alarming rise in youth suicide rates and attempts creates a tremendous public health burden yet, limited knowledge exists regarding the mechanisms associated with youth suicide in high risk groups which is imperative for primary prevention efforts. A parental history of suicidal behavior (SB) is associated with a 4-to- 6-fold increased risk of offspring SB and a younger age of onset for first suicide attempt. The objective of this study is to fill gaps in our current knowledge through examining, longitudinally, how parental history (PH status) is associated with trajectories of neurocognitive functioning (NF) and emotional reactivity/regulation (ERR), how NF and ERR constructs mediate the association between PH status and offspring SB and non-suicidal self-injury (NSSI), and test sex and race as moderators of the association between NF and ERR trajectories and offspring SB/NSSI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative ………………………………… The number of older adults undergoing surgery in the United States is dramatically increasing and they are facing unique concerns with regards to pain management in the postoperative period as unnecessary prolonged use of pain medications can cause adverse drug events. The objective of this K23 proposal is to obtain an in-depth understanding of the patterns of prolonged use of postoperative pain medications for older adults and understand the barriers and facilitators that contribute to this prolonged use in order to refine a targeted, evidence-based intervention to prevent prolonged use of postoperative pain medication in older adults and then pilot this intervention. Ultimately, the information learned from this proposal will lead to the development of clinical interventions to improve the quality of life for older adults in the postoperative period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most human complex diseases and traits are highly polygenic with GWAS disease signal spread throughout the genome, thereby implicating a large number of genes for the disease. In order to provide actionable insights to inform drug treatments and CRISPR screening assays, it is extremely important to powerfully identify and rank genes and gene sets representing biological processes based on their association to a disease or trait using both GWAS and functional genomics data. My proposed research will develop and evaluate statistical and machine learning methods to 1) to identify and rank genes for a trait using both common variant and rare variant association studies and gene-level annotations from functional data, 2) identify disease- associated gene sets characterizing cell types and cellular processes from functional data and 3) pinpoint short genomic regions (~ few 100bp in size) linked to disease-associated genes and gene sets from (1) and (2) where disease signal is concentrated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: NOVEL ROLE OF NEPHRON EPITHELIALIZATION IN NUCLEAR SIGNALING Formation of tubules is essential for the development of the kidney and urinary tract, and failure of this process results in urogenital anomalies, which occur in almost 2% of the world population and represent nearly one- fourth of all birth defects. Kidney tubule malformations result from disruption of either of two groups of proteins, the planar cell polarity (PCP) or exocyst proteins, but how they affect the formation of tubules in the developing kidney is not well understood. This study is significant because it will uncover how these protein groups work together to form the kidney tubules, improving our understanding of the mechanisms underlying prevalent birth defects involving the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer treatments harnessing the power of the immune system (immunotherapies) have revolutionized the treatment of various cancers, but they have not proven successful in patients with brain tumors, as these patients have dramatically weakened immune systems. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will examine factors that weaken these patients’ immune systems and may also impact patients with cancer outside the brain to a lesser degree. Knowledge from this proposal may uncover novel immunotherapeutic strategies and ways to reverse this immunosuppression, thereby enhancing existing immunotherapies, thus contributing to the NCI’s mission of alleviating the burden of cancer on patients.
