IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During cell division, cells inherit an identical and complete set of all chromosomes; however, mistakes sometimes occur leading to cells with abnormal numbers of chromosomes and to a condition called aneuploidy. Aneuploidy is the leading cause of pregnancy miscarriages and birth defects in humans. The goal of this proposal is to understand the causes and consequences of aneuploidy in human embryonic cells which will lead to new strategies to prevent aneuploidy and improve the success of reproductive and regenerative medicine therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to discover new principles for selective catalysis, and to apply those principles to the discovery of valuable organic reactions. The fruit of this effort will be new classes of small- molecule, chiral organic catalysts engineered to induce rate acceleration and stereoselectivity in a wide range of challenging transformations through networks of attractive non-covalent interactions. These catalysts form the basis for conceptually novel and efficient methods for the synthesis of chiral organic compounds of known or potential utility in public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension and obesity are strongly comorbid conditions that afflict an overwhelming fraction of the American populace, and hypothalamic pathways involved in coordinated control of blood pressure and metabolism are implicated in the development and maintenance of each. The current proposal will investigate the role of the angiotensin signaling within a specific subtype of neuron within the hypothalamus in normal cardiometabolic control, how that pathway is fundamentally altered during obesity, and how those alterations mechanistically contribute to the maintenance and elaboration of obesity and associated hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is the leading cause of death in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc), and many SSc-ILD patients do not respond favorably to treatment with immunosuppression. This study will investigate whether specific patient characteristics, imaging features and potential blood biomarkers, can be used to determine which patients with SSc-ILD are most likely to experience a positive improvement in their lung disease in response to immunosuppressive therapy. Integrating predictive clinical and biological factors into our SSc-ILD model of care may improve health outcomes for these patients and provide novel mechanistic insights into treatment responsive versus resistant SSc-ILD subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Prediction and prevention of psychosis is an international priority given the tremendous personal and public health burden associated with the illness. Progress in this initiative has been hindered by a poor mechanistic understanding of risk and by the siloed nature of research on the high-risk stages of psychosis versus related disorders such as depression. To inform generalizable prediction and prevention, this proposal will identify shared and differential vulnerabilities of two neurobehavioral dimensions with known relevance to psychotic and depressive illness – stress and reward processing – among youth with emerging manifestations of these disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Brain function depends on the continuous delivery of energy sources through its blood supply. Impaired blood flow through vasculature in the brain is an early event in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We found, for the first time, that pathogenic forms of tau, a protein that contributes to cause AD, accumulate in cells of the brain vasculature, causing brain vascular dysfunction. Our studies will define how pathogenic tau drives brain vascular dysfunction in AD. These studies will have a lasting impact, because they will reveal new mechanisms of AD. With our studies progress will be made towards bringing TOMA or other immunotherapies to Veterans sooner.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children’s reading and math skills are critical to their future educational outcomes, career readiness, and overall health and well-being (e.g., ACT, 2020; Cain & Oakhill, 2006; DeWalt et al., 2004; Geary, 2011; Heilmann, 2020; Krajewski & Schneider, 2009; Ritchie & Bates, 2013), yet many children struggle with math and learning to read (National Center for Education Statistics, 2020). This proposal will examine individual differences in word reading and math ability in the functional role and connectivity of executive function, an underlying cognitive mechanism of reading and math. Ultimately, this increased understanding may offer a more directed approach to improve academic skills in struggling learners, thereby increasing educational and health outcomes for at-risk children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Inflammation is a common factor among individuals with kidney disease, a major contributor of death in the US. Many aspects of kidney function are linked to the circadian clock, however, its contribution to inflammation is not well known. This project intends to define the role of the circadian clock in activation of renal inflammation, thus identifying novel targets that may be used for treatment to improve the quality of life in individuals with kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Black Americans are at higher risk of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and earlier cognitive decline than other ethnic groups in the US, with the highest risk in Black women. The proposed study of 2,500 participants from the Black Women’s Health Study (BWHS) will take advantage of the blood samples and data on stressors, illnesses, behaviors and other variables collected in the BWHS. The goal of the proposed study is to ascertain the effect of early life (e.g., childhood violence victimization) and midlife (e.g. experiences of interpersonal racism) stressors together with genetic variants and plasma biomarkers associated with AD on cognitive decline in Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Most chronic wound infections are due to the presence of biofilm, which makes the microbes causing the infection exceptionally difficult to kill. In order to combat this healthcare challenge, researchers are pursuing biofilm dispersal agents, which can induce microbes to leave the safety of the protective biofilm and become more susceptible to killing by antibiotics. In this project we will investigate the risk versus reward of using biofilm dispersal as a way to treat wound infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Women are more vulnerable to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) than men as they age, and substantial evidence suggests that declining ovarian hormones during menopause contribute to the sex difference in Alzheimer’s risk, as greater lifetime exposure to ovarian hormones (through early puberty and late menopause) predicts reduced vulnerability to AD. Prior research suggests that a reduction in ovarian hormones following menopause may promote AD through a reduction in neural metabolism or disruption of intrinsic network connectivity, but the protective effect of developmental ovarian exposure on these processes is not well understood. In the proposed research, we will test the hypothesis that greater lifetime exposure to ovarian hormones moderates AD-promoting effects of menopause by measuring lifetime ovarian exposure, cognitive function, brain metabolism, network connectivity and brain markers of AD pathology in a single study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Despite the clear beneficial effects of physical fitness and exercise to improving health during aging, we do not know the best amounts and intensities for optimal lifelong immune health. This project will address gaps in understanding how exercise improves immune system health in older patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by studying 1) how exercise training alters RA immune cell function, immune cell metabolism, and markers of premature immune cell aging; and 2) if a remotely supervised high-intensity exercise training program for older RA patients is safe, acceptable, and feasible. Results from this project will lead to novel treatments to improve inflammation and immune system health during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this K08 is to prepare the PI (Normarie Torres-Blasco, Ph.D.) to become an independent investigator to address health equity through access to culturally adapted interventions for Hispanic/Latinx patients-caregivers coping with advanced cancer. The research goal of this proposal is to refine and pilot an intervention titled: Caregivers-Patients Support to Latinx Coping with Advanced-Cancer (CASA), five 60-minute telehealth sessions for patient- caregiver dyads. This study aims to use a collaborative intervention planning framework that blends community-based participatory research and dissemination and implementation models to modify and assess the feasibility and acceptability of the CASA intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Hypoglycemia unawareness is a serious complication of diabetes resulting from recurrent hypoglycemia (RH) during intensive-insulin therapy; however little is known about the underlying mechanism due to lack of an animal model. We have established the first mouse model for hypoglycemia awareness/unawareness and our data suggest that the anti-narcolepsy drug modafinil may restore both hypoglycemia awareness and impaired glucose sensing by perifornical hypothalamus orexin glucose-inhibited (GI) neurons. This proposal seeks to define the central pathways which control the awareness of hypoglycemia and how modafinil corrects them after RH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying the protective effect of physical activity (PA) on cardiovascular structure and function, functional capacity, and heart failure (HF) development in older adults, who are at greater risk for HF-related morbidity and mortality, with the use of high throughput proteomic profiling. Identifying promising protein candidates contributing to the benefits of PA has the potential to inform protective doses of PA, which may strengthen national recommendations for PA for the prevention of HF, and to provide new targets for therapeutic intervention for HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial specific phospholipid cardiolipin plays many crucial roles in bioenergetics. In the heart, linoleic acid is specifically concentrated in cardiolipin, likely linking to proper cardiac function. This study aims to determine the molecular basis underlying the mechanisms to specifically regulate the cardiac cardiolipin, which will expand our fundamental understanding of cardiac bioenergetics, a major determinant of cardiac health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventive treatment (e.g., statins) can reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease but are most effective when targeted to high-risk individuals. New artificial intelligence techniques may predict risk of heart attack and stroke from medical imaging. The proposed study will develop and test whether artificial intelligence can identify persons at high-risk for future cardiovascular events based on chest imaging and assess whether these predictions are better than existing risk scores.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: RELEVANCE: Colorectal cancers occur in up to 8% of Veterans, in whom there is a critical need for precision oncology tools to select appropriate components of a multimodal treatment strategy for rectal cancers. Veteran rectal cancer patients could gain significant quality-of-life benefits from being selected for non-operative management due to their increased age as well as impact of surgical co-morbidities. Veteran rectal cancer patients have also specifically shown a survival benefit to targeted administration of adjuvant chemotherapy. In this VA Merit Award, we will build on our initial exciting results to validate novel computational image Rectal Response Classifier (ciRRC) tools that leverage routine MRI scans to (i) identify rectal cancer patients who can be safely recommended non-operative management as they achieved pathologic complete response after neoadjuvant therapy, as well as (ii) select high-risk rectal cancer patients who will gain added benefit from targeted chemotherapy; towards improving patient outcomes and survival in Veteran rectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bipolar disorder is associated with high rates of tobacco use (cigarette smoking) and, currently, there is a lack of effective treatments for addressing tobacco use in this population. This study will evaluate a behavioral intervention called episodic future thinking, which encourages people to actively visualize future, positive events that they think will be benefited by quitting smoking, that has the potential to intervene on some of the cognitive processes that lead to smoking behavior in bipolar disorder. This study may contribute to a new behavioral intervention that can be applied in clinical practice to target the cognitive processes that contribute to smoking in bipolar disorder and to encourage people with bipolar disorder to participate in smoking cessation treatment.

PHR: The overall goal of the Colorado StARR Program (CSP) is to recruit, train, and retain outstanding resident-investigators focused on translational research in heart, lung, and blood disorders. This career development training will be achieved through seamless integration with our ACGME-accredited Medicine, Pediatric, and Surgery housestaff training programs, a structured milestone-driven training program that includes individualized career development plans, pairing our resident-investigators with outstanding, dedicated mentors with extensive disease-specific research expertise and a wide array of cutting-edge approaches to research, and providing appropriate oversight of the mentor-mentee relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant growth in treatment options for patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has increased the importance of understanding patients’ values and preferences to determine appropriate therapy. This project aims to evaluate the feasibility of implementing a novel patient decision support tool to improve treatment decision-making for older adults with AML. This tool uses best-worst scaling, an innovative, yet robust method to elicit patient values, which may be widely applicable to other treatment settings across oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative: The cause of AD is not well understood and lacks an effective treatment. We will test the hypotheses that AD may be a pathological disorder driven by activation of a distinct microglia subset/lineage (~5% of total), resulting in neuroinflammation, amyloid deposits and cognitive decline in animal models, which will be validated using well-defined post-mortem brain tissues from AD patients. These studies will provide new insight into the pathogenic mechanisms that contribute to AD and may lead to the discovery of novel diagnostic biomarkers and new therapeutic approaches to this disease and perhaps other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decline in proteostasis is a defining feature of aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) but the signaling pathways responsible for protein quality control are only in part known. We have recently found an important role for the disaccharide maltose in preserving proteostasis in the central nervous system during aging. In this application, we propose to investigate the mechanisms responsible for the effects of maltose-induced signaling on improving proteostasis, which may help design effective therapies to preserve and/or reinstate proteostasis in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop a voice assistant (VA) to improve the quality of life and wellbeing of persons living with dementia (PLwDs) and their care partners. Specifically, the VA will deliver customized and tailored cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) at scale — one of the most effective interventions for maintaining cognitive functioning and wellbeing of PLwDs. Given the wide adoption of VAs, this project has the potential to positively impact a large population of PLwDs and their care partners including those living in remote and rural areas.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple organ dysfunction syndromes (MODS) frequently occur in pediatric patients and severe MODS patients needed Veno-Arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation support (ECMO) (label as ECMO patients) as a palliating maneuver to recover their cardiopulmonary function. The major knowledge gap exists regarding the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying MODS deterioration for their advanced life support. The proposed work will provide a comprehensive overview of cellular and molecular mechanism associated with deterioration of MODS patients who may require ECMO support, which will be applicable for early diagnostic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myopia and glaucoma pose significant public health concerns - half the world’s population is projected to be myopic by 2050 and glaucoma is estimated to affect more than 120 million people worldwide by 2040, which in turn will increase the global prevalence of myopic glaucoma significantly. Evidence shows that myopic patients are at higher risk of glaucomatous degeneration, however the mechanisms behind the myopia-glaucoma association remain unknown. The proposed research aims to identify the effect of myopia on three retinal neurovascular cell types crucial for ganglion cell survival, and their relationship with glaucoma susceptibility, in a novel non-human primate model of myopia that will be subsequently induced with glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive dysfunction is a highly prevalent feature of depression that is resistant to existing treatments and predictive of higher relapse rates, worse social and occupational functioning as well as elevated risk for neurodegenerative disorders. This proposal is a mechanistic randomized controlled trial that integrates advances in cognitive neuroscience to determine whether inhibition of tumor necrosis factor signaling via intravenous infusion of infliximab improves psychomotor speed and executive functioning in depressed individuals who exhibit an inflammatory phenotype. This research has the potential to identify an inflammatory mechanism underpinning a particularly debilitating feature of depression and to offer proof-of-concept for anti- inflammatory interventions as adjunctive treatment for cognitive dysfunction in depression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) afflicts nearly 50,000 veterans, and the military population is at special risk to develop MS compared to civilians. Despite recent medical advances, there remains a substantial unmet need for additional effective MS treatments. Injury to the brain and spinal cord in MS is caused by autoimmune inflammatory T cells that enter the central nervous system and attack the myelin sheath. T cell activity is regulated by lipid and vitamin A metabolism. Our project focuses on the role of a metabolic enzyme we recently discovered to be expressed in T cells. Inhibiting this enzyme protects animals from developing MS- like symptoms. A detailed understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of immune suppression by targeting this metabolic enzyme may lead to new approaches to treat or prevent MS and possibly other autoimmune or inflammatory disorders. If successful, this project has the potential to substantially reduce the impact of MS on veterans, their families, and the American public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this exploratory, collaborative research proposal, we investigate an innovative approach to abrogate the neuroinflammatory crosstalk that promotes Alzheimer’s disease (AD) progression using state-of-the-art technologies of nanoparticles, stem cells, and brain-like mimetic human organoids. This proposal aims to test therapeutic nanotechnology based on a series of amphiphilic macromolecule for their potential amelioration of neuroinflammation and inhibition of the progression of AD. This project is relevant to public health as it aims to suppress AD progression and inhibit neurodegeneration associated with aging disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over two-thirds of all deaths associated with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) occur in nursing homes with the quality of end-of-life care varying by type of ownership. Twelve percent of US nursing homes have received investments from real estate investment trusts (REITs) with the impact on end-of-life care being unknown. Using a novel database of REIT investments in nursing homes, this is the first study of the relationships between these investments and the quality and cost of care at the end-of-life for residents with ADRD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Early initiation of heavy drinking (prior to age 14) in Veterans is associated with higher rates of mental health disorders compared to other veterans and civilians. Further, military personnel aged 18-25, engage in heavy drinking at higher rates than their civilian peers, and those under 21 drink alcohol at the highest rates. Research shows that engaging in risky drinking behavior during this period induces persistent neurological changes. We have found, in a preclinical model, that adolescent alcohol exposure paired with adult stress induces an elevated anxiety- like behavior, which may be reversible. If awarded, this Career Development project will assess the persistence and pharmacological reversibility of the enhanced anxiety response to adult stress after adolescent alcohol exposure. We will also evaluate the neural circuits, neural and astrocytic mechanisms, and synaptic functions that underly these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Earlier identification of individuals at high risk for coronary artery disease is needed to allow for initiation of prevention strategies to reduce morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. Polygenic scores, which can estimate an individual’s genetic predisposition for disease early in life, have the potential to advance risk prediction beyond current methods based solely on clinical factors. This proposal seeks to combine newly available data and statistical methods to advance the actionability of polygenic scores by improving their performance across diverse ancestral groups, making them more interpretable in the clinical setting, and identifying new uses for them in guiding preventive therapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Osteopontin (OPN) is a protein implicated in many cancers including lung and colon cancers, and melanoma. Thrombin, the key blood clotting enzyme, cuts OPN into two fragments with new functions not seen in intact OPN. We created a knock-in (KI) mouse in which normal OPN is replaced by one resistant to thrombin cutting. Mouse melanoma growth and spreading are suppressed in the OPN-KI mice. We have identified a monoclonal antibody (mAb) A6 that binds to OPN and blocks its cleavage by thrombin. A6 suppresses melanoma growth and spreading in normal mice. We have “humanized” A6 and its efficacy against different human cancer cells will be tested in a humanized mouse model. We have developed a co-lead, mAb C6r, directed against the thrombin-cleaved OPN fragment, OPN-R. These mAbs represent a novel immuno- oncologic therapeutic in the treatment of many cancers commonly encountered in our Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Statins are a widely used class of lipid-lowering medication, yet, little is known about their effect on the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). In this project, we will leverage a unique opportunity to create a quasi-experiment using a clinical guideline in the UK and established statistical methods in economics to study the effect of statins on ADRD risk overall, and across relevant subgroups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric emergency department visits for anaphylaxis have tripled during the past decade, with mandatory prolonged observation periods driving emergency department overcrowding and excessive healthcare costs. There is a need for personalized clinical prediction models and the discovery of prognostic biomarkers to enhance patient risk stratification, optimize observation periods and prevent unnecessary hospitalizations. The research goals of this K23 award are consistent with the mission of NIAID, to better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent allergic diseases, and will improve patient outcomes and optimize healthcare utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other neurodegenerative diseases involve a loss of brain function and brain cells over time and eventually cause death, affecting one third of people over the age of 85. Recent research has found that brain cells build up new mutations in the DNA (known as somatic mutations) in AD, which appears to harm the brain cells. This proposal will test how somatic mutations are related to the progression of AD in the brain, and how they are related to the buildup of misfolded proteins amyloid-β and tau.

PHR: Project Narrative The lack of diversity among the US biomedical research workforce remains a significant challenge. The Program to Increase Diversity Among Individuals Engaged in Health-Related Research- Functional and Translational Genomics of Blood Disorders, at Augusta University will address these challenges by providing intensive mentoring and research experiences, to develop competitive grant applications, and increase diversity of the US biomedical workforce.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Promoting physical activity and healthy food intake in patient-centered ways is key to improving heart health in rural areas. This project will use a new digital health tool called PREVENT to improve healthcare quality in rural communities by providing tailored physical activity and food intake goals and offering resources and Community Health Worker support to overcome barriers to healthy behaviors. This project will provide a foundation for the candidate’s career as an independent investigator by providing focused training and the data to support a larger study of PREVENT.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Behavioral Medicine and Sleep Disorders Institute (BSM PRIDE) at the University of Miami is to continue to increase diversity in the academic workforce. This will be achieved by providing congruent mentored learning experience to an additional cadre of 48 URM faculty pursuing careers aiming at cardiovascular risk reduction through implementation of translational behavioral models. Trained URM faculty will be empowered to develop independent careers in behavioral medicine and sleep disorders research, applying innovative methods to improve health equity in minoritized communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: A hallmark of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis and Alzheimer’s disease, is the cytoplasmic accumulation of TDP-43, a nuclear DNA/RNA binding protein. This research proposal will use both yeast and mammalian models of TDP-43 to uncover the molecular role cyclin C plays in TDP-43 toxicities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a common tobacco-related condition in which progressive dilatation of the largest blood vessel in the abdomen leads to rupture and approximately 41,000 deaths world-wide annually. Given that the major risk factors for AAA include advanced age, male sex, and a history of tobacco use, it is not surprising that AAA disease is relatively common in the Veteran population. There are currently no medical therapies that prevent AAA development, rupture, or aneurysm-related death. We propose to study and identify the key mechanisms behind nicotine-induced acceleration of AAA disease, with the ultimate goal of finding novel pharmacological or genetic therapies that could inhibit AAA growth and prevent associated sickness and death. This line of research may also add insight as to how other forms of environmental exposures impact chronic cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The veteran population develops chronic kidney disease (CKD) at a higher rate than the general population. Patients with CKD are at an increased risk of fracture and if a fracture occurs, patients with CKD have a greater risk of death compared to other populations. Unfortunately, treatments aimed at reducing fracture risk in CKD patients are limited in part due to the lack of extensive studies. My research program is focused on understanding causes of bone fragility in CKD and working on approaches to minimize fracture risk. Beyond CKD, bone loss from other conditions (such as osteoporosis) affects millions of Veterans and thus our work in CKD has far reaching implications. The results of this work will provide a basis for improving the quality of life of veterans at risk of bone loss and fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive cellular therapy (ACT) is a complex, novel, and potentially life-saving therapy for patients with hematologic malignancies but is associated with significant toxicities, high symptom burden, and extreme prognostic uncertainty which results in poor end of life (EOL) outcomes. This clinical research and career development proposal will support an early stage investigator to refine and test a palliative care (PC) intervention (PEACE) tailored to the needs of patients receiving ACT and their caregivers given their profound unmet supportive care needs. The intervention aims to improve the quality of life, symptoms, coping, prognostic understanding, and EOL communication of patients receiving ACT and their caregivers and will lay the foundation to demonstrate the role of PC for improving the quality of care and lived experience of these patients and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emotional disorders are among the primary causes of disability and impairment worldwide, but predicting their course, which can be used to improve disease management and to deliver more timely and individually tailored treatment, is notoriously difficult. We propose to create a precision-medicine framework for predicting emotional disorder symptoms that leverages theoretically relevant time-series measures using modern “forecasting” machine learning methods. By promoting more accurate predictions of future symptom changes and just-in-time interventions for emotional disorders, this framework will provide a foundation for alleviating one of the major causes of disease and financial burden worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will provide mechanistic insight and novel therapeutic targets for treating cognitive dysfunction in Rett syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder with loss of cognitive, motor and sensory function in early childhood. The project uses a novel human cerebral organoid model–3D neuronal cultures generated from induced pluripotent stem cells from patients with Rett syndrome–to study how brain cells form functional connections in early life and how these networks are altered by the genetic change in Rett syndrome. Our goal is to identify strategies for restoring cellular-scale brain network activity and development to reduce disability and enable children and adults with Rett syndrome to more fully participate in their family and community life.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the spine that is accompanied by pain, disability, and irreversible joint damage. Veterans with AS have a high incidence of co-morbidities including cardiovascular disease, inflammatory bowel disease, uveitis, and psoriasis making it a significant public health concern for which there is no cure. Given the diversity in the clinical manifestations of AS, and our limited understanding of the cause of disease, we are currently unable to predict what treatment plan is best for each patient. This project uses a translational research approach to investigate the cellular mechanism by which the AS-associated gene CARD9 controls arthritis-causing T cells in AS and develop a biomarker of treatment responders in the clinic. Our study results may become the basis for new personalized-therapeutic strategies that will improve treatment responses and alleviate Veterans suffering from this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Drug-resistant epilepsy is a devastating neurological disorder that afflicts approximately 1 million people in the United States who have limited effective treatment options. Brain stimulation is a novel therapy for epilepsy that is adjustable and generally well-tolerated; however, the optimal protocols and underlying mechanisms of neurostimulation in epilepsy remain unknown. The proposed study will explore the temporal and spatial optimization of neurostimulation in epilepsy, and investigate its novel mechanistic effects on disease evolution with the ultimate goal to improve neurostimulation therapy and the lives of people with epilepsy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Social anxiety is associated with significant deficits in social and occupational functioning. The proposed study seeks to evaluate the feasibility of implementing a brief text-based intervention for decreasing social anxiety related safety behaviors among Veterans attempting to re-integrate into the workforce. Findings from this pilot will support a larger randomized controlled study examining the efficacy of the intervention for improving functional outcomes and quality of life among Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of preventable vision loss in the U.S. and disproportionately affects minorities and people with limited socioeconomic resources. The proposed study will co-design, implement, and evaluate a ride-share transportation intervention, adapted from the existing PROgram for Non- emergency TranspOrtation (PRONTO), in patients with diabetic retinopathy residing in neighborhoods with high social vulnerability with a goal to increase adherence to scheduled ophthalmology visits as a critical step in reducing vision loss. This study will prioritize the association of social vulnerability with missed ophthalmology appointments to help guide a targeted patient-centered intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Perivascular spaces (PVS) are hypothesized to have roles in brain resilience and disease. To understand their associations in aging and AD, we propose to study PVS metrics in a large, underserved aging population using an automated Frangi filter technique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increased levels of ceramides, bioactive sphingolipids in the brain, are associated with memory deficits in Alzheimer’s disease and in people with advanced age. Using the state-of-the-art lipidomics and novel genetically engineered mice where ceramide metabolism is targeted in a cell type specific manner, this project aims to understand the cellular and molecular basis of abnormal ceramide production in the brain and how it contributes to neurodegeneration and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Informal caregiving for persons with dementia (PWD) who are living at home typically involve multiple caregivers, but little is known about the full scope of caregiving experienced by the many family members and/or friends involved in caregiving for PWD in the community. The proposed research will for the first time characterize informal caregiving networks of PWD longitudinally and generate evidence on how the network characteristics affect caregivers and PWD outcomes to help identify strategies for alleviating caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial bloodstream infections (BSI) are among the most common and serious infections in solid organ transplant (SOT) recipients. Optimal immunosuppression management in SOT recipients with BSI is unknown but critical to improving outcomes. The proposed studies will identify cytokine, chemokine, immunoglobulin, and gene expression biomarkers of 30-day mortality and septic shock among SOT patients with BSI, enabling the development of an immunologic prognostic model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Aggression is often considered a “negative” behavior, but proper display of aggression is essential for self- preservation and maintenance of resources. The negative context of aggression has limited its study as a motivated behavior, yet it is critical to understand the adaptive as well as the maladaptive consequences of aggression in both sexes, in order to appreciate the underlying neurobiology and improve mental health outcomes. This proposal will advance our understanding of synaptic plasticity driving aggression reward and motivation, including the roles of glutamate and oxytocin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project investigates the link between cerebral microvascular health and brain function in Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) patients. CADASIL is the most common heritable cause of vascular dementia. Collectively, this project will provide fundamental knowledge about small vessel disease in humans and help to elucidate the link between cerebral microvascular health and clinical, functional, and cognitive impairments associated with small vessel disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 42,000 persons with spinal cord injury (SCI) are eligible for treatment in the VA Healthcare System, with direct healthcare expenditures exceeding $716 million/year. Skeletal muscle fibrosis is a pathologic and currently unresolvable consequence of SCI. Fibrosis worsens muscle force producing capacity and promotes contractures, thereby facilitating limb impairment and hindering physical rehabilitation efforts. There is no known treatment for SCI-induced muscle fibrosis because a major gap exists in understanding of the cellular and molecular signals that stimulate fibrosis after SCI. As such, significant need exists to identify these signals and to test therapeutic strategies that target muscle fibrosis in the impaired limbs after SCI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: NARRATIVE  The number of patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in the United States will continue to escalate due to the high prevalence of the two main risk factors for the disease—obesity and diabetes that are both higher within the Veteran community compared to the general public. From a public health standpoint, there are no effective medications to treat NASH, no biomarkers for disease progression, and no effective high- throughput screening technologies. The goal of the project is to benchmark the in vitro microfluidic system against two animal models of NASH. The technology has unique advantages afforded by its ability to be a high- throughput system that utilizes patient-specific cells that can be obtained with minimal intervention. Once validated here, the microfluidic system will enable improved diagnostics, uncover molecular pathways and identify new treatments for a disease that leads to liver cancer, need for transplantation, and oftentimes death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We identified MLLT3 as a critical human HSC “stemness” regulator that dictates HSC fate decisions using distinct isoforms. Both long and short isoforms of MLLT3 are highly enriched in human HSCs but become downregulated in cultured HSCs, compromising their self-renewal and engraftment. Here we will use cutting edge molecular approaches to examine the mechanisms by which MLLT3 isoforms regulate human HSC functional maturation and ability to provide sustained multilineage engratfment, which may help develop new approaches to generating HSCs for the treatment of blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Lewy body dementia is the second most common neurodegenerative dementia following Alzheimer disease and imposes significant human and economic costs. Loss of synapses, or chemical connections between nerve cells in the brain, is thought to be a major mechanism by which these dementias cause symptoms. For this project, we will study volunteers who are at risk for Lewy body dementia using simultaneous magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography to quantify the density of synapses in their brains relative to other measures of brain health, thus providing a temporal map of brain changes for use in future intervention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to construct biomarkers for risk of dementia using multiple novel EEG measures and deep learning techniques. Using the existing large datasets of >8,000 subjects from four longitudinal cohort studies, the project will also test whether the constructed biomarkers mediate or moderate the genetic influence on the risk for dementia and can facilitate a better prediction of future cognitive decline and other adverse health outcomes. This project will potentially provide a non-invasive, cost-efficient tool that can be used to identify people at risk for developing dementia and to evaluate the treatments/interventions of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is becoming the most common neurodegenerative disorder among adults, a population that is projected to grow exponentially in the coming decades. A growing body of research demonstrates that modifiable lifestyle factors are key to understanding the progression of AD from midlife – when the nascent pathologic processes underlying AD begin – to later life. This project will evaluate the associations of midlife aerobic fitness and sleep apnea with increased risk of AD pathology and dementia, making critical advances toward the early identification and potential prevention of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The disease course of chronic heart failure, a prevalent disease with high morbidity and mortality, is highly variable and our ability to predict progression on an individual level and prevent it is limited. Data from animals suggests that the gut microbiome, a community of microbes living in our gastrointestinal tract, may play a role in heart failure pathophysiology and disease progression. The goal of this project is to better understand disturbances in the gut microbiome, its interactions with the host and their joint impact on heart failure pathophysiology and disease progression in patients with chronic heart failure, which will identify novel preventative and therapeutic targets and improve risk stratification in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a major public health crisis. The goal of this project is to leverage the electronic Self-Administered Gerocognitive Examination (eSAGE), the metadata collected during eSAGE test-taking, the rich electronic health record data, and advanced machine learning techniques to develop a widely accessible, easy-to-use, and highly accurate assessment tool, its smart app and its integration with EHR systems for cognitive impairment detection. The tool will be evaluated and validated by socioeconomic disadvantaged, AD- vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Antibodies are critical components of the immune system that direct inflammation and other immune responses through interactions with receptors, which are controlled in large part by conserved sugar, or glycan, molecules on the antibody. Proinflammatory changes in antibody glycosylation have been shown to correlate with Alzheimer’s Disease and may be a predictive biomarker of disease onset and/or severity. We have developed a novel method for comprehensive profiling the glycosylation states of antibodies that we will use to decipher the glycosylation code of Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Multiple Myeloma is incurable cancer with increased prevalence among older Veterans, African Americans and those exposed to Agent Orange. Myeloma cells alter bone marrow to support their growth, causing non-healing bone damage. Current treatments do not heal bone lesions and drug resistance is common. Patients are on treatment lifelong, with new options needed at periodic relapses, putting a huge strain on the VA system. We propose to add the already approved non-cancer drug, fingolimod, to proteasome inhibitor the mainstay of myeloma treatment, to improve response and bone health. Deeper response is expected to lead to longer disease control and better quality of life. The combination will be tested in animal models of MM with effects on tumor burden and bone cells determined. Markers of response will be mapped in patients, and the combined treatment tested against patient bone marrow samples, with the goal of a rapid and efficient clinical trial within five years, which would lead to swift adoption of the combined treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a condition in which neurons of the brain cannot remove damaged and dysfunctional proteins. This proposal will test whether increasing the ability of neurons to remove these proteins improves cellular health and cognition in mice. If successful, these studies will reveal a new target for the treatment and management of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will improve our understanding of how noninvasive sensory stimulation reduces pathophysiological markers of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Using optical microscopy and preclinical models of AD, the effects of neuromodulation on brain metabolism and cerebral hemodynamics will be explored in live brains with cellular resolution. The findings will guide improvements of neuromodulation therapies as an inexpensive, nonpharmacological tool to reduce the AD pathology in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnant people are exposed to persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and non-chemical stressors which adversely impact maternal and child health outcomes, including cognitive development in offspring. African Americans, who disproportionally experience elevated rates of adverse maternal and child health outcomes, are also exposed to the highest levels of environmental hazards and social stressors. This research will leverage a prospective birth cohort of African Americans and will apply novel statistical methods to examine infant neurodevelopment in relation to a mixture of prenatal POPs and social stress exposures, better reflecting real-life exposure patterns.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Recovery from sepsis requires the body to use a large quantity of the body's amino acids and fat stores. These metabolic substrates come from tissues like muscle and fat and serve not only as an energy source but also to support and activate the immune system as well as being used to repair damaged tissues and organs. This application seeks to understand the molecular role of the Yap1/TAZ /CD14 pathway activated in the liver in sepsis and how this pathway specifically regulates whole body metabolism and muscle loss in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida parapsilosis is a major fungal pathogen that can cause invasive fungemia as a result of antimicrobial therapy-induced collateral damage to the human intestinal microbiota. This project aims to develop biology- based and data-driven mathematical models directly from patient data to investigate the ecological mechanisms underlying the intestinal expansion of C. parapsilosis in immunocompromised patients. Additionally, this project will establish a generalizable computational framework that enables the rational design of probiotic-based antifungal therapy to reduce the risk of intestinal C. parapsilosis expansion.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTH TEXAS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Neurologic and mental health complications are among the most common post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 infection. A recent study showed that Veterans surviving COVID-19 had over 80% increased risk of mental health diagnosis over the subsequent year. They might linger or worsen over time. Characteristics, predictors, and mechanisms of these complications remain unclear. We are planning to leverage a well-characterized cohort of Veterans with and without COVID-19 diagnosis to administer careful serial neuropsychological testing over up to three years to better characterize these complications and to establish whether antiviral therapy is preventive of cognitive impairment. We will also study blood biomarkers of brain damage and advanced imaging on a subset of these patients to determine whether these predict and/or explain the neurocognitive changes. A successful completion of these aims will establish benchmarks to analyze and manage neurologic and mental health changes following acute COVID-19 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid epidemic continues unabated, yet adoption of highly efficacious medication treatment remains low, particularly in residential addiction treatment programs. This application will promote the development of skills in an outstanding postdoctoral researcher whose research focuses on the implementation of state policy interventions targeting the scale-up of evidence-based practices such as medication treatment in addiction treatment settings. This award will provide the applicant with exceptional mentorship and training opportunities to gain skills needed during the K-99 phase to launch a successful career as an independent investigator during the R-00 phase conducting novel research aimed at reducing the public health harms caused by the opioid epidemic by improving access to evidence-based practices that promote long-term recovery from opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 14% of adolescents (As) and 10% of young adults (YAs), aged 18-24, use electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) and are at risk for health harms from toxicant/carcinogen exposure and long-term nicotine addiction. Evidence on how to help A/YA ENDS users quit is scant with only one randomized controlled trial which used the texting program, This is Quitting. The proposed work will identify strategies used by A/YAs to quit ENDS, probe for strategies to increase cessation engagement, and also test the feasibility in YAs of adding both financial incentives and nicotine replacement therapy to the existing cessation program, This is Quitting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to use large-scale data, such as the Alzheimer's Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP), systematically collected clinical and imaging data, and observations in the scientific literature, to identify factors that increase the risk of and protection against dementia. Motivated by the great success of knowledge graph (KG) as a cornerstone of almost all successful cognitive systems in industry, we propose to construct a novel and comprehensive AD-related knowledge graph (AD-KG) platform based on multiple curated resources, literature, and a large-scale AD-related database with multiple types of high-dimensional data in different studies that have different missing-data patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Acute pain, brought on by vaso-occlusion, is the most frequent cause of hospital admission in sickle cell disease and greatly reduces overall health and social well-being. The amino acid citrulline increases nitric oxide, which has vasodilatory properties and the potential to relieve vaso-occlusion. In this clinical trial, we will investigate whether the addition of this novel treatment, intravenous L-citrulline, will significantly impact opioid use and clinical outcomes in this high risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Frequent brain examinations are an important tool for monitoring patients after brain injury, but if excessive, may cause sleep disruption and worsened outcomes in hospitalized patients. Interrupting sleep may make people confused (delirious) and may ultimately increase risk for dementia similar to Alzheimer’s disease. Improving patients’ sleep in the intensive care unit may improve their outcomes, so this project studies whether checking brain status hourly versus every-other-hour impacts sleep quantity and short or long-term cognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children and adolescents with sickle cell disease are at risk for disease-related cognitive deficits that often impact working memory function and contribute to poor academic achievement and attainment. Prior research shows that a home-based, eHealth working memory training program (Cogmed) leads to significant improvement in working memory for youth with sickle cell disease but adherence to the training is a concern. This study will examine a novel treatment approach by combining Cogmed working memory skills training with social support components and memory strategy training to improve adherence and broaden access to this efficacious intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Black Americans face a disproportionately high risk of developing incident cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), compared to non-Hispanic White adults, but the biological mediators underlying this elevated risk are not well understood. The proposed research will use a novel high- throughput proteomics platform to measure 3,072 plasma proteins in Black and White participants of the Reasons for Geographic and Racial Differences in Stroke (REGARDS) study and evaluate relationships of these proteins with ADRD risk factors, incident cognitive impairment, and trajectories of cognitive function. Results of this research may identify risk factors for impaired cognitive health and biological pathways that amplify racial disparities in ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income older adults are more likely to experience functional disability, and in turn disability often causes emotional, physical, and financial burden in the family members that assist affected older adults. This mixed methods research study will examine how housing disrepair (including problems with one’s home’s roof, walls, or heating) contributes to functional disability in low-income older adults and caregiving burden in their family caregivers, generating foundational knowledge and an understanding of possible modifiable factors and mechanisms from which to develop an intervention. A rigorous training program in mixed methods research, intervention development, family caregiving, and research team leadership will assure career advancement as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: [This study will advance understanding of lumbosacral spinal stenosis (LSS) a major cause of pain and dysmobility in older adult Veterans and a leading cause of disability and loss of independence. Major research studies have shown that surgery for LSS is more effective than usual (medical) management. Still, there are many patients for whom surgery is not possible. There have been reports that temporary use of a modified rolling walker or sleep positioning may help relieve LSS. Going further, our VA team has created a detailed round-the-clock LSS management plan that addresses all daily activities. We will recruit a small group of older adult Veterans with LSS to pilot this comprehensive modified activity program. Our team will support the day- and-night lifestyle modifications and monitor participants closely for relief of symptoms and improvements in walking. We will also assess potential barriers to adopting this therapy by interviewing Veterans and healthcare providers regarding problems with therapy initiation.] If this small study works, we plan to expand the effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tau accumulates in pathological aggregates within neurons in AD and is an important fluid biomarker of disease. NPTX2 is a synaptic protein that is also prominently altered in AD and interacts with tau as a biomarker of disease. The proposed research aims to develop new tools to image tau accumulation in vivo and examine its interaction with NPTX2 loss of function using a newly established TgF344-AD x NPTX2f/f rat model. Studies will advance understanding of early-stage AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Implementation science (ImS) is a branch of research that focuses on the “use of strategies to adopt and integrate evidence-based health interventions and change practice patterns within specific settings” and is a major initiative of the NIH research portfolio. There is also greater emphasis on eliminating health inequities and social and structural barriers, such as racism, that fuel health inequities, but no other training programs exist that focus on training junior faculty from under-represented minority (URM) backgrounds in Implementation Science. The UCSF Research in Implementation Science for Equity (RISE) program has successfully bridged that gap for the past 8 years, equipping URM scholars to pursue innovative research of interest to the NHLBI and to launch successful careers as independent investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. has the highest rate of maternal mortality among high-income countries and hypertension is a leading cause, contributing to 40% of maternal deaths. To improve the quality and cultural relevance of hypertension care, this proposal will examine the effects of the digital health approach Moms@Home on home blood pressure monitoring in a diverse population of pregnant women with hypertension. By facilitating more timely diagnosis and potentially better blood pressure control with digital health and home blood pressure monitoring, this proposal holds promise to reduce the risk of preventable and devastating clinical events for women with high- risk pregnancies and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When ER+/HER2- breast cancer patients are prescribed endocrine therapy and CDK4/6 inhibitors, it is common for a small percentage of the tumor cells to keep dividing. We suspect these cells could be responsible for drug resistance. The goals of this project are to identify this remnant of tumor cells; to understand how they circumvent treatment with endocrine therapy and CDK4/6 inhibitors; and to discover new signaling proteins that promote resistance. In the future, this information could be used to predict how a patient will respond to endocrine/CDK4/6 inhibitor therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), the most common form of pancreatic cancer causes death in 89% of patients within 5 years of diagnosis. PDAC will become the second leading cause of US cancer deaths by 2040. Pancreatic cancer is deemed a presumptive condition for veterans with exposure to radiation from nuclear weapons and for those who fought in Southwest Asia or the Persian Gulf. PDAC associates with smoking, obesity, diabetes, older age and male gender, all more frequent in veterans than civilians. Clinical progress has been slow in PDAC, and unlike other cancer types, there has been no success using immune therapies. We found that the protein Oncostatin M Receptor (OSMR) causes greater pancreatic cancer aggressiveness. We will study OSMR in mouse models of pancreatic cancer biology and treatment. We will investigate OSMR at the single cell level in human tumors to understand how it changes cell types in the tumor and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse midline gliomas (DMGs) are devastating childhood brain tumors for which there are no effective therapies. I previously identified aberrant FOXR2 expression as a key driver event in DMG formation and growth, and that FOXR2 specifically activates ETS transcription factor circuits and is functionally redundant with growth factor receptor pathways. The work proposed here seeks to define the mechanisms by which FOXR2 cooperates with ETS transcription factors to drive MAPK signaling in FOXR2-expressing DMGs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteochondral defects (OCDs) – damage to cartilage and underlying bone – leads to pain, loss of joint function and osteoarthritis. The goal of this research is to develop a bioprosthetic implant as an alternative to autografting and partial resurfacing treatments. The cylindrical implants would stimulate formation of new bone tissue and integration with host tissue while supplying synthetic cartilage necessary for joint function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project assesses the effects of short-term air pollution exposure on lung function in a large national cohort of adults with a specific focus on effects in vulnerable populations, and also evaluates the use of a novel exposure assessment technique, nasosorption, for the development of novel biomarkers of air pollution exposure in at-risk populations. The proposed project has valuable public health implications, both in characterizing the effects of air pollution exposure in high-risk individuals and developing novel clinical tools to identify patients who are highly exposed to air pollution, with the ultimate goal of informing policy and clinical practice to mitigate the effects of these exposures in vulnerable groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Mutational variants in the trafficking receptor SORLA have been shown to be associated with increased Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. Although previous studies from our group and others have demonstrated roles for SORLA in both reducing Aβ accumulation, as well as mediating protective effects in response to Aβ, it remains unknown whether SORLA is also neuroprotective with respect to tau. Our proposed study here investigates whether SORLA upregulation also reduces toxic effects associated with tau, and potentially implicates SORLA in mediating protective effects from both fundamental pathologies (Aβ and tau) that define AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Salla disease is a rare lysosomal storage disorder linked to heritable autosomal recessive mutations in the human SLC17A5 gene, encoding a transporter protein on the membrane of lysosomes that is needed for export of recycled sugar molecules used in glycoprotein and glycolipid formation. Studies have been limited in scope due to the premature lethality associated with mutations in SLC17A5 that result in an acute accumulation of sugars within the lysosome and cause a severe infantile sialic acid storage disorder (ISSD), whereas Salla disease is characterized by weaker mutations that result in a more slowly progressive adult form of neurodegenerative disease. Here we will develop a new animal model of Salla disease that circumvents the lethality of ISSD and other models through use of genetic and pharmacological combinations designed to uncover neuromodulators of SLC17A5 and enable the examination of two primary symptoms – convulsions and progressive neurodegeneration, to accelerate the path of therapeutic discovery for adults with this rare disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improvements following behavioral parent training for childhood ADHD are attenuated significantly when parents also experience high levels of ADHD symptoms, and parental ADHD poses a significant barrier to successful application of the parenting skills learned during treatment. The proposed project will design and preliminarily test a behavioral parenting program that integrates (a) CBT strategies for parental ADHD symptoms and (b) an mHealth adjunct app providing timely, personalized reminders and CBT-based supports to improve in vivo parenting skill use. By reducing barriers to skill use due to parental ADHD, this study has considerable potential to improve child outcomes and reduce the significant personal and public health costs associated with the disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy with T cells expressing so called chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) that target CD19 (CD19- CAR T cells) has been very effective for pediatric patients with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL). However, only approximately half of patients benefit from this approach long term. In this proposal, we aim to overcome current limitations of CD19-CAR T-cell therapy by generating these CAR T-cells from healthy donors and enhancing their anti-leukemia activity by additional genetic modifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Metabolic syndrome (MetS), insulin resistance (IR), and type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) increase the risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (ADRD), and AD pathology worsens MetS/IR/T2DM pathobiology. To investigate the underlying mechanisms whereby MetS/IR contributes to AD/ADRD pathology and vascular dementia, we utilize a nonhuman primate (NHP) model of MetS/IR, dyslipidemia, T2DM, and systemic inflammation resulting from consumption of a high sugar diet (HSD) in order to address the scientific premise that MetS/IR/T2DM exacerbates molecular and cellular changes within the brain that promote pathogenesis of AD/ADRD which we will rigorously investigate in peripheral metabolic pathways and vulnerable hippocampal, cortical, and hypothalamic circuits, and cerebrovasculature via coordinated immunochemical, histopathologic, proteomic, and transcriptomic studies along with associated biobehavioral assessments and advanced imaging approaches. By addressing our hypothesis that the HSD initiates a vicious cycle between mechanisms underlying neurodegeneration and diabetes pathogenesis that result in the progression of both diseases, and whereby neuropathology is exacerbated by MetS/IR/T2DM, while impaired brain control of glucose and lipid homeostasis leads to a worsening progression towards T2DM, this proposal will provide novel information regarding mechanisms involved in these interactions and will lead to new and better targeted therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Arsenic exposure is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, and this relationship may be modified by arsenic methylation, a biological pathway that decreases arsenic toxicity and increases excretion of arsenic in urine. This study will identify pre- and post-transcriptional gene regulatory factors involved in arsenic methylation efficiency and arsenic-related cardiovascular disease risk among Native American adults. Findings will provide insight to the pathways that link arsenic to complex health outcomes, support the development of biomarkers of arsenic-related cardiovascular disease, and help target public health interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Suicide prevention is VA’s highest clinical priority, and the greatest number of lives lost to suicide are in older Veterans. To advance the science in suicide risk research, we need an Individualized Approach, especially for aging Veterans—informing how best to target the multidisciplinary needs of older Veterans, which in turn will inform how best to mitigate and prevent suicide. Research is lacking that addresses the complexities of comorbidities in older Veterans who attempt suicide, and little is known about social risk factors, although they are likely hugely impactful—and next to nothing is known about how these factors may characterize individuals at greatest risk. The proposed project will provide necessary and relevant knowledge on the near-term typologies and long-term trajectories that lead to suicide death for aging Veterans and the pathways from suicide attempt to mortality, this project will inform the development of person-centered suicide prevention and intervention strategies in the segment of the population with the highest occurrence of suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phenotypic diversity allows pathogenic microbes and cancer cells to survive drug treatments and form permanent drug-resistance mutations, which poses a major challenge in medicine. It is not fully understood how phenotypic diversity contributes to collective biological functions, such as in biofilm formation and cancer metastasis. This project aims to address this general question by investigating bacterial collective migration, exploring how the diversity of phenotypes enables groups of bacteria to adapt across various physical environments and mediate pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Smoking is the leading cause of preventable illness, disability, and death in the United States. The rate of smoking is higher among Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Unfortunately, smoking cessation efforts that are effective in the general population have shown limited effectiveness in smokers with PTSD. We have successfully developed a treatment manual that provides evidence-based treatment for both PTSD and smoking at the same time. Contingency management (CM) is an intensive behavioral treatment that has significantly improved rates of stopping smoking in people with psychiatric disorders. CM provides positive reinforcers (e.g., vouchers, money) to Veterans who pass a biological test to show that they have not smoked since the last therapy session. This trial aims to test whether adding contingency management to combined PTSD and smoking cessation treatment will significantly increase treatment attendance and completion, greater reduction of PTSD and depressive symptoms, and greater rates of stopping smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Glycemic control is often the main of diabetes care, but a singular focus on glycemic control may lead to patients’ overall health and wellbeing being overlooked or undervalued. We have previously developed an intervention comprised of (a) a set of conversation cards designed to enable patients to identify aspects of life with diabetes important to them and to share them with their clinician to obtain their input; and (b) materials that help clinicians respond to patient concerns. We now propose to conduct a randomized clinical trial to test the feasibility of the research procedures and efficacy of the intervention with respect to patient reported outcome measures and for improving glycemic control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE U.S. efforts to End the HIV Epidemic have often overlooked cisgender women, who account for approximately 20% of new HIV diagnoses, and are routinely not engaged in HIV prevention services due to lack of knowledge and perceived risk- on the sides of both patient and provider- as well as insufficient integration of empowering HIV prevention counseling into routine woman-centered services, such as family planning services. Shared decision-making is a model that allows for discussion of all treatment options and empowers women to make informed health care decisions with consideration for their needs and preferences, usually through the use of a shared decision-making tool that decreases provider bias and increases provider knowledge while increasing the acceptability of care and counseling to the patient and the likelihood of adherence to the determined care plan. This adaptation of an evidence-based shared decision-making tool for use with HIV prevention in the high-reach setting of family planning clinics will provide scaffolding for improved HIV prevention counseling and increased HIV prevention method uptake, including novel and forthcoming modalities of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV prevention, advancing efforts to end the HIV epidemic among an underserviced at- risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compared to non-Hispanic Whites, Blacks carry a disproportionate burden of illness, disability, and early mortality. These health disparities have been linked to high levels of psychosocial stress experienced by Blacks, but the biological mechanisms linking stress with health disparities are not well understood. This project investigates the role of DNA methylation (changes that control genetic expression) in the connections between early life stress, protective factors, and health disparities in early markers of chronic disease in early childhood, late adolescence, and young adulthood.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Identifying efficacious drugs for the treatment of heart failure will save infant lives, but successful drug development in this population is dependent upon integration of growth, maturation, and disease specific influences on drug disposition and response. These factors are often ignored in infant heart failure trials. Our multidisciplinary team will systematically and efficiently characterize and validate the exposure-response relationship of the heart failure probe drug digoxin in infants with heart failure from single ventricle congenital heart disease; this disruptive approach is translatable to other therapeutics to broadly impact outcomes in this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: TPI Df is an untreatable metabolic disease. Overwhelming data demonstrate that disease pathogenesis is known to result from the targeting of functional mutant protein for degradation. Drug therapies do not exist for this disease. We propose to develop an optical compound screen to full high throughput screening standards, use the platform to screen FDA approved drugs, biologically active compounds, and a diversity compound library and identify the first in class TPI Df small molecule therapies. We will prioritize molecules using toxicology and metabolic stability assays, and validate the most promising compounds in TPI Df patient cells and in vivo using a mouse TPI Df model. Overall this project will discover and validate the first ever treatments for TPI Df that will provide the basis for clinical trials.

PHR: While outcomes have been improved for many cancers, there remains a substantial need to develop and validate more effective treatments, while also improving the quality of life and well-being for cancer patients. The NRG Oncology National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN) group addresses this need, and the NRG Oncology Statistics and Data Management Center (SDMC) represents an integral component critical to ensuring that NRG Oncology clinical trials are properly designed, implemented, conducted, analyzed, and disseminated. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses some of the major challenges in the generation, purification and transplantation of human stem cell-derived midbrain dopamine neurons, challenges that currently limit the routine use of those neurons. The work will yield novel insights into brain development and establish techniques to facilitate human midbrain dopamine neuron production, purification and subtype specification in a dish. Our findings should have a broad impact and enable improved model systems to study and treat Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Therapy resistance in patients with metastatic melanoma is a significant clinical problem. The goal of this proposal is to understand how aggressive neural crest stem cell (NCSC)-like melanoma cells drive metastasis and therapy resistance. Mechanistic insight into the molecular vulnerabilities of NCSC-like melanoma cells is required for the development of clinically-relevant therapeutic strategies that can eliminate them to ablate metastases, overcome resistance and increase the overall survival of patients with advanced cancer.
