IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccines have had a major impact on human health through the elimination of childhood diseases such as measles, diphtheria, whooping cough and polio. Safer, new generation vaccines are made from recombinant proteins instead of whole pathogens, but these require adjuvants to stimulate the immune system. Conventionally, only one type of adjuvant is used but they are more effective when combined. In this proposal we will used modern immunological tools to dissect the cellular and molecular pathways that underlie synergistic effect of adjuvants when combined.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, aging-associated lung disease characterized by the scarring of lung tissues, shortness of breath, and high mortality due to respiratory failure. This proposal will lay the groundwork for developing a new therapy for the treatment of IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Understanding the mechanisms whereby hepatocyte-secreted miRNA-containing extracellular vesicles (EVs) in mediating responses of insulin producing and insulin sensitizing cells, and how these are altered during the development of obesity, will provide a critical insight into the role of hepatic regulation on peripheral insulin sensitivity. In the future, therapeutic  treatments targeting hepatocyte EV miRNAs and their gene network may be developed to improve insulin sensitivity in obesity and Type 2 diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will examine the structure, function and quality of social connectedness in patients with Huntington’s Disease (HD) and their adolescent and young adult offspring, in comparison with a sample of adolescents and young adults and their parents without HD. Our goal is to identify problems in the structure, function and quality of social connectedness in HD patients and their offspring and to study their association with quality of life and cognitive, emotional and behavioral problems associated with HD over a period of two years, and to examine bidirectional associations with two potential mediators of the association between social connectedness and health outcomes: executive functioning and emotion regulation. Findings from this study could inform future research to identify markers of HD risk early in development and guide the development of interventions to help slow the progression of symptoms of HD in this vulnerable group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Many developmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and Schizophrenia (SCZ), have a greater incidence in males than in females, and sex-dependent risk or protective factors have been postulated, but not yet identified. We hypothesize that early brain development differs in males versus females, and that inherited risk factors are mitigated in females by protective patterning in the developing female brain, at a developmental stage long before gonadal development. This project is seeking the first detailed understanding of early sexually dimorphic brain development, and will pioneer the discovery of how disease susceptibility depends on sex-biased gene regulation in the developing brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide insights into epigenetic mechanisms of familial predisposition to obesity and may help to identify molecular markers of metabolic dysfunction in children. The proposed study is innovative because it utilizes state-of-the-art in vivo and in vitro approaches to establish the interaction of ancestral diet and exercise on transgenerational programming of mitochondrial dysfunction. The project is relevant to NIH mission that seeks acquisition of fundamental scientific knowledge, because it may lead to new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for the early diagnosis, prediction and personalized interventions of metabolic disorders in children. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will establish a Micronesian Data Laboratory at the University of Guam to conduct high-quality population-based surveys beginning with the first Guam National Health Interview Survey, with an emphasis on estimating gout and hyperuricemia prevalence. A Steering Committee and community partnership will be formed and engaged throughout the research process. The inaugural GNHIS findings will inform policy or program needs to support population health, generate future collaborative grant proposals, and serve as a model for other territories or USAPIs interested in NHIS or similar survey implementation. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop an engineered nanofiber-hydrogel composite with high biostimulatory activity that is capable of remodeling into vascularized soft tissue, and to understand materials properties and cellular responses governing optimal soft tissue remodeling in genetically tractable and established translational models. This study will yield a new series of off-the-shelf biostimulatory materials with high potential to repair craniofacial and other soft tissue losses in reconstructive surgery.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Research Institute Summer Scholars Program (CRISSP) is focused on advanced skill development to ensure that the best and brightest advanced undergraduates (juniors and seniors) are fully prepared for careers in biomedical research with an emphasis on areas directly relevant to the mission of the NICHD. CRISSP, places these talented upper level undergraduate students in a rich pediatric-focused environment where they will receive direct hands-on research experience, didactic sessions and mentoring to not only inspire them to pursue careers in basic, translational and clinical pediatric research but also to develop advanced skills that are essential to performing cutting-edge research to promote the health and well-being of children and to propel them forward as leaders and innovators in child health research. The program emphasizes practical skill development, mentorship and underrepresented minority (URM) recruitment into the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative C. albicans has become the third or fourth most common nosocomial bloodstream isolate; mortality rates are high (35% or greater) and treatment is costly. While antifungal compounds exist, these drugs are often of limited use because of their toxicity and side effects, and due to the emergence of antifungal resistance in the clinical setting. It is vital that C. albicans research continue as rapidly as possible – successful advance of this project, to provide a curated and comprehensive Candida albicans database, will continue to accelerate Candida research, and in doing so will aid in the fight against these fungal infections, significantly positively impacting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This longitudinal mixed-methods study examines the effects of mobility status on developmentally salient health outcomes in Latino youth from migrant farmworker families across adolescence. Additionally, we assess how mobility levels may differentiate mental and physical health and substance use outcomes in youth who remain highly mobile versus those who become settled, and identify resilience factors that have potential to protect youth from poor health outcomes. Mitigating the consequences of migratory stressors on health trajectories and identifying protective factors during a critical transition time, when health disparities are expected to become increasingly prevalent, may be one of the most significant ways to promote health and well-being among migrant children in farmworker families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative. Chronic exposure to a wide range of prenatal stressors including depression, financial stress, and adverse childhood experiences is more common among racial/ethnic minorities and may be causally related to obesity disparities in early life. Although epigenetic mechanisms are thought to mediate these processes, we lack sufficient supporting data in humans to guide policy. To identify early-acquired epigenetic mechanisms that link maternal social stress to metabolic dysfunction in children, and determine if a Mediterranean diet mitigates these effects, we will leverage existing cohorts of mothers and their children in Durham and Wake Counties in North Carolina, from 750 participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative Researchers have documented health disparities between sexual minority and heterosexual individuals across hundreds of studies, but the investigations of why these disparities exist remain incomplete primarily because of the absence of a targeted contextual database that includes repeated measures of structural stigma and racism (legal and social climate) at multiple levels (i.e., tract, county, and state). This project will construct a database that will be linked to the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health). This database will enable researchers across multiple disciplines, including demography, economics, geography, psychology, public health, public policy, and sociology, to identify sources of health disparities and inform public health policies and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is one of the leading causes of mortality in the United States and reactive oxygen species have been shown to play a critical role in atherosclerotic plaque development. Clinical trials utilizing antioxidant therapies have been unsuccessful and we propose that nicotinamide nucleotide transhydrogenase (NNT) can reduce the development of atherosclerosis by regulating mitochondrial ROS production and preserving normal endothelial cell function. Results from these studies will highlight NNT as a master regulator of mitochondrial antioxidant activity and as a novel therapeutic target in the treatment of atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement)  Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC)—the most lethal form of prostate cancer with limited treatment options—is characterized by dysfunctional DNA repair, with 20%–30% of mCRPC bearing germline or somatic mutations in DNA repair genes, such as BRCA1/2 and others with deficiency in homologous recombination repair (HRR). Genetic or treatment-induced HRR deficiency renders cancer cells particularly vulnerable to inhibition of DNA-damage tolerance pathways, such as the Rev1-dependent translesion DNA synthesis (TLS). Hence, results from our proposed studies of TLS inhibition in mCRPC are highly relevant to public health as they will provide valuable insights into the development of new treatment modalities for patients with lethal mCRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: ! Project Narrative This project seeks to identify people at high risk of a skin cancer such as melanoma, so these individuals can be monitored by a dermatologist. This Precision Prevention strategy would prevent cancers from reaching a lethal stage and reduce the health care cost of removing even rarely-lethal but invasive cancers. Predicting an individual's risk uses new methods for sampling skin non-invasively and measuring DNA adducts at ultrasensitive genomic sites, thereby objectively measuring a person's past exposure to ultraviolet light – the principal carcinogen leading to skin cancer. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Positron emission tomography (PET) is a highly specific and sensitive imaging technique that visualizes molecular interactions, having a significant impact on biomedical research and translational medicine. This proposal reinvents bismuth germanate (BGO) scintillator as an exciting scintillator that offers exceptional promise for time-of-flight (TOF) PET using its newly discovered “fast timing resolution”. Combining high sensitivity from TOF capability and no background radioactivity would be highly enabling for very low dose applications. The ability to perform TOF PET with BGO make it worthy of consideration for PET scanners designed for brain, breast, and total body imaging as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent discoveries have revealed that the half-lives and functions of sialylated glycoproteins at the cell surface can be regulated by their rates of de-sialylation with increased protein age. The neuraminidases responsible thereby control glycoprotein abundance and function among various cell types including epithelial cells of the intestine where they may participate in the onset of colitis. The research proposed in this application will determine whether Neu3 induction is involved in the onset of colitis in a mouse model of recurrent human food poisoning and will explore the role of protein sialylation in maintenance and erosion of the mucin barrier during intestinal inflammation and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Notre Dame proposes to create a Post-baccalaureate Research Education Program (ND-PREP) to provide a one year pre-PhD biomedical research experience for individuals from underserved diverse backgrounds. The goal of ND-PREP is to provide Fellows with the research experience, professional development, and life skills necessary to gain admission to and succeed in competitive biomedical PhD programs. This goal will be achieved by providing the Fellows with a three-part formal training program that includes: 1) an intensive in-laboratory research experience (75% of trainee time); (2) a set of skills-development workshops and enrichment activities that will also serve to build a strong ND-PREP cohort (15% of Fellow time, with workshops ranging from research ethics to life skills); and (3) Fellow participation in a unique community engagement activity focused on lead abatement in the local community (10% of Fellow time).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to train University of Utah undergraduate students from underrepresented racial/ethnic backgrounds in air pollution-related health research through the transdisciplinary faculty-mentored summer program Health, Air Pollution and Population Initiative in Education and Science Training (HAPPIEST). Exposure to air pollution is magnified in racial/ethnic minority communities, and it is thus critical to engage affected populations in this area of research. The proposed project's main contributions to public health are twofold: (1) HAPPIEST prepares underrepresented minority students to enter STEM research, thereby diversifying the pool of talented scientists; (2) the program advances knowledge in environmental health science thereby informing innovative solutions for air pollution-related health problems in the Salt Lake Valley and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative An estimated seven million yearly deaths are attributable to air pollution, with over 60% due to household air pollution (HAP) caused by use of biomass- or kerosene-fueled kitchen stoves in low- and middle-income countries. Women and children suffer the highest exposures, with documented ill effects on their respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurologic systems, along with mounting evidence of neurocognitive impairments in growing infants and children, due to HAP. The proposed work seeks to describe and quantify the risks of neurocognitive developmental impairment in relation to HAP with the goal of informing local and global public health policies and initiatives to reduce HAP.

PHR: Project Summary/Abstract In-home monitoring technologies have the potential to transform the healthcare system by enabling the transition from reactive care to proactive and preventive care. This study will leverage a highly innovative technology for cardiovascular in-home daily monitoring; the fully integrated toilet seat (FIT). A multidisciplinary research team, comprised of engineers, physicians, advanced practice providers, data scientists, biostatisticians, designers, and software developers, will advance an automated system that provides health care providers with early warning of patient deterioration through an in-home clinical trial of heart failure patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diarrheal pathogens are the cause of over 1.5 million deaths globally each year, mostly affecting children in underdeveloped countries. Barrier maintenance and host defense against diarrheal pathogens requires the complex interplay of both immune cells and intestinal epithelial cells, but how these cell types cooperate to eradicate pathogens is largely unknown. This proposal seeks to eclucidate the mechanisms by which IFN acts on intestinal epithelial cells to recruit and sustain local IL-22 delivery from pathogen-specific CD4+ T cells in the setting of intestinal infection and how this process can be manipulated for therapeutic benefit in the treatment of diarrheal illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness worldwide. Therefore, it is essential to understand the molecular mechanisms that contribute to the formation and maintenance of lens transparency. The proposed research will result in the characterization of novel pathways in lens development, homeostasis and pathogenesis and will continue development of a publicly available web-based interactive tool – for both clinicians and scientists – that facilitates prediction and prioritization of genes/pathways to further accelerate cataract gene discovery.

PHR: This over-arching goal of this T32 renewal grant is to provide support for pre-doctoral students at Emory University in order to help deliver the next generation of scientists needed to continue the fight against bacterial and viral pathogens. PHR: A novel pro-drug form of the human proteasome named Rapaprotin has been identified from the rapamycin-inspired macrocycle library. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: TITLE: Venous Malformations (VM): murine model to identify therapies to target aberrant venous development PROJECT NARRATIVE: Venous malformation (VM) appear in young children, are severely disfiguring and cause chronic pain and increased risk of pulmonary embolism. We use patient-derived in vivo and 3D models to identify signaling molecules implicated in the formation of abnormal blood vessels in VM patients. Our findings will be fundamental for the development of novel targeted therapeutic strategies for the treatment of patients affected by VM or other vascular anomalies with dilated vasculature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The skin is colonized by microbial communities, but their role in the barrier function of the skin is not well- defined. The proposed research will illuminate the molecules produced by beneficial skin microbes, their impact on the skin, and their therapeutic potential for treating inflammatory and infectious skin diseases. Findings from these studies will provide insight into fundamental roles of our endogenous microbiota while advancing targets for the treatment of skin disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative For many individuals with sensory impairment or neurodevelopmental disorders, moderate stimuli can be perceived as overwhelmingly intense. This work will identify neurobiological signatures of hyperacusis, an auditory hypersensitivity disorder that often accompanies migraine, Autism, Fragile X syndrome and sensorineural hearing loss. This work would identify neural circuit mechanisms for hyperacusis and open new long-term therapeutic avenues for a common neurological disorder that has no widely accepted treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer therapy-induced cognitive dysfunction (CRCI) or chemobrain is one of the major quality of life issue for cancer survivors. With over 16.9 million cancer survivors alive today, assessing long-term neurocognitive complications and effective clinical recourse is now considered the most important clinical criterion for evaluating therapeutic outcome. This proposal (in response to a chemobrain RFA, PAR-21-329) will delineate effectiveness of systemic injections of human neural stem cell-derived extracellular vesicles and miRNA-based mechanism of neurocognitive benefits using intact and cancer mouse models to ameliorate CRCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to cadmium (Cd) is hazardous to human health, and chronic exposure is a risk for carcinogenesis that includes prostate cancer. Our results suggested that Cd-exposure differently induced prostate malignancies (i.e.), Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the transition zone (TZ) of the prostate, and poorly differentiated carcinoma (PDC) in the peripheral zone (PZ) of the prostate. Hence, the goal is to determine the pathobiology and molecular landscape of Cd-induced SCC's in both laboratory models and clinical specimens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Imbalances in the relationship between neuronal and immune cells during development cause inflammatory cascades which drive neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism and schizophrenia. This proposal seeks to understand how an unexpected immune cell, the mast cell, is recruited to the developing brain and promotes the normal developmental trajectory of surrounding glia. Elucidating the mechanisms by which peripheral immune cells shape neurodevelopmental processes will strengthen our understanding of how inflammatory disturbances cause neurologic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Retinal vascular health, which is important for normal vision, is impaired in children who are born prematurely, patients who suffer from diabetic retinopathy and senior citizens who frequently develop age-related macular degeneration. This proposal focuses on a circulating lipid molecule, called sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) which acts on retinal vessels to promote blood vessel health and normal vision. The major aim of the proposal is to understand how S1P function is defective in retinal diseases such as retinopathy of prematurity and S1P inhibitor-induced macular edema, which is anticipated to ultimately lead to new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemodialysis patients experience a disproportionately high burden of sudden cardiac death. Medication- provoked sudden cardiac death (i.e. death triggered by QT-prolonging medications) may be preventable and has not been studied enough in this population. Our project aims to uncover medication-related risk factors for sudden cardiac death and develop clinical decision support tools that will promote safer medication prescribing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) slows cone photoreceptor death in many animal models of retinal degeneration with different genetic origins and was recently shown to improve cone function in patients with retinitis pigmentosa (RP). This AOSLO Resource Center for the NAC Attack trial will evaluate macular cone photoreceptors in 40 participants assigned to NAC or placebo, providing a sensitive measure of disease progression and response to NAC. Success of this trial may lead to the commercialization of a safe and effective treatment that could prevent blindness in patients with RP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infects epithelial cells, causing cold sores and genital lesions, and spreads to neurons in which it establishes a life-long infection. We will investigate the protective effects of the cytokine interferon lambda acting specifically in the skin to limit HSV lesion severity during acute and recurrent infection. We also will investigate whether interferon lambda limits the spread of mosquito-borne and tick-borne viruses when they are inoculated into the skin by a feeding arthropod.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) affects over 14 million individuals in the United States, but the underlying factors that determine why some individuals develop progressive COPD while others do not have not been fully elucidated. This proposal will determine how injury and clot formation in specialized vessels called the lung lymphatics are early and defining events in the pathogenesis of COPD that contributes to disease progression. We will also test how existing drugs can be used to target the lymphatics for therapy in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The world-wide epidemic of obesity represents a major public health threat at the nexus of inflammatory disorders, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes mellitus. Our proposed studies are based on our exciting prior finding that eating at the `wrong' time of day, as occurs in shift work and sleep disorders, leads to visceral adiposity and inflammation, while restricting high fat feeding to the `right' time of day promotes healthful obesity. Here we propose to dissect the mechanisms regulating day/night nutrient handling using metabolic flux in tandem with transcriptomic and genomic analyses in adipocytes, and we will combine studies of time-restricted feeding with powerful transgenic models to elucidate how high-fat feeding and related circadian disruption contribute to the immunometabolic complications of obesity at the level of the adipocyte.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulatory mechanisms involved in maturation of the heart following birth are poorly understood. This is an important area of investigation given that during the development of heart failure the mature adult heart reverts to a more fetal format restricting its capacity for fuel combustion and cardiac performance. This project will investigate a newly discovered master regulatory network involved in maturation of the heart, delineate the mechanisms involved in its dysregulation during the development of heart failure, and will test new therapeutic approaches aimed at heart disease by exploiting this newly discovered circuitry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The tremendous promise of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) to regulate inflammation is evident in corneal transplantation, where treatment of graft recipients with MSCs has been shown to decrease immune rejection of the donor tissue. However, the precise mechanisms by which MSCs regulate immune cell responses have not been defined. We propose to determine the cellular and molecular interactions by which MSCs modulate immunity in corneal transplantation, anticipating that improved understanding of these mechanisms will yield therapeutic targets that could be useful not only in tissue grafting but in a wide variety of inflammatory and autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gammaherpesviruses (GHVs) are ubiquitous viruses that establish lifelong chronic infections that can lead to cancer, especially lymphoma. We identified a host protein, p53, as being critical for limiting mutations and cellular transformation due to GHV infection. Experiments are proposed to further define mechanisms of genetic mutations and tumorigenesis that are restricted by p53 during GHV infection, which could identify targets for therapies to prevent or treat GHV-associated lymphomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH To develop effective therapies for rare monogenic diseases, knowledge of both genetic and environmental factors that might influence disease development and potential responses to therapeutics is extremely important. These factors which may alter disease onset, severity, and clinical appearance may thereby, alter response to treatments. Identification of these “modifiers” promises to deepen our understanding of pathogenic mechanisms, yield new potential targets for therapeutic intervention, and enhance the use of precision medicine to improve treatments. In this application, we focus on the pathogenic mechanisms that underlie CRB1-associated retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory disease, occurring preferentially in arterial branch points exposed to pro- atherogenic disturbed blood flow, while the straight parts of arteries exposed to stable flow are spared. Here, we propose a novel hypothesis that disturbed flow increases the expression of CEBPb protein in endothelial cells, which triggers them to become an unhealthy type known as “endothelial reprogramming,” leading to atherosclerosis development. Our study is designed to uncover the mechanisms by which disturbed flow triggers endothelial programming and atherosclerosis and identify potential antiatherogenic therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many stroke survivors face the daily struggle of living with disability; movement synergies are a major contributor to their impairment. Understanding the neural circuits underlying synergies is the first stage of developing rational therapeutic interventions. Our long-term aim is to develop ways of treating synergies at the circuit level (such as neurostimulation to induce plasticity, or specific drugs), freeing patients to improve their function unencumbered by these intrusive and unwanted movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and heterocyclic aromatic amines are two groups of ubiquitous environmental pollutants that possess potential, obesogenic effects and may lead to excess weight gain in humans, although prospective evidence is lacking to support or refute the role of these chemicals in obesity etiology in humans. The proposed investigation aims to fill this important knowledge gap by examining these pollutants, as well as their interactions, in relation to short-term weight loss, medium-term weight regain, and long-term weight change in both weight-loss trial and longitudinal observational study settings. This research will generate novel evidence that not only elucidates and substantiates associations between these pollutants and weight gain, and also helps to inform policy- or recommendation-making processes toward reducing exposures and curbing obesity epidemic in the U.S.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic islet α cell dysfunction is one of the principal mechanisms underlying the hyperglycemia and impaired response to hypoglycemia in diabetes mellitus. The molecular mechanisms underlying the ability of α cells to maintain synthesis of the counterregulatory hormone glucagon are poorly understood. This study will delineate the communication between two key protein degradative mechanisms, namely endoplasmic reticulum (ER)- associated degradation (ERAD) and macroautophagy, in promoting ER protein quality control and α cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Mitochondrial metabolic dysfunction has long been recognized as a key contributor to Alzheimer’s disease (AD); however, the underlying molecular mechanisms of how neurons coordinate mitochondrial activity and how they go awry in AD remain poorly understood. Combining molecular assays in mouse and human neuronal cultures and metabolic imaging in live animal brains, we seek to understand a novel mechanistic link between impaired mitochondrial metabolism, abnormal accumulation of soluble amyloid-β oligomers, Tau dysfunction and insulin resistance in AD. This effort may lead to improved understanding of AD pathogenesis and new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor-associated macrophages (TAM) represent one of the most abundant immune components in the breast cancer tumor microenvironment and exhibit a robust and unique influence on the disease. How to surmount TAM infiltration and function in order to activate a potent anti-tumorigenic and anti-metastatic response represents a gap in knowledge for the BC field. Continued research is needed to elucidate the interplay between tumor cells and the diverse immune cell populations within the primary tumor microenviornment, and how this interaction shapes tumor biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to population health because pediatric asthma is a common chronic condition that affects millions of U.S children, especially children from urban, low-income communities. Children with persistent and poorly-controlled asthma should be taking a daily preventive medication, like inhaled corticosteroids, to reduce their risk for breathing problems leading to frequent emergency department visits and hospitalizations; however, a wide gap exists between what is recommended and adherence to medications. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Regulatory T cell-antigen presenting cell contact can result in antigen specific suppression of effector T cells. The biological processes leading up to antigen specific immune suppression can serve as potential therapy targets for restoring self-tolerance in autoimmune diseases. This project proposes to delineate these biological processes for the first time in man resulting in the development of antigen-targeted therapies against autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The metabolic sensor mTORC1 has been successfully targeted to promote longevity in a range of species, but the translational capacity of this anti-aging intervention to humans is limited by negative side effects and a lack of knowledge about the mechanisms driving lifespan extension. The goal of this project is to investigate how neuron-specific mTORC1 inhibition in C. elegans extends lifespan without impairing growth or development by assessing changes both in the neurons and in peripheral tissues. This work will advance our understanding of both the metabolic regulation of aging and the functions of the mTORC1 pathway in general, and will influence the way we design interventions to promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Assembly of inhibitory and excitatory neurons into early networks represents a critical period in cortical development during which early principles of circuit formation and function are established. This elaborate process, which involves inhibitory neurons migrating long distances to eventually integrate with excitatory neurons, is often associated with various neuropsychiatric disorders; however, the basis of how disease-causing mutations affect discreet steps of this process in humans remains unknown. This proposal aims to investigate, using a stem-cell-based model of human cortical development, how distinct mutations in the gene TCF4, each of which has been implicated in distinct disorders such as schizophrenia, intellectual disability and epilepsy, affect the assembly of early human cortical networks. The long-term goal is to attain a comprehensive understanding of disease biology surrounding atypical cortical networks in patients with discrete TCF4 mutations and eventually identify new drug targets that are potentially shared across various disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve quality of life among individuals with chronic [low back] pain, there is a critical need to develop mobile health (mHealth) tools that promote safe, effective, and accessible self-management of pain. This research is innovative because it tests a novel mHealth tool— mobile neurofeedback— that uniquely enables self-management of chronic [low back] pain to be performed easily and safely anytime, anyplace. If this study yields positive results, it has potential to fundamentally change patients’ ability to manage pain on their own.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, manifesting as progressive memory loss and other cognitive functions. An objective blood-based biomarker that can predict and identify AD is a currently needed treatment modality. Herein, we will use a combination of a modified small RNA-seq and a newly developed quantification method to investigate whether the changes in tRF expression can differentiate AD from other neurodegenerative conditions and identify its preclinical stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Biomolecular condensation of RNA and proteins has been implicated in the pathogenesis of various neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, yet the physiological role and mechanism by which an mRNA condenses are unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The production of new neurons throughout life in the dentate gyrus is critical for function of the hippocampus, and after seizures there is increased production of new neurons but the formation of abnormal circuitry. We have identified a role of mossy cells in the hilus in the production of a secreted factor that regulates dentate neurogenesis in an activity dependent manner. In addition, we examine the formation of developmental circuits in the dentate that regulate the development of the dentate stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative. Taste disorders can have detrimental effects on a person's health and quality of life. The underlying mechanisms of these disorders are not understood but may result from disruption of the connections between taste buds and the neurons carrying taste information to the brain. Here, we are exploring the relationship between taste neuron structure, connectivity, and function to elucidate the role of connectivity in taste disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Bowdish, Michael Eugene PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to establish the University of Southern California Cardiovascular and Thoracic Surgery Stimulating Access to Research in Residency (USC-CVTS StARR) Program to foster the development of clinician- investigators in the field of cardiovascular and thoracic diseases, by enhancing the recruitment and retention of talented residents into successful research careers, while also meeting requirements for medical board eligibility. Three highly competitive training programs in the Department of Surgery, the General Surgery Residency Program, the Integrated Vascular Surgery Residency Program, and the Integrated Cardiothoracic Surgery Residency Program, are uniquely positioned to participate in the R38 program. Through the development of an Independent Career Development Plan (ICDP), composed of research, education, and mentorship components, we will establish a program that will lead to both clinical and research competency and establish a lifelong methodological foundation overlaid with additional competencies in communications, grant-writing, leadership and team science that are requisite for success as independent career investigators. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to deliver PCATS.JIA, a patient-centered shared decision-making tool for use at point of care to improve quality and outcomes of clinical care for children with JIA. The tool will be co-designed with its end- users (patients, clinicians), along with experts in user-centered design, data scientists, and health services and outcomes researchers. We will design and test implementation within the setting of a 23-center Pediatric Rheumatology Care and Outcomes Improvement Network (PR-COIN), leveraging our existing validated computational tool based on an advanced Bayesian nonparametric causal learning algorithm.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Inform Shared Decision-making with Advanced Bayesian Causal Inference to Improve Quality of Pediatric Rheumatology Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic exposure to stressful experiences can result in maladaptive affective states yielding behavioral disturbances in rodents and stress-related mood disorders in humans. One potential cause is corticotropin- releasing hormone (CRH) signaling in bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST), which is a sexually dimorphic integrative center for limbic information and valence monitoring. CRH-expressing BNST neurons (in the oval subnucleus) are critical mediators of the chronic stress response and may underlie sex differences therein. Our proposed studies will examine the role of BNST CRH signaling as a nexus for chronic stress-induced behavioral outcomes increasing our understanding of the impact of chronic stressors on affective states in both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of a safe and effective prophylactic HIV vaccine has been a long sought, but unfulfilled goal of biomedical research, essential for the ultimate control of the HIV epidemic. We propose a novel approach to develop HIV prophylactic vaccines, using a new vaccine platform that we developed, Killed Whole Cell Genome-Reduced Bacterial vaccines that express vaccine antigens on the surfaces of the bacteria, targeting two highly conserved viral antigens, the HIV Membrane Proximal External region and the Fusion Peptide region of the viral envelope protein. Recombinant bacterial vaccines can produce good antibody and cell- mediated immune responses, are very inexpensive to produce, do not require ultra-cold storage conditions, and be administered via a non-parenteral route, without need of highly trained medical professionals, and are thus highly suitable for global use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Angiogenesis in the developing retina requires communication between endothelial cells, pericytes and myeloid cells, and dysregulated communication between the three cell types drives ocular neovascular diseases (ONDs) that are currently treated with anti-VEGF agents that target endothelial cells only. In this proposal, we identify the secreted Slit2 ligand as an activator of retinal neovascularization that acts through Robo receptor signaling in pericytes and myeloid cells, and show that Slit-Robo pathway inhibition reduces OND in mouse models. By identifying mechanisms of Robo-mediated signaling in pericytes and myeloid cells we will uncover novel biology controlling retinal development and homeostasis that could be applied to OND prevention and may confer additional benefit over VEGF inhibition of endothelial cells alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Behaving adaptively in our environment requires noticing the patterns around us and storing the learned information for long-term use. This project examines how the brain can quickly and effectively encode these patterns and how it then processes and solidifies this new information across time and sleep. A detailed understanding of these mechanisms could suggest new targets for intervention in mental health disorders such as depression and schizophrenia with profound disturbances to learning and sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Changes in the abundance of circulating blood glycoproteins are important experimental and clinical determinants of health and disease; however, the mechanisms regulating blood protein half-lives have been difficult to perceive. We have developed the means to identify the endogenous ligand repertoires of endocytic lectin receptors that control blood glycoprotein half-lives and by using meta-analyses of the data we can predict previously undetected phenotypes and disease signs linked to their dysfunction including inflammation, coagulopathy, cardiovascular defects, and high blood pressure, as well as other physiological effects. This research proposal will investigate lectin receptor ligand repertoires and functions in blood protein homeostasis and its potential collaboration with environmental factors in further determining susceptibility to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop personalized models of aggression using data from ecological momentary surveys and passive sensors from smartphones and wearable devices. This approach to studying aggression is important because psychological models of aggression emphasize that it is dynamic and contextualized but aggression is rarely examined in daily life where these dynamics can be studied, hindering our ability to predict and intervene on aggressive urges and behavior in the contexts where they normally occur and are most consequential. By revealing the personalized antecedents of aggressive urges and behavior, we can identify person-specific mechanisms that precede instances of aggression, which in turn will provide crucial information needed to develop personalized, technology-based interventions that can be delivered before the harmful aggressive behavior occurs.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Urban adolescents and young adults (AYA) face formidable barriers to making healthy decisions core to sexually transmitted infection (STI) prevention, such as, communicating with sex partners and health providers about STI testing, including for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), connecting to scientifically accurate STI/HIV informational resources that are culturally and linguistically appropriate, and utilizing the clinical services available to prevent new infections. Using a design thinking framework, we will a) Characterize AYA's use of electronic health record (EHR) patient portals and determine the correlates and patterns of longitudinal use; b) Develop a patient-centered clinical decision support intervention that leverages the EHR patient portal system to optimize patient engagement in STI/HIV prevention behaviors among urban AYA, and c) Pilot test the intervention among urban adolescents residing in an STI/HIV prevalent community. Successful completion of the mentored award will provide the requisite training to become an independent investigator with expertise in developing and evaluating digital healthcare strategies that reduce health disparities associated with STIs/HIV, give voice to a hitherto low-resourced and minoritized population, and move the United States population towards the Healthy People 2030 Goals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient-facing decision support for HIV and sexually transmitted infection prevention in low-income and minority patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed research is to investigate how clinical genomic sequencing impacts families of pediatric patients. This research will develop an empirically informed framework of normative values important to families of pediatric patients, including ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI), which will then be used to elicit preferences for features of sequencing from a nationally representative sample of parents in the US. The results of this work will lead to a measure of family utility that integrates ELSI and can be used in a decision analytic model to assess the impact of genomic sequencing and the importance of including family- level ELSI considerations in such analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gestational diabetes is a common medical complication of pregnancy that annually affects ~250,000 women in the United States. Diabetes exposure during pregnancy can have long-term consequences on the health of offspring as it is associated with an increased risk of developing metabolic (obesity and type-2 diabetes) and cardiovascular diseases. The proposed research will investigate the hematopoietic alterations in offspring born to diabetic pregnancies to provide new diagnostic and therapeutic tools to mitigate the long-term negative effects of gestational diabetes on the health of adult offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) causes excruciating headaches in nearly all patients during the days, weeks, or even years after the bleeding. We propose a new way to treat these severe headaches—limiting the use of opioids, which can cause addiction and have dangerous side effects—using a nerve-block procedure that has been successful in treating other types of headaches, such as migraines. If this new way of pain treatment proves successful, it could be the beginning of a huge change in how we treat pain in SAH patients, and in acute brain injury in general.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parental care is an evolutionarily conserved behavior that is highly modulated by the sex, physiological state, and genetic background of the caregiver. An inability to properly display parental behaviors can lead to long- lasting detrimental effects in the infant. Thus, understanding the molecular basis for sex-, state-, and genetic- dependent expression of parental behavior is critical to understanding this essential behavior in normal and pathological contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is seeking to define the cellular and molecular events associated with resistance to immune checkpoint blockade in bladder cancer. Our preliminary data defines a gene signature emanating from myeloid cells associated with resistance to immune checkpoint blockade. Here, we will generate detailed atlases of bladder cancer which will refine our understanding of the precise myeloid cells associated with resistance, dissect the mechanistic basis for such resistance, and substantiate the clinical relevance of these observations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of the Centers for AIDS Research (CFAR) Symposium is to provide a venue to present and discuss recent advances in HIV research. This is a unique forum for presentations of the most “cutting edge” HIV research topics. The symposium provides an environment that fosters interactions between senior HIV investigators and early-stage investigators that will one day be leaders in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Bilateral communication between the brain and intestine, also called the “gut-brain axis”, is integral to nutrient homeostasis and similar “sensing” pathways may also exist in iron deficiency anemia. Understanding the molecules and mechanisms for how fluctuations in iron and heme levels translate into inter-organ communication and heme trafficking may lead to design of heme-based nutraceuticals to ameliorate iron-deficiency, the world’s number one nutritional disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Ependymoma is the third most common malignant brain tumor in children with no effective chemotherapeutics identified to date. We propose to thoroughly investigate FACT (FAcilitates Chromatin Transcription) as a driver of the highly lethal ependymoma subtype, ZFTA-RELA. Results will offer preclinical insight into FACT as a therapeutic target and establish the efficacy of CBL0137 as rationale therapy to inform future clinical trial design for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Understanding how the heart regulates normal systemic metabolic homeostasis is of critical importance, as its perturbation is a major source of metabolic disorders and dyslipidemia-related heart dysfunction. The Drosophila heart provides an excellent model system with which to define the molecular mechanisms that underlie functional communications between the heart and other major metabolic tissues that are essential for the maintenance of normal systemic lipid homeostasis. Our studies in the Drosophila heart system therefore represent the first step in a continuum of research that is expected to fill critical knowledge gaps in the fields of cardiac biology and energy metabolism and lay the groundwork for developing new therapeutic strategies for the amelioration of obesity and related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic stroke survivors represent a growing population among older adults in the U.S. and a very high-risk group for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), however factors and mechanisms that contribute to preserving cognitive health and timing of dementia onset in this population remain unclear. We will examine the role of biological aging in cognitive resilience and timing of dementia onset after stroke and molecular pathways underlying this relationship through integration of state-of-the art clinical assessments of stroke and cognition over more than 15 years of follow-up with algorithmic combinations of physiological biomarkers and molecular proteomic data in diverse samples from well- established cohorts. This research will help identify novel biomarkers and molecular proteomic pathways of cognitive resilience to open up new avenues for protection of cognitive health and primary prevention of vascular dementia among ischemic stroke survivors and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE In U.S. cities, Black youth are 20 times more likely, and Hispanic youth are 4.4 times more likely, to be fatally shot than non-Hispanic White youth at ages 18-24. To prepare for a career as an independent investigator focused on eliminating racial/ethnic disparities in youth firearm violence, Dr. Jay will train in structural racism and health disparities, community-engaged research, computer simulation modeling, and economic evaluation. His research will examine the potential benefits of desegregation policies and physical investments to reduce disparities in youth firearm injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Regulatory B cells (Bregs) play an important role in preventing transplant rejection and inhibiting autoimmune diseases. However, Bregs remain poorly understood. We can now directly identify these cells and determine how and where they work in vivo. Study of mice that have with a greatly increased number of Bregs will identify the factors controlling their expansion. These studies will provide critical new insight necessary to harness these potent cells to promote allograft survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibodies have emerged as one of the most powerful and effective classes of drugs to treat a wide variety of human diseases including cancer, autoimmunity and inflammatory conditions. While much effort in the past has been devoted to engineering antibodies to recognize distinct targets, the next generation of antibodies will derive enhanced clinical efficacy from engineering efforts aimed at manipulating the manner in which antibodies engage immune receptors and the subsequent immune system reactions that they induce. Experiments proposed in this application are designed to capitalize on our growing understanding of a family of antibody-modifying enzymes in order to use them more effectively to modify antibodies in novel ways, so as to unleash the full potential of antibody drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The major goal of this grant application is to determine the molecular mechanisms in which MMP1 regulate age- related skin dermal extracellular matrix (dermal aging), and the impact of these processes on the pathogenesis of many age-related skin diseases. In this application, we propose a novel concept that dermal aging process is driven by fibroblasts adaptation to deleterious surrounding ECM microenvironment. Thus, we view skin dermal aging as “outside-in adaptation”; age-related deterioration of the dermal ECM (composition, structural integrity, organization, and mechanical properties) drives cellular aging by altering ﬁbroblast spreading/mechanical force and impairing MMP1 activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Although research documents that adult sexual assault (ASA) is a serious public health concern that disproportionally impacts sexual minority (SM) men, we know little to date about risk and protective factors related to ASA victimization and perpetration experiences among this population as well as factors that promote or hinder adverse outcomes among SM men who experience ASA victimization. The purpose of this study is to utilize a longitudinal, prospective design to test three innovative models, inclusive of intersecting social identities , that include well-established (e.g., heavy episodic drinking), as well as population-specific (e.g., internalized homonegativity), risk and protective factors to predict (1) experiences of ASA victimization among SM men; (2) experiences of ASA perpetration among SM men; and (3) adverse outcomes among SM men who experience ASA victimization. The proposed project aligns with NIMHD’s research priorities to advance the scientific understanding of health disparities and improve minority health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This project will develop new methodology for improving the resolution of sodium images from the human brain. There have been approaches for generating sodium images of the brain using imaging times that are suitable for routine clinical use, however these images suffer from significant blur as a result of the demanding nature of this brain imaging application (much weaker signal than conventional MRI vanishing very quickly after it has been generated). Our approach seeks to reduce the deleterious effects of this blur through the use of anatomical information from concurrently acquired high-resolution conventional MRI scans of the brain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus is an infection that can be easily transmitted from women to newborns at the time of delivery. The REVERT-B study (Reducing Vertical Transmission of Hepatitis B in Africa) is a clinical trial designed to test a new strategy of using antiviral medication in high-risk pregnant women and newborns to reduce the risk of hepatitis B transmission. The study will measure efficacy, safety, tolerability and adherence to medication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Acute toluene intoxication, which constitutes a worldwide public health problem, is associated with severe neurological deficits and even death driven by brain ischemia, yet the molecular targets and mechanisms involved in the brain hypoperfusion evoked by toluene remain unknown. Departing from previous work that focused on the role of neuronal ion channels in toluene intoxication, this study will identify the ion channel complex of the BK type which is present in cerebral artery smooth muscle as the target that mediates toluene- induced cerebral artery constriction, and the relative contribution of BK channel subunits and channel functional states to toluene action. This information is critical to predict the differential vulnerability of cerebral arteries that irrigate different brain areas to toluene, and the efficacy of endothelium-independent vasodilators that selectively target BK subunits to counteract toluene’s deleterious action, these agents acquiring significant potential as they will remain effective under prevalent conditions that may disrupt endothelial cerebrovascular function, such as diabetes, ageing, hypertension and stroke itself.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Pericytes are multipotent precursor cells in human tissues, which also demonstrate tissue-specific properties in their innate differentiation potentials. Comparative transcriptomics between human pericytes of different anatomical sites identified TIAM1 as a potent regulator of cellular fate decisions. Here, we will investigate this activator of the Rho family of small GTPases as a molecular switch that determines osteogenic versus adipogenic differentiation in human pericytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will measure the relationship between telemedicine adoption by skilled nursing facilities and clinical outcomes among their residents with dementia, as well as characterize the factors associated with different patterns of telemedicine use by SNFs with claims and survey data. Results from this proposal will inform how Medicare and state Medicaid programs should regulate and promote telemedicine use in these settings. Our findings will also help guide clinicians who care for residents with dementia on the clinical impact associated with telemedicine use and how it is being used nationally, both of which address NIA's mission of improving the health and well-being of older Americans for those residing in nursing homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that 75% or more of breast cancer survivors report cancer-related cognitive impairments (CRCI) that are associated with reduced functional ability and quality of life, efforts to adequately assess CRCI are critical. We aim to provide valuable knowledge that will advance the science in accurately measuring CRCI in the context of everyday life. Findings from this study will provide critical data for establishing best practices for using cognitive patient reported outcomes in CRCI research and clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is strong evidence that viruses kill neural progenitor cells and impair neurogenesis through an unknown mechanism. We recently discovered that the widely used recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV) kills dividing neural progenitor cells and ablates adult neurogenesis. In the current proposal, we aim to uncover the cellular and molecular pathways that mediate this rAAV-induced toxicity in order to identify a universal mechanism for viral causes of neurodevelopment disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Non-standard viral genomes generated during virus replication are critical determinants of disease severity in humans during infection with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Here we propose experiments to advance our understanding of the host and viral factors that determine the accumulation and activity of cbVG during RSV infection. This virus infects 100% of the human population at an early age and represents a large public health burden. The proposed studies may identify new opportunities to reduce the burden of RSV disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Two-thirds of older adults with severe injuries are treated at non-trauma centers (under-triage), despite evidence that care at trauma centers reduces preventable deaths (lives that appropriate and timely medical care would have saved). One of the critical barriers to reducing preventable deaths after injury is the absence of interventions that improve physician decision making. The objective of this proposal is to test the real-world efficacy of video game interventions designed to promote physician use of evidence-based practices.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: This HIV training grant will build upon existing research at our institutions to improve human capacity in HIV- related hematology and transfusion research in South Africa. It aims to improve the academic research stature of the Clinical Hematology division at University of Cape Town and historically disadvantaged partner institutions and to continue to strengthen the Research and Development Academy at the South African National Blood Services. Research will include studies of HIV-positive participants and blood specimens, studies of HIV cure, studies the use novel technologies to detect HIV and implementation science studies directed at HIV-related lymphoma and anemia and exclusion of HIV-infected persons from blood donation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview-based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Anti-cancer drugs and environmental chemicals elevate irreversible protein trapping in DNA, inducing a DNA damage response and mutagenesis if not repaired properly. The proposed research examines the key steps in cellular mechanisms that eliminate trapped proteins in DNA and thereby prevent the development of several motor neuron diseases and therapeutic resistance in breast and ovarian cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE; PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The present study aims to provide insight on the effects of minority stress, affect, and sociocultural protective factors on Hispanic and white sexual minority youth’s (SMY) use of alcohol. The study will test whether the double jeopardy or resiliency hypothesis predict use of alcohol and the sociocultural protective factors that explain the differences between Hispanic and white SMY alcohol use. Findings will help to identify risk of alcohol use among SMY and the protective factors that could be leveraged in treatment to help address problematic drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is a multicenter, randomized, double-masked, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to test the hypothesis that oxidative damage is a major contributor to cone cell death in retinitis pigmentosa (RP) and that long-term oral N-acetylcysteine will promote cone survival and reduce severe visual disability. It has the potential to provide a treatment that applies to all patients with RP regardless of the causative mutation and help to maintain visual function and reduce severe disability. It will also answer the scientific question, to what extent does oxidative damage contribute to cone cell death in RP and is it a target for the development of additional treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is the leading cause of death in industrialized societies. Our research studies the critical role of membrane abnormalities during heart failure. We have discovered new pathways that generate toxic molecules promoting the progression cardiac compromise. The proposed research is directed toward identifying several levels of new targeted approaches for the treatment of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to develop a new molecular strategy to limit subretinal fibrosis in blinding eye disease. Adenosine receptor 2A (Adora2a) is expressed in choroidal endothelial cells and macrophages and contributes to their transitions to mesenchymal cells and myofibroblasts. The proposed studies are designed to use Adora2a deficient cells and mice to investigate the involvement of different cellular Adora2a in subretinal fibrosis and to define the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cross-coupling reactions enable the construction of new C–X bonds (X = C, N, O, F, etc.) necessary for the synthesis of existing pharmaceuticals and new drug candidates. While precious metal Pd-based catalysts are largely used on an industrial scale, the combination of the disparate electron transfer properties of earth abundant first row transition metal catalysts and the possibility of harnessing light energy to generate uniquely reactive electronic states represents an attractive, sustainable approach to accessing new mechanistic possibilities for drug synthesis and discovery. Using a combined spectroscopic and computational approach, the objective of this proposal is to define the critical electronic structure contributions to ground state Cu- and Ni-catalyzed cross-couplings and to further use and develop time-resolved spectroscopies to elucidate key excited state factors that allow for sustainable light-driven syntheses of molecular therapeutics.

PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding Geometric and Electronic Structure Contributions to Ground and Excited State Cu- and Ni-Catalyzed Cross-Coupling Reactions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL - Center for Native Environmental Health Equity Research Indigenous communities in the US experience substantially higher rates of chronic diseases and an ever- increasing prevalence of cancer compared to the US population overall with decades of industrial mining, in these communities that rely heavily on natural resources resulting in disparately greater exposures to the waste from 161,000 abandoned hard rock mines remaining within 10km of 600,000 tribal members. Disparities in solid waste infrastructure and continued use of low-temperature burning results in incomplete combustion of ever-increasing amounts of plastics in the waste stream now adds exposure concerns due to microplastics and other plastic degradation products that now combine with and exacerbate the metals exposures, further increasing risks for cancer and other chronic diseases. This Center will identify these emerging tribal contaminants and evaluate exposure:disease relationships to develop mitigation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary open angle glaucoma is a complex chronic disease that affects over 2.9 million people in the United States and is the 2nd leading cause of blindness in this country. Clinical decision making for glaucoma is challenging, as clinicians must incorporate large amounts of longitudinal data from many data sources, which often results in suboptimal testing and management. This study will lead to the development of a standards- based clinical decision support system that presents data at the point of care to help clinicians determine a personalized frequency for visual field testing for patients with glaucoma, which will reduce over- and under- testing and ultimately prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This decade has seen an explosive, devastating epidemic of opioid use disorder (OUD) in the U.S. Yet few treatments for OUD have emerged from neuroscience, perhaps in part due to a failure of conventional rodent models to capture fundamental behavioral aspects of the disorder. Using state of the art tools for manipulating and determining activity within brain circuits and networks during translationally-relevant behaviors in rats, we determine the specific roles of GABAergic ventral pallidum neurons in OUD-like behaviors, thus potentially opening new therapeutic avenues to treat addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 200,000 new cases of ovarian cancer (OC) occur per year worldwide, but the overall survival of OC has not significantly changed for decades. Therapies targeting host immune cells to destroy cancer cells have shown great promise in many tumor types, but thus far most OC patients have failed to respond. This project will determine how P53, which is mutated in nearly 100% of the most common OC subtype, affects epigenetic regulation of repetitive elements in OC to activate immune cells against tumors, informing future epigenetic and immune therapies against this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to eliminate inequities in birth outcomes for black women. This timely and urgent project not only aligns with NICHD’s goal of preventing pregnancy-related complications and reducing maternal and infant death but will further underscore the negative impact of racialized police violence on society, bolstering arguments for large-scale change in police-community interactions. This study also marks an important change in public health framing from one that incorrectly names race—a seemingly immutable characteristic—as a “risk factor” to one that centers racism as a fundamental cause of health inequities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Exposure to volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is an important determinant of maternal-fetal health, with implications for preterm birth and other adverse health outcomes. VOCs contaminate shallow soils and groundwater of post-industrial cities at Superfund, residential, commercial, and industrial properties, leading to exposures via vapor intrusion. The outcome of this study will help to understand the impact of VOCs on the fetal immune development and the susceptibility to respiratory viral infections in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application aims to evaluate the clinical safety, proof of concept efficacy, and pharmacokinetic profile of HBI-002, an oral low dose carbon monoxide (CO) drug product with dual mechanisms of action in a Phase 2a clinical study in sickle cell disease (SCD). If successful, this research will provide critical safety, efficacy, dosing, and mechanistic information for advancing HBI-002 into later stage clinical trials in SCD, with the ultimate objective being to provide a multimodal therapeutic to reduce the incidence of vaso-occlusive crises and inflammation, thus reducing the incidence of disability and premature mortality in this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Severe, drug-resistant asthma is a growing public health issue in the United States and worldwide, creating a large burden on the health care system. The goal of this proposed work is to understand aberrant immune responses in severe asthma, a subset of disease that is poorly responsive to standard therapies. Our novel focus on the role of immune mediators, interleukin-22 binding protein, type I interferons, and interleukin- 22, in severe asthma will identify targets for the development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reproductive success in several mammalian species is greatly limited by embryo loss due to chromosomal abnormalities, or aneuploidy. The proposed studies aim to determine the precise relationship between aneuploidy and a dynamic process called cellular fragmentation that differs in frequency across mammals using a comparative genomics approach. This work has the potential to improve reproductive efficiency in agriculturally important animals and for translational application to human assisted reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic Dermatitis remains one of the most important challenges to pediatric public health in the United States affecting millions of children and adults, and continues to increase in prevalence, causing significant morbidity, mortality, and tremendous financial burden. The causes, genetic bases and relationship between S aureus skin colonization and AD remain incompletely understood. We will contribute extensively to the Atopic Dermatitis Research Network as a Clinical Research Unit through successful implementation, scientific expertise, and training of the next generation of NIH funded investigators skilled in AD. We will also specifically examine the role of genetic and microbial modifiers in AD by investigating the mechanisms of increased AD severity in patients with the R576 polymorphism in IL-4Rα and the impact of S aureus skin decolonization on AD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Macrophages play a critical role in host defense and tissue repair, but their dysregulation leads to chronic inflammatory diseases associated with metabolic disorders. Our data support a new paradigm that implicates Mao A and Nox4-derived ROS production in both monocyte “priming” and dysfunction induced by metabolic disorders and the subsequent reprogramming of monocyte-derived macrophages as early and essential drivers of atherogenesis. The studies we propose here aim to test this novel paradigm and to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms.
